Primary city commission members shall notify alternate members as far in advance of meetings as possible when the primary member will not be able to attend a board or committee meeting. 
(Ord. 1657-2001 § 2, 2001). 
Chapter 2.32 - ORDINANCES VIOLATION BUREAU*[] 

Footnotes: 
--- () --- 
* For statutory provisions on violations of municipal ordinances, see N.M. Stat. Ann. Ch. 35 Art 15. 

2.32.010 - Established-Purpose-Administration. 
A.  There is established an ordinance violation bureau of the city, for the purpose of assisting the municipal court in disposing of violations of city ordinances relating to building operation and maintenance, zoning regulations, collection of taxes and service charges, fire and fire prevention, public health and sanitation, and animals. 
B.  The municipal judge is charged with the duty of administering the functions of the bureau. 
(Prior code § 2-47). 
2.32.020 - Citation-Issuance procedure. 
A.  Whenever any city official or employee authorized by this chapter to issue citations discovers any violation of city ordinance as enumerated in Section 2.32.010, or as may be designated by court rule, such official or employee may issue a citation to the person alleged to have committed the violation or owning or occupying the premises upon which the violation is alleged to have been committed and such citation shall be in the form specified in this chapter. 
B.  Such tag shall be made out in triplicate. One copy thereof shall be issued to the person alleged to have committed the violation; one copy to be filed with the department primarily responsible for the enforcement of the city ordinance alleged to have been violated; and one copy shall be filed with the ordinances violation bureau. 
(Prior code § 2-48). 
2.32.030 - Citation-Issuance authority-Restrictions. 
    Pursuant to the authority contained in section 38-1-3, New Mexico Statutes 1953 Annotated, any duly appointed official or employee of the city entrusted with enforcement of any of the ordinances specified in Section 2.32.010 shall have the same power possessed by police officers of the city to issue citations in the same manner and with the same force and effect as citations issued by police officers, but such citations shall relate only to those offenses mentioned in Section 2.32.010 and no city official or employee other than a police officer shall physically arrest or take into custody any violator except on a warrant duly issued. In no event shall a citation be issued for any offense constituting a breach of the peace. 
(Prior code § 2-49). 
2.32.040 - Citation-Defined-Contents. 
A.  As used in this chapter, "citation" means a written or printed notice served upon the person charged with a violation. 
B.  Such citation shall be in a form to be approved by the municipal judge and shall contain the following: 
1.  The name and address of the person creating the violation or the owner or person in charge of the premises at which the violation occurs; 
2.  The date and place of violation; 
3.  A short description of the violation followed by the number and section of city ordinance violated; 
4.  The date and place at which the cited person shall appear and a notice that if the person tagged does not respond to the tag a warrant may be issued for such person's arrest; 
5.  A notice that the person charged may be represented by counsel, that he may plead guilty, and that he has a right to a court hearing; 
6.  Such other information as the municipal judge may specify. 
(Prior code § 2-50). 
2.32.050 - Citation-Service. 
    The citation shall be personally served upon the owner or person in charge of the premises alleged to be in violation. 
(Prior code § 2-51). 
2.32.060 - Citation-Plea entry. 
    After the service of the citation and within such time is fixed by court rule, the person alleged to be responsible for the violation, or his attorney or agent, shall report to the ordinances violation bureau and may then and there enter a written plea of guilty and pay the fine prescribed by court rule; or such person may plead guilty and request a court appearance, or may plead not guilty and be assigned a date for court appearance. 
(Prior code § 2-52). 
2.32.070 - Citation-Failure to appear. 
    If the person charged with the violation does not appear at the bureau within the time specified by court rule, the bureau shall send him a notice directing him to respond to the citation within ten days of the date of the notice, and if such person fails to respond, the bureau shall cause a complaint to be signed by the complainant and a warrant issued for the arrest of such person and his appearance in court. Failure to appear as required by the terms of a citation issued to any person under the terms of this chapter shall constitute a violation of this chapter separate and distinct from the violation for which the citation was issued, and in addition to such violation. Failure to appear upon a citation shall subject the violator to a fine of not more than three hundred dollars or to a term of imprisonment in the city jail for not more than ninety days. 
(Prior code § 2-53). 
2.32.080 - Citation-Consecutive numbering. 
    All citations issued pursuant to the terms of this chapter shall be numbered consecutively beginning with the number one, and no citation shall be cancelled or voided after issuance except by the municipal court. The city treasurer shall have control of and be accountable for all tags, either issued or unissued. 
(Prior code § 2-54). 
2.32.090 - Recordkeeping-Revenue disposition. 
A.  The ordinances violation bureau shall keep a complete record of all citations brought into or processed through it. 
B.  All money received by the bureau as payment for fines shall be paid over to the city treasurer as in the case of all other fines levied by the municipal court. 
(Prior code § 2-55). 
Chapter 2.36 - CLOVIS CULTURAL/ETHNIC AFFAIRS COMMITTEE 

2.36.010 - Establishment. 
    There is created the Clovis Cultural/Ethnic Affairs Committee which is referred to in this chapter as "the committee." 
(Ord. 1694-2002 § 3(part), 2002). 
2.36.020 - Appointment of members-Qualifications-Terms-Compensation. 
A.  The committee shall consist of seven voting members; one city commissioner and six members of the public, appointed by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the city commission. The city manager, or his designee, shall serve in a non-voting ex-officio capacity. 
B.  Members of the committee shall be persons that have professional competence or experience with the arts, cultural activities, or ethnic affairs. 
C.  One public member shall be a resident of each commission district recommended by the commissioners of that district. Two public members shall be residents of Curry County, residing outside the incorporated limits of the city of Clovis. 
D.  Public members shall serve a term of two years, which shall be staggered. Initial public members shall determine the initial term by lot. 
E.  Any non-commissioner committee member may be removed from office by the mayor, with the consent of the city commission, after due notice that such member has missed three consecutive meetings or has been absent at fifty percent of the meetings held during any twelve-month period. In the event of removal under this section, the position shall become vacant and shall be filled as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 1694-2002 § 3(part), 2002). 
(Ord. No. 2102-2018, § 2, 6-7-18). 
2.36.030 - Officers-Meetings. 
A.  The city commission member shall serve as chairperson. 
B.  The committee shall elect annually from its members, a vice chairman. 
C.  Meetings of the committee shall be held at least quarterly, or at the call of the chairperson. 
D.  All meetings of the committee shall be open to the public. 
(Ord. 1694-2002 § 3(part), 2002). 
(Ord. No. 2102-2018, § 2, 6-7-18). 
2.36.040 - Powers and duties of the committee. 
    The powers and duties of the committee shall be: 
A.  To advise and assist public agencies in planning civic activities; 
B.  To foster appreciation for the fine arts and for ethnic activities that create cultural diversity within the arts; 
C.  To encourage the creative activity in the arts of residents of this city, to enhance knowledge of cultural diversities, and to attract to this city additional outstanding creators in the field of fine arts through appropriate programs of publicity, education, coordination, and direct activities such as sponsorship of performing and visual arts; which may include: 
1.  Conduct an annual ethnic fair. 
2.  Promote and conduct activities relating to our multicultural New Mexican heritage, including African American, Anglo, Asian, Hispanic, Latino, Middle Eastern, Native American, and other ethnic communities. 
3.  Develop programs or events relating to the "Clovis Man" history of Eastern New Mexico. 
4.  Promote the use of the Lyceum Theatre for entertainment, cultural, and artistic events. 
5.  Encourage interaction relating to cultural and artistic activities with Clovis Community College, Eastern New Mexico University, Cannon Air Force Base and with other government entities, private organizations, and educational institutions (Clovis Municipal Schools, Clovis Christian School). 
6.  Develop ways to utilize lodger's tax revenues to promote qualifying events and activities. 
7.  Pursue activities, presentations, performances, exhibitions, exchanges, and events that will promote cultural advancement and ethnic diversification in the community. 
8.  Coordinate consideration of sister city program to promote cultural and ethnic relationships beyond the local community. 
D.  To make a report to the city commission, not less frequently than annually, on the activities and progress of the committee and on the recommendations of the committee for expenditures which the committee feels necessary to further the purpose of this chapter; 
E.  To accept on behalf of the city such donations of money, property or memorials as, in its discretion, are suitable and shall best further the aims of this chapter. The committee shall be empowered to accept any additional gifts, contributions or bequests from private persons, corporations, foundations or agencies, or the federal government. Such monies so received may be reemployed as a part of a revolving fund to be used to further the purpose of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1694-2002 § 3(part), 2002). 
(Ord. No. 2102-2018, § 2, 6-7-18). 
2.36.050 - Removal. 
    Any non-commissioner committee member may be removed from office by the mayor, with the consent of the city commission after due notice that such member has missed three consecutive meetings or has been absent at fifty percent of the meetings held during any twelve-month period. In the event of removal under this section, the position shall become vacant and shall be filled as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 1694-2002 § 3(part), 2002). 
Chapter 2.44 - PLANNING-ZONING COMMISSION* 

2.44.010 - Created. 
    There is created a commission to be known as the city planning-zoning commission. 
(Ord. 1268-85 §2, 1985: Ord. 1086-77 §1(part), 1977: prior code §2-17(part)). 
2.44.015 - Reference to planning commission or zoning commission. 
    Henceforth, all references in the ordinances of the city referring to the function and duties of the planning commission or zoning commission shall refer to the planning-zoning commission. 
(Ord. 1268-85 § 7, 1985). 
2.44.020 - Membership-Appointment. 
    The planning-zoning commission shall consist of seven members. The members shall be appointed by the mayor and with the consent of the city commission for two-year terms. The initial terms of three commissioners shall be for one year in order that no more than four commission terms shall expire in any year. One member of the commission shall at all times be an officer, agent, employee or representative of a public utility operating and performing services within the city. One member of the commission shall at all times be a member of the city commission. In the event of any vacancy on the commission, the mayor, with the consent of the city commission, may appoint a member to fill the unexpired term of the retiring, resigning or removed commissioner. Any commissioner may be removed at any time for good cause by the vote of two-thirds of the membership of the city commission. Four members of the commission shall constitute a quorum for the exercising of the duties of said commission. 
(Ord. 1268-85 § 3(part), 1985: prior code § 2-18). 
2.44.025 - Removal. 
    Any member of the planning-zoning commission may be removed from office by the mayor, with the consent of the city commission after due notice and hearing if such member has missed three consecutive meetings or has been absent from more than fifty percent of the meetings held during any twelve-month period of time. 
(Ord. 1331-88 § 2, 1988). 
2.44.030 - Ex officio members. 
    The city manager or the assistant city manager, the building inspector, and the city planner (if employed) shall be ex officio members of the planning-zoning commission without right to vote. 
(Ord. 1268-85 § 3(part), 1985: prior code § 2-19). 
2.44.040 - Powers and duties-Generally. 
    There are delegated to the planning-zoning commission the following powers: 
A.  The power, authority, jurisdiction and duty to enforce and carry out the provisions of law relating to planning, platting, zoning and subdivision; 
B.  All other power, authority, jurisdiction and duty incidental and necessary to carry out the purposes of Sections 3-19-1 through 3-19-12, and 3-21-1 through 3-21-26, New Mexico Statutes Annotated 1978; 
C.  To hold public meetings and recommend changes, alterations or modifications of the areas of the zoning districts established or to be established under the provisions of the laws of the state of New Mexico or the ordinances of the city; and 
D.  To recommend amendments, supplements, changes, modifications or repeals of regulations, restrictions or boundaries established or to be established under the provisions of this ordinance or the laws of the state of New Mexico; 
E.  To vary or adjust the strict application of any of the requirements of the zoning ordinances enacted by the city, in any case in which such strict application would result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship that would deprive the owner of the reasonable use of the land or improvements involved. No variance from the strict application of any provision of the applicable zoning ordinances shall be granted by the planning-zoning commission unless it finds: 
1.  That there are special circumstances or conditions fully described in the minutes and findings of the commission, applying to the land or improvement for which the variance is sought, which circumstances or conditions are peculiar to such land or improvement and do not apply generally to land or improvements in the neighborhood and have not resulted from any act of the applicant subsequent to the adoption of an ordinance by the city, whether in violation of the provisions hereof or not; 
2.  That for reasons fully set forth in the minutes and findings of the commission, the aforesaid circumstances or conditions are such that the strict application of the provisions of this title would deprive the applicant of the reasonable use of such land or improvement, and the granting of the variance would be necessary for the reasonable use of the land or improvement, and that the variance recommended by the commission is the minimum variance that will accomplish this purpose. 
3.  That the granting of the variance would be in harmony with the general purpose and intent of the zoning ordinances of the city, will not be injurious to the neighborhood or the property owners in the neighborhood or otherwise detrimental to the public welfare. 
(Ord. 1305-87 § 2 (part), 1987: Ord. 1268-85 § 4, 1985: Ord. 1086-77 § 1(part), 1977: prior code § 2-17(part)). 
2.44.041 - Recommendation of planning-zoning commission. 
    Prior to consideration of any preliminary plat or master plan, the planning-zoning commission shall send letters of notification by regular mail to the owners of property within the city located within one hundred feet of the property proposed for preliminary plat or master plan. In addition, the city staff shall post signs on the property at least one week prior to consideration, setting forth the type of action being requested and the date, time and location of the planning-zoning commission meeting. When the planning-zoning commission has completed all steps required by law, by this code and by its subdivision regulations, relating to a proposed preliminary plat or master plan of a new subdivision, within the planning and platting jurisdiction of the city, the planning-zoning commission shall submit such preliminary plat or master plan to the city commission with a written recommendation. Any member or members of the planning-zoning commission may submit a minority report to the city commission. 
(Ord. 1305-86 § 4(part), 1987: Ord. 1214-83 § 2, 1983). 
2.44.042 - Approval and recording of plat. 
A.  The preliminary plat of a new subdivision located within the planning and platting jurisdiction of the city shall be subject to final approval of the city commission, after consideration and recommendation by the planning-zoning commission. The city manager or his designee shall have final power to adopt and approve final plats of subdivisions which substantially conform to preliminary plats or master plans already approved by the city commission, subject to the right of appeal to the city commission. For purpose of this section, "substantially conform" shall be interpreted as no change in rights-of-way or easements from the master plan or preliminary plat. Copies of all finally approved plats shall be submitted to the city commission for their information. No final plat shall be submitted for filing to the office of the county clerk of Curry County until such plat has been properly approved according to the terms of this section, with the approval being evidenced on the face of the plat by the signature of the chairman of the planning-zoning commission and the mayor, which shall be attested by the city clerk, and by the seal of the city. 
B.  Once the final plat has been approved and properly executed, the applicant shall submit the proper recording fee and the city shall record the final plat at the office of the Curry County clerk. Any final plat which has not been recorded sixty days after approval shall be void. Any final plats which have been approved and executed prior to the effective date of the ordinance codified in this section and which are in the possession of the property owner, shall be void if not recorded by December 31, 1992. 
(Ord. 1423-92 § 2, 1992: Ord. 1305-87 § 4(part), 1987: Ord. 1214-83 § 3, 1983). 
2.44.050 - Powers and duties-Street vacations. 
A.  In addition to those powers granted by Section 2.44.040, the planning-zoning commission is empowered to hear and investigate all applications for vacation of streets, alleys or other public ways within the corporate limits of the city. All applications for such vacations are directed to the planning-zoning commission for its study and recommendation. 
B.  The planning-zoning commission is directed to conduct a public hearing on each such application for vacation, and the date, time and place of each such public hearing shall be advertised in a newspaper of general circulation within the city at least ten days before the time set for such hearing. Personal notice of such hearing shall be given at least ten days before the date of such hearing by mail to the persons owning property within three hundred feet of the street, alley or other public way to which the application to vacate relates, and a special written notice shall also be given to all the utility companies operating in the public way under franchise granted by the city commission. At such hearing the planning-zoning commission shall hear all interested parties and shall thereafter submit in writing a recommendation to the city commission concerning such application for vacation. No vacation shall be accomplished except by ordinance passed by the city commission. 
C.  The planning-zoning commission is authorized to adopt such rules and regulations relating to the powers conferred upon it by this section as may be deemed necessary. 
(Prior code § 2-17.1). 
2.44.060 - Powers and duties-Fencing variance authority. 
    In addition to those powers granted by Section 2.44.040, the planning-zoning commission is authorized to vary the requirements of Sections 15.44.020 and 15.44.030, pertaining to fences, in any subdivision approved by the planning-zoning commission pursuant to its subdivision regulations. No variance of fencing requirements shall become effective until after a public hearing at which all parties in interest and citizens shall have an opportunity to be heard. Notice of the time and place of the public hearing shall be published one time in a newspaper of general circulation within the city at least fifteen days prior to the date of any variance. The commission, upon authorizing a variance to fencing requirements within any subdivision, shall require the subdivider to insert the terms of the variance in the protective covenants and restrictions for that subdivision, and shall require that the protective covenants and restrictions be recorded in the office of the county clerk of Curry County as a public record. 
(Ord. 1086-77 § 2, 1977: prior code § 2-17.2). 
2.44.065 - Powers and duties-Comprehensive plan. 
    In addition to the powers and duties of the commission granted in this title, the planning-zoning commission shall: 
A.  Research, review and complete studies needed for the update and revision of the Clovis comprehensive plan. 
B.  Evaluate policies, plans, procedures, codes, resolutions, ordinances and rules and regulations of the city relating to the Clovis comprehensive plan and the quality of life within the Clovis, New Mexico area. 
C.  Take action necessary to obtain from citizens, expert consultants, commissions and boards a comprehensive volume of comments and recommendations relative to the Clovis comprehensive plan. 
D.  Make a report to the city commission of the activities of the commission and recommendations of the commission for the amendment and/or revision of the Clovis comprehensive plan. 
E.  Conduct periodic meetings of the commission and public hearings and meetings as necessary to perform the duties set forth in this section. 
F.  Investigate and provide recommendations as directed by the city commission. 
(Ord. 1687-2001 § 3, 2001). 
2.44.070 - Powers and duties-Zoning variances. 
    The planning-zoning commission shall have final power to grant zoning variances, and to adopt and approve final plats of subdivisions which substantially conform to preliminary plats or master- plans already approved by the city commission, subject to the right of appeal to the city commission. Copies of all variances and final plats approved by the planning-zoning commission shall be submitted in writing to the city commission for their information. The city commission shall retain final power and authority to make or grant zone changes or to finally adopt subdivision master plans or preliminary plats. All applications for zone changes and adoption of master plans or preliminary plats shall be referred to the planning-zoning commission, which shall make a written recommendation to the city commission. 
(Ord. 1305-87 § 2 (part), 1987: Ord. 1268-85 § 5, 1985). 
2.44.075 - Public hearing and procedures for variances, conditional uses, and conforming uses. 
A.  Quasi-judicial matters. Land use issues involving requests for variances, conditional uses, and nonconforming uses are quasi-judicial matters which will be decided by the Planning-Zoning Commission following a public hearing conducted in accordance with this section. All other zoning decisions by City officials are legislative determinations. 
B.  Parties. 
1.  The parties to a hearing shall be any of the following persons who have filed a written appearance of record with the chairman of the planning and zoning commission or the planning and inspection department three days prior to the date of the public hearing, or other persons permitted by the planning-zoning commission chairperson: 
a.  A person entitled to notice; 
b.  Representatives of any department or agency of the city or another unit of local government; 
c.  A person who satisfies the chairperson that he has a significant interest in the subject matter of the hearing. 
2.  A written statement giving the name and address of the person making the appearance, signed by him or by his agent, and filed with the manner prescribed herein, constitutes an appearance of record. 
C.  Conduct of Public Hearing. 
1.  All testimony at the hearing shall be under oath or affirmation. 
2.  A party shall be afforded an opportunity to present evidence and argument and to question witnesses on all relevant issues, but the chairperson may impose reasonable limitations on the number of witnesses, and on the nature and length of their testimony and questioning. The planning-zoning commission may call witnesses and introduce evidence on their own volition. 
3.  The planning-zoning commission may adopt specific regulations for the conduct of proceedings at a public hearing, which shall become effective upon approval of the city commission. 
4.  The chairperson shall make a full record of the hearing by sound recording; any person shall have the opportunity to listen to, copy, buy, or transcribe the recording at any reasonable time at the city inspection department. Summary minutes shall be kept of all public hearings, and they shall be kept available for public inspection. 
5.  The planning-zoning commission shall adopt written bindings of act and conclusions which shall become a part of the record. 
D.  Appeals. 
1.  Appeals from decisions of the planning-zoning commission shall be made in the manner and within the time period for other appeals from the planning-zoning commission to the city commission. 
2.  When appeals are made to the city commission, the city commission shall consider the appeal at a regular or special meeting, after notice to all parties. The appeal will be considered on the entire record, consisting of the written arguments, exhibits, summary minutes, findings of fact and conclusions, and the transcript, if deemed necessary by the city commission. The city commission may reverse, affirm, or modify the decision appealed, and it's decision will be final. If it appears to the city commission that testimony is necessary for the proper disposition of the matter, it may upon a majority vote take evidence, which shall constitute a part of the proceedings upon which the determination shall be made. Alternatively, the city commission may demand the matter to the planning-zoning commission for reconsideration. 
(Ord. 1370-90 § 2, 1990). 
2.44.080 - Chairman-Meetings-Rule adoption. 
    The planning-zoning commission shall: 
A.  Elect one of its members chairman for a one-year term; 
B.  Make recommendations to the city commission for the filling of vacancies; 
C.  Hold at least one regular meeting each month; 
D.  Adopt rules for the transaction of business; and E. Keep a public record of its transactions, findings, resolutions, determinations and recommendations. 
(Ord. 1268-85 § 6, 1985). 
2.44.082 - Powers and duties-Comprehensive plan. 
    In addition to those powers granted in this chapter, the planning-zoning commission shall annually conduct a review of the Clovis comprehensive plan and shall submit a report to the city commission with comments, general recommendations, and specific recommendations on changes, amendments or deletions to the comprehensive plan. In furtherance of this duty, the planning-zoning commission is authorized to conduct public hearings to obtain information and citizen input. If approved by a majority of the members of the planning-zoning commission, the commission may recommend to the Clovis city commission that the comprehensive plan committee be activated to conduct a full reevaluation and revision of the Clovis comprehensive plan. 
(Ord. 1526-97 § 2, 1997). 
Chapter 2.45 - PARKS, RECREATION AND BEAUTIFICATION COMMITTEE 

2.45.010 - Creation. 
    There is created in the city a parks, recreation and beautification committee. 
(Ord. No. 1976-2012, § 3, 2-23-12). 
2.45.020 - Membership. 
    The committee shall consist of ten members appointed by the mayor, with the consent of the city commission. There shall be four city commissioners, one from each district; and four citizen members, one from each commissioner district. The ninth member shall be a representative from a group that utilizes the parks and recreation services. The tenth member shall be a resident of Curry County, outside the city, who has experience, expertise, or an interest in the functions of the committee. The mayor, city manager or his designee, parks and recreation director, and a representative from the Clovis municipal schools shall serve as ex-officio members and advisors to the committee. 
(Ord. No. 1976-2012, § 3, 2-23-12; Ord. No. 2028-2014, § 2, 10-16-14). 
2.45.030 - Term of office-Vacancy. 
A.  The terms of the non-commissioner committee members shall be two years and shall be staggered with two of the citizen member positions to have an initial term of one year. 
B.  Any member of the committee may be removed from office by the mayor, with the consent of the city commission. Any committee member that has missed three consecutive meetings or has been absent at fifty percent of the meetings during any twelve-month period shall be removed and the vacancy shall be filled for the remainder of the term by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 1976-2012, § 3, 2-23-12). 
2.45.040 - Meetings. 
A.  The members of the committee are empowered to, perform their duties and make such rules for the administration, regulation and conduct of the affairs of the committee as they may deem proper, necessary and expedient, and may at any time alter, amend or abrogate such rules and regulations. 
B.  The committee shall hold at least one meeting each calendar quarter. 
(Ord. No. 1976-2012, § 3, 2-23-12). 
2.45.050 - Duties and responsibilities. 
    The duties and responsibilities of the parks, recreation and beautification committee shall be to act in an advisory capacity to the city commission and city administration in the following areas: 
A.  The administering of recreational programs and measures regarding public use of parks; 
B.  Policies and fee structures for all park and recreation services and programs; 
C.  The development of recreational areas, facilities, programs and improvement of recreational services; 
D.  The adoption of standards on facilities, programs and financial resources; 
E.  The coordination of city recreation services with the programs of other governmental agencies and voluntary organizations; 
F.  Provide review and oversight of current and future recreational activities held at the Ned Houk Park; 
G.  Oversight of the grazing leases at Ned Houk Park; 
H.  The biannual preparation of the parks master plan, holding public meetings and obtaining public input in preparing the revisions to the plan; 
I.  The identification of future recreational areas within the city; 
J.  The coordination of the city beautification activities; including, but not limited to, Keep Clovis Beautiful, Keep America Beautiful, Tree City USA and Toss No Mas; 
K.  The development, promotion and creation of sponsor programs and activities for the improvement and beautification of public and private property; 
L.  Policies, plans and procedures, codes, resolutions, ordinances, rules and regulations of the city relating to cleanliness and beautification; 
(Ord. No. 1976-2012, § 3, 2-23-12). 
Chapter 2.50 - ECONOMIC INCENTIVE BOARD[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2052-2015, § 2, adopted August 6, 2015, renamed Chapter 2.50 from economic development advisory board as economic incentive board. 

2.50.010 - Establishment. 
    There is established the economic incentive board as an advisory committee to the Clovis city commission. 
(Ord. 1628-2000 § 2(part), 2000). 
(Ord. No. 2052-2015, § 2, 8-6-15). 
2.50.020 - Membership-Qualifications-Term. 
A.  The membership of the advisory board shall consist of eleven members appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city commission. 
B.  The eleven members shall be appointed from the following organizations or professional classification: 
1.  City Manager. 
2.  One representative of the Clovis Industrial Development Corporation (CIDC), who cannot be a member of the CIDC executive committee or a subordinate employee of a CIDC executive board committee member; 
3.  Two representatives of the banking/finance/accounting professions; 
4.  One representative of utility service providers, i.e., gas, electric, water and telecommunications; 
5.  One representative of industry, i.e., manufacturing, warehousing and transportation; 
6.  Four members at large, nominated from individual commission districts by the commissioners representing that district; 
7.  One member that is a resident of Curry County but who does not reside within the city of Clovis. 
C.  The president of Clovis Community College, the executive director of the Clovis/Curry County Chamber of Commerce, and the executive director of the Clovis Industrial Development Corporation shall serve as ex-officio (non-voting) advisors to the board. 
D.  Members shall be selected for three year terms in accordance with Chapter 2.20 of the Clovis city code. The initial terms of members, except for the city manager, shall be staggered with five members having two year initial terms and five members having three year terms. The initial term length shall be determined by lot. 
E.  In the event any vacancy occurs, a member shall be selected to fill the unexpired term from the category of membership of the vacated position. 
F.  Any member may be removed from office by the mayor, with the consent of the city commission after due notice if such member has missed three consecutive meetings or has been absent from more than fifty percent of the meetings held during any twelve-month period of time. 
G.  Members of the board shall serve without compensation. 
H.  The city manager shall serve as chairperson and shall designate another member or a city staff person to serve as secretary. The members shall annually select a member of the board to serve as vice-chairperson, who shall assume the duties of the chairperson when the chairperson is absent or otherwise unavailable. 
(Ord. 1666-2001 § 2, 2001; Ord. 1628-2000 § 2(part), 2000). 
(Ord. No. 2052-2015, § 2, 8-6-15). 
2.50.030 - Duties and responsibilities. 
    The duties and responsibilities of the board shall be to: 
A.  Advise the city commission on matters relating to economic development issues and those specific tasks referred to the board by the city commission; 
B.  Make recommendations on the expenditure of proceeds of the city economic development gross receipts tax and other incentives; 
C.  Coordinate with other local and regional agencies to maximize economic development opportunities; 
D.  Develop activities and procedures to maximize economic development opportunities; 
E.  Coordinate and work with individuals, organizations, and institutions in the pursuit of economic development projects; 
F.  Advise on the implementation of the Local Economic Development Act and other programs and activities; 
G.  Obtain information, analyze financial data and report to the Clovis city commission concerning any industrial, economic, commercial or business project requesting or applying for financial assistance from the city, whether same be for industrial revenue bond financing, the Local Economic Development Act, the Development Incentive Act, or other available source of financial assistance. Recommendations of the board are advisory only and are not binding on the city commission. Unless otherwise specified by ordinance or state law governing the procedures for evaluation, the procedures set forth in the ordinance codified in this chapter shall apply. 
H.  Coordinate local, state, and federal programs, activities, and funding sources for economic development projects. 
I.  Adopt policies and procedures for carrying out the duties and responsibilities of the board, which may include the delegation of duties and responsibilities to the Clovis Industrial Development Corporation or another agency. Any policies and procedures adopted in accordance with this section shall be subject to the approval and ratification of the city commission and shall not contradict the duties and responsibilities of the economic incentive board as stated in this chapter. 
(Ord. 1628-2000 § 2(part), 2000). 
(Ord. No. 2052-2015, § 2, 8-6-15). 
2.50.035 - Additional duties and responsibilities. 
    In addition, the board shall: 
A.  Whenever the city commission or its designated representative receives an application for assistance in connection with the establishment or construction of an industrial, commercial or business project or facility, the city commission shall direct the applicant to the board. The applicant shall be required to prepare a detailed application in writing, on a form to be provided by the board and submitted to it in accordance with currently adopted policies and procedures. 
B.  The application shall be accompanied by an application fee in an amount to be established from time to time by resolution of the city commission. If the application fee is insufficient to cover the cost of investigating and evaluating the project, the applicant shall be responsible for paying such additional amounts to cover the costs of evaluating the application. The proceeds from such application fees shall be deposited by the city treasurer as a separate line item account, which shall be used solely for purposes of funding the activities of the board. In no event shall any part of the original application fee be refundable to the applicant, regardless of the cost of processing the application. The economic incentive board shall recommend what amount, if any, of any additional application fees shall be refundable. 
C.  Upon receipt by the board of an application for municipal assistance completed in accordance with currently adopted policies and procedures, the board shall forthwith commence an investigation of the applicant and of the matters contained in the application, which shall include an investigation of at least the following factors: 
1.  The legal status of the project described in the application and whether or not the project can be lawfully instituted, constructed or operated with the municipal assistance proposed in the application; 
2.  The applicant itself (and if the applicant is a subsidiary of another firm owning a majority of stock in the applicant, the parent firm), to determine the financial status of the applicant and its ability to perform the duties which will be imposed upon the applicant as a result of the application; 
3.  The financial feasibility of the project; 
4.  Verification of the fact that the project will serve the public benefit of the citizens of the city, by providing its citizens with job opportunities and with a source of additional income; 
5.  The proposed technology for the project, to insure that the project will be in fact capable of achieving those purposes stated in the application. 
D.  Upon completion of the investigation, the board shall formulate a written report concerning the application which it shall submit to the city commission. The written report shall detail the findings of the board and shall conclude with a recommendation to the city commission as to whether or not municipal financial assistance should be furnished to the applicant in connection with the proposed project. This shall be a recommendation only, and final authority for determining whether municipal assistance shall be given in connection with a proposed project shall be made solely by the city commission. 
E.  In carrying out its duties and responsibilities, the board, with the concurrence of the city commission, is authorized to engage an outside individual or agency to investigate the viability/feasibility of all parties and matters related to the application. The hiring of an independent agency shall be subject to the city procurement policies and currently adopted EIB policies and procedures if applicable and shall be approved in advance by the city commission. The engagement of such agency/entity may be done on an individual project basis or on a contracted term basis. 
F.  If the board's report to the city commission recommends that municipal assistance be given to the applicant, the written report will identify the terms, conditions, and other material requirements for approval of the project. If the boards' report to the city commission recommends that municipal assistance be given to the applicant, the written report will be accompanied by a suggested form of inducement resolution inviting the establishment of the project to be acted upon by the city commission in the regular course of its business. The inducement resolution shall contain such matters as may be required by law. 
G.  If the city commission determines that municipal assistance should be given to a firm desiring to construct or establish an industrial, commercial or business project within or near the corporate limits of the city, the city commission shall advise the board of the commission's decision. Immediately thereafter, the board shall commence preparation of such proceedings as might be required by federal or state law or regulation to accomplish the purposes designated by the city commission. The board's work in preparation of formal legal proceedings shall be undertaken in consultation with appropriate officials of the city, representatives of the applicant, and representatives of such other firms as the board shall consider necessary. In no event shall any formal legal proceedings be submitted to the city commission unless such proceedings are in compliance with all provisions of this code. 
H.  Upon the completion of those activities required by this section, the board shall cause to be submitted to the city commission all formal legal proceedings which shall be necessary for the completion of the municipal assistance required by the applicant desiring to construct or establish an industrial, commercial or business project within or near the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. 1686-2001 § 3, 2001). 
(Ord. No. 2052-2015, § 2, 8-6-15). 
2.50.040 - Meetings. 
A.  The board shall meet at least quarterly or at the call of the chairperson to effectively perform the duties and responsibilities of the board. 
B.  All meetings of the board shall be open to the public and shall conform to the New Mexico Open Meetings Act. 
(Ord. 1628-2000 § 2(part), 2000). 
(Ord. No. 2052-2015, § 2, 8-6-15). 
Chapter 2.52 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AND PLANNING 

2.52.010 - Established. 
    There is established a department of the city of Clovis and the county of Curry, in accordance with the state Civil Emergency Preparedness Act, Sections 12-10-1 through 12-10-10, NMSA 1978, the department of emergency management. 
A.  The department shall be under the direction of the emergency management director, who shall be an employee of the city, hired by the city manager; 
B.  The city and county may also provide for such additional professional and administrative staff personnel as may be required to effectively carry out the emergency management program. 
(Ord. 1706-2002 § 3(part), 2002). 
2.52.020 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the emergency management department is to: 
A.  Develop and execute the city and county emergency management program and to coordinate the efforts of all city and county agencies and employees and non-governmental agencies to prepare for and function in the event of emergencies endangering the lives and properties of the citizens of city of Clovis and the county of Curry; 
B.  To develop and coordinate comprehensive emergency management plans for the effective employment of city and county resources to protect the lives and health of the citizens of Clovis and Curry County and the private and public property therein from the effects of natural or man-caused emergency events, including acts of war; 
C.  To coordinate the implementation of the plans during periods of emergencies; 
D.  To coordinate with counties contiguous to Curry County and units of local government within Curry County and in consonance with New Mexico All Hazard Emergency Operations Plan; 
E.  To exercise all powers conferred by the Act; 
F.  To participate in carrying out for Curry County those responsibilities required of the LEPC, pursuant to SARA Title III and related regulations, including but not limited to: 
1.  Development, training and testing of the hazardous substance emergency response plan; 
2.  Development of procedures for regulated facilities to provide notification to the LEPC; 
3.  Development of procedures for receiving and processing requests from the public under the community right to know provisions of SARA Title III; and 
4.  Provision for public notification. 
G.  To implement such other and further related activities as may hereafter be legally required by the federal government, the state emergency response commission, the Clovis city commission, or the Curry County commission. 
(Ord. 1706-2002 § 3(part), 2002). 
2.52.030 - Emergency management director-Duties. 
A.  The emergency management director shall be a department head of the city and shall be responsible to the mayor of the city commission and chairman of the Curry County commission for the organization, administration and operations of the emergency management office staff and program for Clovis and Curry County. The director shall, acting for the mayor and county chairman, and in consonance with the emergency management/LEPC committee, coordinate emergency activities of all city and county departments and agencies and non-governmental agencies, and shall maintain a liaison with and cooperate with the emergency management agencies of the federal government, military departments, the state of New Mexico and other political subdivisions therein. 
B.  The director shall have all necessary authority to act for the government of the city and county of Curry in all matters relating to emergency management, including the obligation of such city and county funds and state and federal funds made available and as may be appropriated for emergency management purpose, subject to the administrative supervision and control of the city manager. The director, in consonance with the committee, shall develop an organizational structure for the office, subject to the approval of the city commission and the county commission; 
C.  The director shall serve as the chairman of the committee and shall advise and inform the city commission and county commission on a periodic basis. 
(Ord. 1706-2002 § 3(part), 2002). 
2.52.040 - Funds. 
A.  Funds necessary and appropriate expenses and functions of the department of emergency management, including salaries for approved paid positions, shall be made available through appropriations of the city commission and county commission; 
B.  The director shall prepare and submit to the city commission for its separate approval an annual proposed budget for emergency management expenditures and functions and shall indicate therein those amounts eligible for matching funds under state or federal programs; 
C.  Emergency management funds may be obligated by the director only in the amounts appropriated and for the purposes authorized by the city commission and county commission; 
D.  The total amounts budgeted and appropriated by both the city commission and county commission shall be expended pursuant to the normal fiscal procedures established by the city commission, solely for the expenses of the emergency management department, as authorized by the city commission and county commission. All expenditures shall be subject to normal accounting procedures established by the city commission from time to time and shall be subject to annual audit requirements imposed by law. 
(Ord. 1706-2002 § 3(part), 2002). 
2.52.050 - Emergency management/LEPC committee. 
A.  All persons, businesses and organizations within Curry County having an interest in emergency management and/or hazardous materials may apply for membership to the emergency management/LEPC committee; including, but not limited to those groups designated by SARA Title III and those entities required to submit tier two emergency and hazardous chemical inventory reports; 
B.  The committee shall maintain a current roster of all members and shall provide notification to all members of any meetings of the committee; 
C.  There shall be no limit on the total number of members of the committee; however, each member must annually renew membership in a manner to be determined by the executive counsel. 
(Ord. 1706-2002 § 3(part), 2002). 
2.52.060 - Executive council. 
A.  The committee shall be managed by an executive council to be made up of representatives of the following organizations: 
1.  One member of the Clovis city commission; 
2.  One member of the Curry County commission; 
3.  A representative of Cannon Air Force Base; 
4.  The emergency management director, who shall serve as chairman; 
5.  The Clovis chief of police, or his designee; 
6.  The Clovis fire chief, or his designee; 
7.  The city of Clovis safety officer; 
8.  A representative of the media (newspaper, radio, TV); 
9.  A representative of the American Red Cross; 
10.  The city of Clovis director of public works, or his designee; 
11.  The Curry County sheriff; 
12.  A representative of the local unit of the National Guard; 
13.  A representative from the local office of the New Mexico state police; 
14.  A representative of the Burlington Northern Santa Fe Railway Company; 
15.  A representative of PRMC regional hospital; 
16.  A representative of the local utility businesses; 
17.  A representative of the radio operator's organization; 
18.  Three members of the general public. 
B.  All of the organizations designated as having a representative on the executive council shall appoint that representative in accordance with their own procedures and shall identify the representative to the emergency management director. The members of the general public shall be appointed by the mayor and Curry County chairman, with the approval of the commissions; 
C.  The executive council may organize and form standing and ad hoc committees as necessary to carry out its duties and responsibilities. 
(Ord. 1706-2002 § 3(part), 2002). 
2.52.070 - Executive council rules and regulations. 
A.  The executive council of the committee shall adopt rules of general application governing the execution of its responsibilities under this ordinance, the Act, SARA Title III, and related applicable regulations. Such rules and regulations shall provide for the manner of operation, organization and procedures required to carry out its duties and responsibilities. No rule or regulation shall become effective until approved by resolution of both the Clovis city commission and Curry County commission; 
B.  The committee shall, within four months from the adoption of this ordinance by both the city and county, formulate and submit proposed initial rules and regulations for its organization and operation; 
C.  During the transition period and until the approval of rules and regulations required and authorized by this section are approved as provided herein, emergency management functions shall continue to be administered and coordinated pursuant to Ordinance 1656-2001 of the Clovis city commission and Ordinance 01-01 of the Curry County commission. 
(Ord. 1706-2002 § 3(part), 2002). 
2.52.080 - Effective date. 
    The city commission and the county commission find that the ordinance codified in this chapter shall constitute a mutual aid agreement as authorized by Section 12-10-6 of the Act. The ordinance codified in this chapter shall not take effect until it has been adopted by both the city commission and county commission, and no amendments to the ordinance codified in this chapter shall be valid until approved by both the city commission and the county commission. Neither the city commission nor the county commission shall have the authority to repeal the ordinance codified in this chapter without concurrent action by the other commission. Further, the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall be subject to the transition provisions set forth herein. 
(Ord. 1706-2002 § 3(part), 2002). 
Chapter 2.62 - POLITICAL HANDBILLS 

2.62.010 - Display of political advertising in municipal buildings-Prohibited. 
    No campaign poster, advertisement or promotion in support of or against a candidate for political office shall be displaying in any building owned by the city leased for use by the city. The prohibition shall apply to buildings owned by the city and leased or used by any agency. Violation of this section shall be punished in accordance with Chapter 1.24. 
(Ord. 1375-90 § 2, 1990). 
Chapter 2.63 - AMERICANS WITH DISABILITIES ACT (ADA) COMPLIANCE PROCEDURES 

2.63.010 - Appointment of complaint officer. 
    The city manager shall designate a department head within the city to assume the position of ADA coordinator. The duties of the ADA coordinator shall be as follows: 
A.  Coordinate educational instruction and activities to develop a program for compliance with the Americans With Disabilities Act; 
B.  Prepare a complaint form for use in identifying alleged discrimination; 
C.  Supervise the investigation of all complaints submitted pursuant to the Americans With Disabilities Act; 
D.  Adopt guidelines for the investigation of ADA complaints; 
E.  Establish procedures for the submission of documentation, presentation of evidence and hearing of witnesses; 
F.  Submit proposals for resolution of valid complaints. 
(Ord. 1419-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
2.63.020 - Complaint procedures. 
A.  If an individual believes he/she has been subject to discrimination by any employment practice, or denied access to any city-operated program, services or facility, he/she may lodge a complaint according to the procedures set forth in this section. An employee of the city who believes he/she has been subject to discrimination by any employment practice shall follow the grievance procedures as set forth in Chapter 2.64. 
B.  Within thirty business days of an alleged discriminatory action, the complainant shall make a written complaint to the ADA coordinator, or in his/her absence the city manager, on forms provided by the city. The ADA coordinator will provide assistance in completing the forms if the complainant is unable because of disability. In completing the form, complainants are encouraged to provide as much detail as possible, including dates, times, witnesses, etc. in order to facilitate a prompt and thorough investigation. The form must present the facts of the complaint including recommendations of necessary actions to remedy the alleged discrimination to the satisfaction of the complainant. 
C.  Within three business days after receipt of the written complaint, the ADA coordinator shall begin an investigation of the complaint or shall designate an employee to conduct an investigation pursuant to the investigation guidelines adopted by the ADA coordinator. 
D.  Within twenty-eight business days from the beginning investigation, the ADA coordinator shall submit a written report of the findings. The ADA coordinator shall consult with the city attorney and shall approve final findings. 
E.  Following the adoption of findings and making of a determination whether discrimination has occurred, the ADA coordinator shall inform the complainant of the decision. 
F.  In the event the complaint has been sustained, the ADA coordinator's report shall offer appropriate relief consistent with existing city policy, state statutes and federal regulations. 
G.  The complainant shall have ten days after receipt of the ADA coordinator's report to give notice of acceptance of the proposed relief or to offer further negotiation for resolution. If further negotiation is requested, the ADA coordinator shall have ten days after receipt of the complainant's proposed relief to accept or reject. 
H.  If the proposed relief, after negotiation, is not satisfactory to the complainant, he/she shall be advised of his/her right to file a complaint with the Human Rights Commission, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission or other appropriate federal agency. 
I.  A record of action taken on each request or complaint must be maintained as a part of the records to be maintained by the ADA coordinator. 
(Ord. 1419-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
Chapter 2.64 - MERIT SYSTEM FOR CITY EMPLOYEES[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
For statutory provisions authorizing municipalities to establish merit systems for municipal employees, see N.M. Stat. Ann. § 3-13-4. 

2.64.010 - Findings and determinations. 
A.  The Supreme Court of the state of New Mexico in the case of International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers vs. Town of Farmington, 75 N.M. 393 (1965), held that if a merit system providing for those matters usually contained in a collective bargaining agreement is adopted by a municipality, the municipality may not enter into a collective bargaining agreement that is contrary to the provisions of the merit system. The city commission has considered alternative methods aimed at achieving the goals of protection of the rights of its employees, avoidance of employee dissatisfaction, assurance of access by employees to management, and input by employees into management decisions affecting wages, hours and other terms and conditions for employment. The city commission finds and determines that these goals can best be achieved through a formal merit system. 
B.  The city commission further finds and determines that all personnel actions regarding employees of the city shall be based upon the merit and fitness of all applicants, satisfactory performance of work involved, necessity to the municipality of the work to be performed, and the availability of funds. 
C.  The city commission further finds and determines that fair and equitable rates of pay shall be provided employees of the city with the due consideration of both employees and the taxpayers of the city, and in observance of the principle of equal pay for equal work and appropriate differences in pay for differences in work. 
D.  The city commission further finds and determines that as far as practicable, the public service in the city shall be made an attractive career and incentives shall be provided public employees so as to encourage efficient and effective delivery of services to the residents of the city. 
(Ord. 1068-76 § 1, 1977). 
2.64.020 - Established. 
    Pursuant to its home rule powers, the city commission establishes a merit system for the hiring, promotion, discharge and general regulation of municipal employees. 
(Ord. 1068-76 § 2, 1977). 
2.64.030 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2038-2015, § 2, adopted February 5, 2015, repealed § 2.64.030, which pertained to personnel policy board-created-membership and derived from Ord. No. 1068-76, 1977; Ord. No. 1318-87, 1987; Ord. No. 1352-89; Ord. No. 1586-98, 1998 and Ord No. 1698-2002, 2002.

Editor's note- Ord. No. 2038-2015, § 2, adopted February 5, 2015, repealed § 2.64.040, which pertained to personnel policy board-term-removal from office and derived from Ord. No. 1068-76, 1977; Ord. No. 1318-87, 1987; Ord. No. 1352-89; Ord. No. 1586-98, 1998 and Ord No. 1698-2002, 2002. 
2.64.050 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2038-2015, § 2, adopted February 5, 2015, repealed § 2.64.050, which pertained to personnel policy board-duties and derived from Ord. No. 1068-76, 1977; Ord. No. 1318-87, 1987 and Ord. No. 1484-95, 1995. 
2.64.060 - Authority of city manager. 
    The city manager will be responsible for proper administration of the personnel system. The city manager is further charged with the following responsibilities: 
A.  The sole authority to employ and discharge all municipal employees pursuant to the authority in Section 3-14-14, NMSA 1978, and as may be amended; 
B.  To maintain a personnel system for employees consistent with the intent of this chapter; 
C.  To recommend and institute new or revised rules and regulations determined desirable in accord with the provisions of this chapter; 
D.  To recommend to the city commission that certain modifications be made to this chapter as conditions warrant; 
E.  To ensure that the personnel system provides (1) means to recruit, select, develop and maintain an effective, responsive and productive work force, and (2) policies and procedures for employee hiring and advancement, training and career development, job classification, salary administration, fringe benefits, disciplines, discharge, retirement and other related activities. 
(Ord. 1318-87 (part), 1987: Ord. 1068-76 § 6, 1977). 
2.64.061 - Authority of city commission-Personnel system. 
    The city commission, in accord with the provisions of Section 3-12-2, NMSA 1978 as amended, shall neither perform, collectively or individually, any executive functions in the administration of the personnel system except those assigned by law and this chapter. Such executive functions and authority of the city commission as a whole are set forth as follows: 
A.  To employ and remove the city manager, according to Section 3-14-3, NMSA 1978 as amended; 
B.  To make collective recommendations to the city manager on general personnel policies; 
C.  To create new or additional municipal divisions, departments and sections. To direct the reorganization or deletion of divisions, departments and sections; 
D.  To appoint an acting city manager in the event the city manager is absent for any reason. 
(Ord. 1318-87 (part), 1987). 
2.64.070 - Employees covered-Exceptions. 
    All non-elective positions in the employment of the city are covered under the provisions of this chapter and the rules and policies promulgated by the city, except the following: 
A.  The city manager. 
B.  All members of boards and commissions appointed by the mayor with the approval of a majority of all the members of the city commission; 
C.  Administrators and heads of departments appointed by the city manager shall be at-will employees and shall be exempt except where specifically referred to in personnel policies adopted by the city. 
(Ord. 1352-89 (part), 1989; Ord. 1318-87 (part), 1987: Ord. 1068-76 §5, 1977). 
(Ord. No. 2038-2015, § 2, 2-5-15). 
2.64.080 - Personnel rules. 
    Personnel rules of the city shall: 
A.  Provide for consistent and equitable application of policies and procedures to all employees, guide supervisors in personnel administration, and inform employees of policies that affect their employment; 
B.  Provide that all appointments and promotions to employment with the city shall be made on the basis of merit and without regard to race, color, national origin, political or religious opinions, handicap, sex or age of applicant; 
C.  Comply with all state and federal laws regulating public employees. 
(Ord. 1352-89 (part), 1989: Ord. 1318-87 (part), 1987: Ord. 1068-76 §7, 1977).

2.64.100 - Political activity. 
    No officer or employee of the city shall: 
A.  Hold an elective office of the state or any of its political subdivisions, except officers or employees of the city on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter who on that date hold elective office of the state or any of its political subdivisions may thereafter hold and be elected to the same elective office while serving as a city employee; provided, however, that nothing contained in this section shall be construed to prevent any municipal employee from seeking election to an elective position, if such employee shall take a leave of absence without pay from his position, beginning nine calendar days prior to and including the day of any primary, local, county or general election in which such employee shall be a candidate; if not elected, upon completion of his leave of absence without pay, the employee shall be entitled to be reinstated to his former position without any reduction in pay or privileges; 
B.  Use his position or employment to influence support of other appointed employees for or against any candidate or issue in any election; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall deny the right of an official or employee to express his views on any issue or candidate whatever; 
C.  Engage in political activity while on the job. 
(Ord. 1359-89 § 3, 1989: Ord. 1068-76 § 9, 1977).

Chapter 2.68 - LIBRARY[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
For statutory provisions authorizing municipalities to establish libraries, see N.M. Stat. Ann. § 3-18-14. 

2.68.010 - Established. 
    There is established in the city a free public library, to be known as the Clovis-Carver Public Library. Such library is declared to be a proper and legitimate object of expenditure and operation of the city and is intended to qualify as a proper and legitimate object of expenditure of the county. 
(Prior code §11A-1). 
2.68.020 - Board-Created-Duties. 
A.  There is created the Clovis Curry County library board, referred to in this chapter as the "library board," as an administrative agency of both the city and of the county. 
B.  The library board shall act in an administrative and an advisory capacity, and shall advise and assist the city commission and the board of county commissioners in every possible way to insure the efficient and economical management and operation of the Clovis-Carver Public Library. 
C.  It shall be the duty of the library board to advise the head librarian of the Clovis-Carver Public Library in all matters pertaining to the management and operation of the library. 
(Prior code § 11A-2). 
2.68.030 - Board-Powers-Regulation posting. 
A.  The library board shall establish and operate the Clovis-Carver Public Library and shall have the control and management of such library, including the power: 
1.  To receive gifts, bequests and donations of all kinds; 
2.  To make bylaws, rules and regulations for the operation of the library, not in conflict with the ordinances of the city nor of the laws of the state. 
B.  The rules and regulations adopted by the library board for regulating the public use of the facilities of the library shall be posted in conspicuous places in the library for public inspection and information. 
(Prior code § 11A-3). 
2.68.040 - Board-Membership. 
    The library board shall consist of nine members who shall be residents of the county. Seven of the members shall be appointed jointly by the mayor of the city and the chairman of the board of county commissioners, with the approval of the city commission and the board of county commissioners. In addition to the seven members appointed by the city and county, the city commission shall select one member from the city commission who shall serve during the term for which he is elected to the city commission, and the board of county commissioners shall appoint one member from the board of county commissioners who shall serve during the term for which he is elected to the board of county commissioners. 
(Ord. 1484-95 § 2(part), 1995: prior code § 11A-4). 
2.68.045 - Board-Nonvoting student membership. 
    There is established two nonvoting student members of the library board, to be appointed by the mayor, with the consent of the Clovis city commission, based upon the recommendation of the principal, Clovis High School. The terms of the nonvoting student members shall be two years. A junior at Clovis High School shall be selected each year to serve a term to coincide with the student's junior and senior year of high school. Terms shall be staggered. Vacancies of either student nonvoting positions shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointments provided herein, and all vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term of the appointed member. 
(Ord. 1478-95 § 2, 1995). 
2.68.050 - Board-Organization-Term. 
A.  At the first meeting of the library board, the members shall elect from its membership a president, a vice-president, a secretary, a treasurer and such other officers as may be necessary to carry out the functions of the Clovis-Carver Public Library. The term of the first officers will expire with the first regular meeting of the library board held in the month of July, 1969. 
B.  At the first regular meeting of the library board held in July, 1969, and annually thereafter at the first regular July board meeting, the library board will organize itself for the succeeding year by electing from its membership a president, vice president, a secretary, a treasurer and such other officers as may be necessary to carry out the functions of the Clovis-Carver Public Library. The offices of secretary and of treasurer may be held by the same person. 
(Prior code § 11A-5). 
2.68.060 - Board-Member removal. 
    Any voting member of the library board may be removed from office by the mayor, with the consent of the city commission after due notice if such member has missed three consecutive meetings or has been absent from fifty percent of the meetings held during any twelve month period. In the event of any removal under this section, the position becomes vacant and shall be filled as provided in Section 2.68.070. 
(Ord. 1478-95 § 3, 1995: prior code § 11A-6). 
2.68.070 - Board-Vacancy filling. 
    On the death, removal, resignation, change of residence to a place outside the county, or inability to act as a member of the library board, a vacancy on the library board shall exist and such vacancy shall be filled by appointment by the mayor of the city and chairman of the board of county commissioners, acting jointly, and with the approval of the city commission and the board of county commissioners, to fill the unexpired term of such member. 
(Prior code § 11A-7). 
2.68.080 - Board-President. 
    The president of the library board shall preside at all meetings, appoint all committees, call special meetings when necessary and generally perform the duties of a presiding officer. In the absence of the president, the vice president shall preside. 
(Prior code § 11A-8). 
2.68.090 - Board-Secretary. 
    The secretary of the library board shall keep a record of all of the proceedings of the library board meetings; shall issue notices of all regular meetings and, upon authorization of the president of the library board, of all special meetings; shall have custody of the minutes and other records of the library board and shall notify the city manager and county manager of any vacancies on the library board. 
(Ord. 1484-95 §2(part), 1995: prior code §11A-9). 
2.68.100 - Board-Treasurer. 
    The treasurer of the library board shall have charge of special library funds and income outside the regular library appropriations that are in charge of the city treasurer, and shall report at each meeting of the library board on the state of such funds. 
(Prior code §11A-10). 
2.68.110 - Board-Meetings. 
    The library board shall hold regular quarterly meetings on the last Monday of the month in January, April, July and October. The board shall by a majority vote, set the meeting time. Special meetings may be called by the chairman or the library director on an as-needed-basis, subject to giving required notification of the date, time and place of each special meeting. 
(Ord. 1775-2004 §2, 2004: prior code §11A-11). 
2.68.120 - Fund. 
A.  There is created within the municipal budget of the city a library fund supported by the city, together with funds allocated by the board of county commissioners. Such library fund is to be administered by the treasurer of the city as are the other funds of the city. 
B.  All money received by the library board from any charges, fines or penalties, together with appropriations from other funds by the city for salaries, books, supplies and other purposes, relative to the operation of the library, shall be placed in the fund, together with any gifts, bequests or donations to the city for the library. 
C.  The library board shall, each year, provide an annual library budget at a regular budget to be included in the total city budget of the city. 
(Prior code §11A-12). 
2.68.130 - Personnel. 
    A duly qualified head librarian and such other assistants or personnel as may be necessary for the operation and maintenance of the library shall be regularly employed by the city. Such librarian and other personnel shall be employed as may be prescribed by duly adopted personnel regulations of the city. The library board shall have the right and obligation to establish qualifications for the head librarian and such other library personnel as may be selected and to make recommendations relative to such employment. 
(Prior code §11A-13). 
2.68.140 - Head librarian-Duties. 
    The duties of the head librarian shall be such as are usually imposed on like persons in like employment and the head librarian shall be considered the executive officer of the library board. The head librarian shall be solely responsible for the administration of the Clovis-Carver Public Library under the direction and review of the library board. The head librarian shall attend all library board meetings. 
(Prior code §11A-14). 
2.68.150 - Theft of book-Defined-Penalty. 
A.  Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
1.  "Library" means the Clovis-Carver Public Library. 
2.  "Book" means any book, newspaper, magazine, pamphlet, manuscript or other property belonging to the library and which is available for use by the public. 
B.  Theft of Book Defined. Whoever willfully detains any book belonging to the library for thirty days after receipt of notice in writing to return the same, given after the expiration of the time which by library rule such book may be kept, has committed the offense of theft of a book. 
C.  Penalty. Whosoever commits the crime of theft of a book shall be subject to a penalty and fines not to exceed three hundred dollars and imprisonment not to exceed ninety days. 
(Ord. 1724-2003 § 2, 2003; Ord. 1244-84 § 1, 1984: Ord. 1137-80 §§ 1-3, 1980). 
Chapter 2.69 - SENIOR SERVICES COMMITTEE[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2103, §§ 2-4, adopted June 21, 2018, amended Chapter 2.69 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Chapter 2.69, §§ 2.69.010-2.69.050, pertained to a commission on older adults, and derived from Ord. No. 1189-82, 1982; Ord. No. 1484-95, 1995; Ord. No. 1673-2001, 2001 and Ord. No. 2081, adopted January 19, 2017. 

2.69.010 - Created-Membership. 
A.  There is established a senior services committee, consisting of nine voting members: One city commissioner, who shall serve as chairperson; the president or other board member designee of La Casa Buena Salud; the president or other board member designee of Baxter Curren Senior Center; the president or other board member designee of the Friendship Center; four residents from the city of Clovis, one from each district; and, one Curry County representative that resides outside the incorporated area of the city of Clovis. All members of the senior services committee shall be appointed by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the city commission. 
B.  Any public member of the committee may be removed from office by the mayor, with the consent of the city commission after due notice that such member has missed three consecutive meetings or has been absent from fifty percent of the meetings held during any twelve-month period. In the event of any removal under this subsection, the position shall become vacant and shall be filled for the unexpired term of the appointed member in the same manner as set forth herein. 
C.  The ex-officio, non-voting members shall be designated as follows: The city of Clovis Senior Services Director, a Curry County Commissioner, and one representative from American Association of Retired People (AARP), Retired Senior Volunteer Program (RSVP), Foster Grandparent Program, 50+ Senior Olympics, and Curry Residents Senior Meals Association (CRSMA). Ex-officio, non-voting members shall be designated by the organizations they represent. 
(Ord. No. 2103-2018, § 3, 6-21-18). 
2.69.020 - Term of Office-Vacancies. 
A.  The terms of the voting members of the senior services committee shall be three years. The terms of the voting members shall be staggered as designated and determined by the administration of the city of Clovis. 
B.  Vacancies of the voting members of the senior services committee shall be filled by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city commission, and all vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term of the appointed member. 
(Ord. No. 2103-2018, § 3, 6-21-18). 
2.69.030 - Meetings-Organization. 
    The senior services committee shall establish a regular meeting date, which shall meet at least quarterly. The city commissioner shall serve as chairperson. At the regular meeting of the senior services committee occurring during the month of July of each year, the senior services committee shall designate one of its members as vice chairperson. The vice chairperson shall serve for a term of one year, with the term expiring at the regular meeting in July of the next succeeding year. 
(Ord. No. 2103-2018, § 3, 6-21-18). 
2.69.040 - Duties and responsibilities. 
    The duties and responsibilities of the senior services committee shall be to: 
A.  Advise and assist the city commission in the development and application of policies and programs relating to senior citizens. 
B.  Evaluate policies, plans, procedures, codes, resolutions, ordinances, and rules and regulations of the city relating to senior citizens. 
C.  Take necessary action to obtain from citizens, expert consultants, commissions and boards, comprehensive comments and recommendations relative to senior citizens. 
D.  Make reports to the city commission of the activities and recommendations of the senior services committee. 
E.  Investigate, research, review and provide recommendations as directed by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2103-2018, § 3, 6-21-18). 
Chapter 2.71 - WATER POLICY ADVISORY COMMITTEE 

2.71.010 - Created. 
    There is created the Clovis water policy advisory committee. 
(Ord. 1719-2002 (part), 2002). 
2.71.020 - Membership-Qualification-Appointment. 
A.  The committee shall be composed of nine voting members to be nominated by the mayor and, with the advice and consent of the commission, to be appointed by him.
