The total amount of public money expended and the value of credit pledged in the fiscal year in which that money is expended by the city of Clovis for economic development projects pursuant to Article 9, Section 14 of the New Mexico Constitution and the LEDA shall not exceed ten percent of the annual general fund expenditures of the local government in that fiscal year. 
    The limits of this subsection shall not apply to: 
1.  The value of any land or building contributed to any project pursuant to a project participation agreement; 
2.  Revenue generated through the imposition of the municipal infrastructure gross receipts tax pursuant to the Municipal Local Option Gross Receipts Taxes Act [Chapter 7, Article 19D NMSA 1978] for furthering or implementing economic development plans and projects as defined in the LEDA or projects as defined in the Statewide Economic Development Finance Act [Chapter 6, Article 25 NMSA 1978] otherwise known as the city of Clovis economic development tax fund or the local economic development tax fund; provided that no more than the greater of fifty thousand dollars or ten percent of the revenue collected shall be used for promotion and administration of professional services contracts related to the implementation of any such economic development plan adopted by the governing body; 
3.  The proceeds of a revenue bond issue to which municipal infrastructure gross receipts tax revenue is pledged; 
4.  Funds donated or invested by private entities to be used for defraying the cost of a project. 
C.  The city shall create and maintain an economic development fund into which such revenues shall be deposited. The economic development fund and income from the economic development fund shall be deposited as provided by law. Money in the economic development fund may be expended only as provided in the LEDA or the Statewide Economic Development Finance Act. All expenses from the economic development fund for land, building and infrastructure projects shall be reviewed by the economic incentive board (EIB board) and a funding recommendation for the project shall be presented by the EIB board to the city commission for action. The decision to fund the proposed project shall be made by the city commission. 
D.  Nothing within this section prohibits the city of Clovis from allocating up to ten percent of the city of Clovis general fund expenditures annually or prohibits the city from receiving state economic development LEDA funds and grants for arts and cultural district purposes or cultural facilities as described in the local economic development act and this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2053-2015, § 2, 8-6-15). 
3.28.040 - Economic development goals, strategies and priorities. 
    Goal Statement: The goal of this economic development plan ordinance is to effectively implement marketing, business development initiatives and incentive programs to convey Clovis and the regions advantages in order to retain, attract and expand economic based business and industry that will create high wage jobs for area citizens. 
A.  Goal: Work with existing businesses and qualifying entities to improve the general business climate in order that they may be successful in retaining employees and creating new jobs through start-up business and retention and expansion programs. 
1.  Strategies. 
a.  Retain and increase the local employment base by increasing the competitiveness of local business establishments through economic development programs, business incubator programs, small business assistance programs. 
b.  Continue business and industry retention and expansion program efforts in partnership with area economic development organizations. 
c.  Identify and assist business and industry through expansion opportunities that bring new jobs to Clovis and Curry County. 
d.  Continue to address opportunities to improve profitability and efficiency of existing business and industry. 
e.  Support the development and education of a high-quality workforce to ensure a well trained workforce is available for business and industry. 
f.  Develop and maintain tax structure and economic development incentive programs to retain and attract industry. 
g.  Ensure that the city practices are "business friendly". 
B.  Goal: Recruit business and industry to expand the local economy and increase employment through the creation of high wage jobs. 
1.  Strategies. 
a.  Target marketing efforts to prospective businesses within targeted business and industry sectors that complement and diversify existing agriculture, railroad and military installation industries. 
b.  Market industrial sites at the Clovis Industrial Park and the Clovis Municipal Airport Industrial Park. 
c.  Develop and maintain attractive local incentive packages such as industrial revenue bonds and LEDA incentives that are competitive with other communities and states. 
d.  Maintain a "business friendly" fast track construction permitting and inspection process for business and industry. 
C.  Goal: Develop adequate infrastructure for growth and development. 
1.  Strategies. 
a.  Continue the public-private partnership with Clovis Industrial Development Corporation to continue the development of the Clovis Industrial Park and the Clovis Airport Industrial Park for a variety of light to moderately heavy manufacturing industries and aviation industries. 
b.  Continue to improve and develop area highways, streets and roads to serve business and industry. 
c.  Improve commercial air service to Clovis. 
d.  Encourage the expansion of railroad facilities, rail spurs and intermodal transportation facilities in the Clovis area. 
e.  Maintain, encourage and improve water, gas, electric and wastewater treatment infrastructure to serve industry. 
f.  Continue to improve, enhance and develop historical and cultural facilities within the Historic Downtown District, downtown Metropolitan Redevelopment Area and Clovis Main Street District. 
(Ord. No. 2053-2015, § 2, 8-6-15). 
3.28.050 - Targeted businesses and industry. 
    The economy of Clovis is supported by three basic industries: agriculture, military and railroad. Economic development efforts are focused on new or expanding industries which enhance these three sectors and other light to moderately heavy industry to diversify Clovis and the region. Target industries include but are not limited to: 
A.  Aviation/aerospace and defense; 
B.  Cannon Air Force Base and its support industries; 
C.  Manufacturing; 
D.  Logistics, warehouse, distribution and transportation; 
E.  Back office and customer support; 
F.  Renewable energy; 
G.  Value-added agriculture/food processing; 
H.  Retention and expansion of business and industry. 
(Ord. No. 2053-2015, § 2, 8-6-15). 
3.28.060 - Criteria to determine eligibility for aid. 
    Business applicants applying for aid through this chapter must be the City, a corporation, limited liability company, partnership, joint venture syndicate, association or other person that is one or a combination of two or more of the following: 
A.  A business or qualifying entity that is an industry for the manufacturing, processing or assembling of agricultural or manufactured products; 
B.  A business or qualifying entity that is a commercial enterprise for storing, warehousing, distributing or selling products of agriculture, mining or industry, but, except as provided by paragraphs D. and E. of this definition, not including any enterprise for sale of goods or commodities at retail, or for the distribution to the public of electricity, gas, water or telephone or other services commonly classified as public utilities; 
C.  A business or qualifying entity in which all or part of the activities of the business involves the supplying of services to the general public or to governmental agencies or to a specific industry or customer, but, other than as provided in paragraph E. of this subsection, not including businesses primarily engaged in the sale of goods or commodities at retail; 
D.  A telecommunications sales enterprise that makes the majority of its sales to persons outside New Mexico; 
E.  A facility for the direct sales by growers of agricultural products, commonly known as farmers' markets; 
F.  A business that is the developer of a metropolitan redevelopment project; or 
G.  A cultural facility. 
(Ord. No. 2053-2015, § 2, 8-6-15). 
3.28.070 - Information required to determine that applicant is financially solvent and committed to the community. 
    The Clovis Economic incentive board will receive and evaluate proposals pursuant to criteria set forth in Sections 2.50.030 "Duties and responsibilities, and 2.50.035 "Procedural duties and responsibilities" relating to the economic incentive board. 
(Ord. No. 2053-2015, § 2, 8-6-15). 
3.28.080 - Procedure to verify application information. 
    Upon receipt by the economic development incentive board of an application for municipal assistance completed in a manner satisfactory to it, the review committee or other designated entity shall forthwith commence an investigation of the applicant and of the matters contained in the application, which shall include an investigation of at least the following factors: 
A.  Determine whether the project can be lawfully instituted, constructed or operated with the municipal assistance proposed in the application; 
B.  Determine the financial and management ability of the applicant (and if the applicant is a subsidiary of another firm owning a majority of stock in the applicant, the parent firm) and its ability to perform the duties which will be imposed upon the applicant as a result of the application; 
C.  Evaluate the financial feasibility of the project; 
D.  Verify that the project will serve the public benefit of the citizens of the city by providing its citizens with job opportunities and with a source of additional income; 
E.  Insure that the project will be capable of achieving those purposes stated in the application; 
F.  Prepare a cost-benefit analysis of the project; 
G.  Insure that the project conforms to the Clovis economic development plan within this chapter; 
H.  Insure that the project collateral security is adequate to protect the public investment; 
I.  Develop any other information the EIB board or city commission deems necessary for a full review of the economic development project application. 
    Upon completion of its investigation, the EIB board shall formulate a written report concerning the application which it shall submit to the city commission. The written report shall summarize the findings of the review committee and shall conclude with a recommendation to the city commission. The decision to provide economic development tax funding or to provide other local incentives for a proposed project shall be made by the city commission. Projects shall be approved by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 2053-2015, § 2, 8-6-15). 
3.28.090 - Project participation agreement. 
    Upon approval by the Clovis city commission, the city and the applicant will enter into a project participation agreement required by LEDA which shall set out: 
A.  The contributions to be made by each party to the participation agreement. 
B.  Detail the minimum benefit required by the city of Clovis from a qualifying entity, including the number and types of jobs to be created or retained; the proposed payroll; repayment of loan, if any; purchase by the qualifying entity of city owned land, buildings and infrastructure; the public to private investment ratio; and direct local tax base expansion. 
C.  The security provided to the city by the qualifying entity in the form of a lien, mortgage, other indenture and the pledge of the qualifying business's financial or material participation and cooperation to guarantee the qualifying entity's performance pursuant to the project participation agreement. 
D.  A schedule for project development and completion, including measurable goals, time limits for those goals and reporting requirements, which include regular audited financial documentation as required and stated in the applicant's project participation agreement. 
E.  Time period for which the city shall retain an interest in the project. Each project agreement shall have a "sunset" clause after which the city shall relinquish interest or oversight of the project. 
F.  Provisions for performance review and actions to be taken upon a determination that project performance is unsatisfactory. 
G.  Specific procedures to determine success and methods for recouping investment in the event an economic development project is determined to be unsuccessful or if a qualifying entity seeks to leave the area. 
H.  Priority of Investment. The investment of private funds before public funds is required unless the city commission specifically authorizes prior release of public funds. 
(Ord. No. 2053-2015, § 2, 8-6-15). 
3.28.100 - Audit requirements. 
    The city shall provide for an annual independent audit in accordance with the Audit Act. See NMSA, 1978 §§ 12-6-1 to 12-6-14. The audit is a public record. 
(Ord. No. 2053-2015, § 2, 8-6-15). 
3.28.110 - Other revenue sources. 
    If revenue sources other than those of the city of Clovis are used to support an economic development project, the source and amount of any such funding must be disclosed. 
(Ord. No. 2053-2015, § 2, 8-6-15). 
3.28.120 - City resources available. 
A.  Available resources the city may offer qualifying businesses include: 
1.  Land the city is willing to purchase, lease, sell or grant; 
2.  Buildings the city is willing to purchase, lease, sell or grant; 
3.  Infrastructure the city is willing to purchase, build, extend or expand; 
4.  Deal-closing/relocation grants for land, building and infrastructure; 
5.  Post-performance venture grants for land, building and infrastructure; 
6.  Financial incentives, tax abatements and resources available: 
a.  Industrial revenue bonds, 
b.  LEDA Incentives, 
c.  Development Incentive Act. 
B.  No local economic development gross receipts tax funds collected by the city of Clovis shall be used for a cultural facility purpose. Nothing within this code prohibits state of New Mexico funding received through the Local Economic Development Act or capital outlay from being utilized for cultural facilities. 
(Ord. No. 2053-2015, § 2, 8-6-15). 
3.28.130 - Minimum investment required from a qualifying entity. 
    The city shall require any one or more of the following criteria as a minimum investment from a qualifying entity in order to receive economic development assistance: 
A.  Number and type of jobs created or retained. 
B.  Proposed payroll. 
C.  Repayment of loans, if any. 
D.  Purchase by the qualifying entity of city-owned land, buildings or infrastructure. 
E.  Capital investment. 
F.  Public-to-private investment ratio. 
1.  The amount of private dollars provided directly to an eligible entity for a project must be at least twice the amount of Clovis Local Economic Development Act dollars invested in the economic development project. 
2.  The public investment shall be available to the project only after the investment of the private dollars, as set forth in the project participation agreement, unless the majority of the Clovis city commission specifically allows earlier public investments. 
G.  Direct local tax base expansion. 
(Ord. No. 2053-2015, § 2, 8-6-15). 
3.28.140 - Safeguards of public resources. 
A.  The "qualifying entity" is responsible for submitting required compliance reports in accordance with the terms and conditions of the project participation agreement, to the city manager or his/her designee. The city manager or his/her designee shall verify the report and the EIB board shall be responsible for reviewing and recommending approval/disapproval of the required compliance reports submitted by a "qualifying entity." If a qualifying entity is found to not be in compliance, the EIB board shall provide a recommended course of action to the city commission to protect the public monies. The decision to approve or disapprove a report or to establish a recommended course of action shall be made solely by the city commission. 
B.  The city manager or his/her designee shall present a financial report detailing the fund balance and income and expenses from the local economic development tax fund to the EIB board on a quarterly basis. 
C.  If a qualifying entity ceases operation, relocates or otherwise defaults or reneges on its contractual or implied obligations to the city, the city shall recover any costs, land, buildings or other thing(s) of value. The project participation agreement shall contain a specific term to establish default provisions and remedies for recoupment of public resources. 
D.  The city shall require a substantive contribution from the qualifying entity for each economic development project. Public support provided for an economic development project shall be in exchange for a substantive contribution from the qualifying entity. The contribution shall be of value and may be paid in money, in-kind services, jobs, expanded tax base, property or other thing(s) or service(s) of value for the expansion of the economy. 
E.  The qualifying entity shall provide security to the city, state of New Mexico or any other New Mexico governmental entity providing public support for an economic development project. The security shall secure the qualifying entity's obligations based on terms stated in the project participation agreement with the city or regional government and shall reflect the amount of public support provided to the qualifying entity and the substantive contribution expected from the qualifying entity. 
    Security programs may include, but are not be limited to: 
a.  Letter of credit. 
b.  Performance bond equal to the city's contribution. 
c.  A mortgage or lien on property and/or equipment. 
d.  Other security agreeable to both parties. 
e.  Post performance grant payments for land, building and infrastructure. 
F.  If a qualifying entity fails to perform its substantive contribution, the city shall enforce the project participation agreement to recover that portion of the public support for which the qualifying entity failed to provide a substantive contribution. The recovery shall be proportional to the failed performance of the substantive contribution and shall take into account all previous substantive contributions for the economic development project performed by the qualifying entity, based on the terms stated in the project participation agreement. The project participation agreement for an economic development project that uses public support provided by the state to the city shall include a recapture agreement for the state. 
(Ord. No. 2053-2015, § 2, 8-6-15). 
Title 5 - BUSINESS TAXES, LICENSES AND REGULATIONS 
Chapter 5.04 - BUSINESS LICENSES*[] 

Footnotes: 
--- () --- 
* For statutory provisions authorizing the licensing of businesses, see N.M. Stat. Ann. § 3-38-1 et seq . 

5.04.010 - Purpose. 
    It is declared that the licensing and regulation of the occupations, businesses, trades and vocations described in this chapter are conducive to the promotion of the health and general welfare of the city. 
(Prior code § 6-28). 
5.04.020 - Applicability. 
    No occupation, profession, trade pursuit, corporation or other business firm shall be required to pay any license pursuant to this section if currently paying or assessed a business registration fee pursuant to the provisions of Section 5.06.010. 
(Ord. 1172-81 § 6(a), 1981: prior code § 6-35). 
5.04.030 - Grounds for refusal. 
    The city commission may refuse to grant or issue a license under the provisions of this chapter to any person subject to the licensing provisions, whenever it may deem such refusal for the best interest of the public; provided, however, that no license shall be refused without giving the person applying for a license an opportunity to be heard on such application; and provided further, that such refusal shall require a majority vote of the members of the city commission present and voting. 
(Prior code § 6-37). 
5.04.035 - Distress and special sales. 
    A distress sale is any offer to sell to the public, or sale to the public, of goods, wares or merchandise on the implied or direct representation that such sale is in anticipation of the termination of a business at its present location or that the sale is being held other than in the ordinary course of business. A special sale is a temporary sale of goods, wares or merchandise brought into the city solely for the purpose of conducting the temporary sale. Special sales must be conducted at a single location for a period of three days or less. Special sales may be conducted only in an "F" zone. 
(Ord. 1337-88 § 3(part), 1988). 
5.04.040 - Application. 
    Any person filing an application for issuance or renewal of any business license shall include in the application the following information: 
A.  The exact nature or kind of business for which a license is requested and the goods to be sold; 
B.  The name, home and business address of the applicant, and the name and address of the owner, if other than the applicant, of the business; the social security number and birthdate of the applicant; 
C.  The applicant shall present a current driver's license or other identification; 
D.  The proposed location of the business, event or sale; 
E.  A statement or lease agreement from the owner granting the use of the property for conducting the business, event, or sale; 
F.  The dates of the proposed event or sale and the length of time for which the right to conduct the sale is being requested; 
G.  The time of operation during each business day of the proposed event or sale; 
H.  The applicant's current taxpayer identification number or evidence of application for a current taxpayer identification number; 
I.  A copy of the license any state or other authority required for the business to be conducted; and 
J.  Such further information as the clerk may deem necessary to enable him/her to issue the license. 
(Ord. 1337-88 § 3(part), 1988). 
5.04.041 - License to be displayed. 
    The applicant shall display the business license at the business location at all times during the event or sale. 
(Ord. 1337-88 § 3(part), 1988). 
5.04.042 - Issuance of duplicate license. 
    A duplicate license may be issued for a fee of five dollars by the city clerk to replace any license issued under this chapter which has been lost or destroyed. 
(Ord. 1337-88 § 3(part), 1988). 
5.04.050 - Fees-Designated. 
    The license fee which shall be paid to the city as a prerequisite to the conduct of the businesses named in this section shall be in the following amount: 
Carnivals $300.00 per day Circuses 300.00 per day Fortunetellers, palm readers, mediums, phrenologists, and any other business purporting to be able to forecast the future or to influence future events 150.00 per month Fruit and vegetable peddlers doing business at a temporary location. 50.00 per year Pawnshops 250.00 per year Distress sales 50.00 per sale Special sales 100.00 per sale Prizefights and wrestling 10.00 per day  
(Ord. 1337-88 § 2, 1988: Ord. 1196-82, 1982; Ord. 1195-82, 1982; Ord. 1172-81 § 6(b), 1981: Ord. 1163-80 § 10(b), 1980; prior code § 6-31). 
5.04.080 - Fees-Payment in installments. 
    The licenses issued pursuant to this chapter may be paid for in two equal installments on June 30th and December 31st of each year. 
(Prior code § 6-34). 
5.04.100 - Fees-Penalty for delinquent payment. 
    A penalty of ten percent of the amount due to the city under this chapter may be assessed upon any person who shall fail to pay the license fee prior to January 10th or new businesses who shall fail to pay the license fee prior to opening of business. 
(Prior code § 6-36). 
5.05.110 - Fees-Failure to pay is misdemeanor. 
    The failure of any person to pay a license fee as provided in this chapter within the time limits described in this chapter shall be deemed a misdemeanor. 
(Prior code § 6-39). 
5.04.120 - Exceptions. 
    Fruit and vegetable peddlers, who raise their own vegetables and fruits, and who sell their own home grown produce at a temporary location are not required to pay a license fee, but must file an application with the city clerk. 
(Ord. 1337-88 § 3(part), 1988). 
5.04.130 - Licenses for sponsored arts and crafts events. 
A.  Notwithstanding the provisions of this chapter, any organization with a headquarters, chapter or licensed business located within the city may obtain a license to conduct or sponsor an arts, crafts, or specialty consignment event or sale twice each calendar year within the city under the following conditions: 
1.  A fee of twenty-five dollars per event shall be paid for the license; 
2.  The sale or event may not exceed three days duration; 
3.  The sale must be conducted at a location in an E or F zone; 
4.  The applicant must display the business license at the sale location at all times during the event or sale; and 
5.  The granting of a license shall not constitute a waiver of payment of any New Mexico gross receipts tax required to be paid by state law. 
B.  Application for the arts, crafts or specialty sale license shall be submitted to the city clerk and shall contain the following information: 
1.  The exact nature or kind of sale for which the license is requested and the goods to be sold; 
2.  The dates on which the sale will be conducted and the hours of operation; 
3.  Proper verification of the identity, location and nonprofit status of the sponsoring organization; 
4.  Verification of the lease or agreement from the owner granting use of the property for sale; 
5.  A list of names and addresses of all vendors who will display goods for sale; and 
6.  Such further information as the clerk may deem necessary to enable him/her to issue the license. 
C.  Refusal by the clerk to issue a license may be appealed to the city commission within five business days of the receipt by applicant of the notice of refusal. The city commission may refuse to grant or issue a license under the provisions of this chapter whenever it may deem such refusal for the best interest of the public; provided, however, that no license shall be refused without giving the organization applying for the license an opportunity to be heard on such application; and provided further, that such refusal shall require a majority vote of the members of the city commission present and voting. 
(Ord. 1410-92 § 1, 1992; Ord. 1365-90, 1990). 
Chapter 5.06 - BUSINESS REGISTRATION FEE 

5.06.010 - Imposed-Rate. 
    There is imposed on each place of business conducted in this city a business registration fee of thirty-five dollars. The fee is imposed pursuant to Section 3-38-3, NMSA 1978, as it now exists or is hereafter amended, and shall be known as the business registration fee. The business registration fee may not be prorated for businesses conducted for a portion of the year. 
(Ord. 1699-2002 § 2, 2002: Ord. 1172-81 § 1, 1981). 
5.06.020 - Exemption. 
    No business registration fee shall be imposed on any business which has acquired a business license pursuant to Chapter 5.04 of the Clovis City Code. 
(Ord. 1172-81 § 2, 1981). 
5.06.030 - Application to do business required when. 
    Any person proposing to engage in business within the municipal limits of the city shall apply for and pay a business registration fee for each outlet, branch or location within the municipal limits of the city prior to engaging in business, unless such person is required to obtain a business license pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 5.04 of the Clovis City Code. 
(Ord. 1172-81 § 3, 1981). 
5.06.040 - Annual renewal of business registration. 
    Prior to March 16th of each year, any person with a place of business in the city, subject to this chapter and not otherwise exempt from this chapter shall apply for renewal of business registration with the municipal clerk. 
(Ord. 1172-81 § 4, 1981). 
5.06.050 - Application requirements for issuance or renewal of registration. 
    Any person filing an application for issuance or renewal of any business registration shall include in the application his current revenue division taxpayer identification number or evidence of application for a current revenue division taxpayer identification number. All applications shall be in writing and shall be prepared on a form authorized by the municipal clerk. 
(Ord. 1172-81 § 5, 1981). 
5.06.060 - Effective dates and transition provisions. 
    The following effective dates and the following transition provisions relating to the imposition or amendment of those taxes and fees imposed or adopted by this chapter shall be followed: 
A.  Those persons who have paid a license fee pursuant to Section 5.04.050 of the Clovis City Code for the calendar year 1981 shall not be subject to either the business registration fee or to the business license fee until January 1, 1982. 
B.  Those persons who were, on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this chapter, subject to the occupation tax imposed by Chapter 5.08* [] of the Clovis City Code shall continue to pay such occupation tax as imposed until January 1, 1982, at which time such persons shall be subject to the business registration fee imposed by Section 5.06.010. 
C.  Any person or firm commencing business within the municipal limits of the city after July 1, 1981, shall apply for and pay a business registration fee or a business license fee, whichever is applicable, according to the terms of this chapter and of Chapter 5.04 of the Clovis City Code. 
(Ord. 1172-81 § 8(a)-(c), 1981). 
Footnotes: 
--- () --- 
* Editor's Note: Chapter 5.08 was repealed by Ord. 1172-81. 

5.06.070 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person who violates this chapter or fails to comply with any of its requirements shall be subject to the penalty imposed by Section 1.24.020 of the Clovis City Code. Should any person conduct any business in violation of the provisions of this chapter, the city shall have the additional authority to: 
A.  Institute an appropriate action or proceeding to prevent the conduct of the business, or to restrain, correct or abate the violation of this chapter; or to prevent the occupancy of the building, structure or land on which the business is located; and 
B.  Bring suit in district court for the collection of any delinquent business registration fee or business license fee. 
(Ord. 1172-81 § 9, 1981). 
Chapter 5.12 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE SALES*[] 

Footnotes: 
--- () --- 
* For statutory provisions on the powers of municipalities to regulate and license the sale of alcoholic liquors, see N.M. Stat. Ann. § 60-6-1 et seq .; for provisions on offenses and penalties of the alcoholic beverages statutes, see N.M. Stat. Ann. § 60-1-1 et seq . 

5.12.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
A.  "Alcoholic liquors" means and includes any and all distilled or rectified spirits, potable alcohol, brandy, whisky, rum, gin, aromatic bitters bearing the federal internal revenue strip stamps, or any similar alcoholic beverage, including all blended or fermented beverages, dilutions or mixtures of one or more of the foregoing, containing more than one-half of one percent alcohol by volume, but excluding medicinal bitters. 
B.  "Beer" means any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of any infusion or decoction of barley, malt and hops or other cereals in water, and includes such liquors as porter, beer, ale, and stout. 
C.  "Club" means any organization of persons organized and operated under the laws of this state, organized for nonprofit to members, with a membership of not less than fifty regularly admitted and enrolled members who have paid membership dues at the rate of not less than five dollars per year, which is the owner, lessee or occupant of premises used exclusively for club purposes and which the chief of division of liquor control of the New Mexico Bureau of Revenue finds is operated solely for recreation, social, patriotic, political, benevolent or athletic purposes. 
D.  "Dispenser" means any person selling, offering for sale, or having in his possession with intent to sell, alcoholic liquors by the drink or in packages containing less than five gallons. 
E.  "Minor" means any person under twenty-one years of age. 
F.  "Package" means any immediate container of alcoholic liquors, beer or wine which is filled or packed by the manufacturer or bottler thereof for sale by such manufacturer or bottler to retailers, dispensers or clubs for resale. 
G.  "Retailer" means any person selling, offering for sale, or having in his possession with intent to sell, any alcoholic liquors for consumption off the premises of the licensee and in unbroken packages containing less than five gallons. 
H.  "Wine" means all alcoholic beverages obtained by the fermentation of the natural sugar contained in fruit or other agricultural products, with or without the addition of sugar or other products, and which does not contain less than one-half of one percent nor more than twenty-one percent alcohol by volume. 
(Prior code § 3-1). 
5.12.020 - License-Application investigation. 
    Upon receipt by the city of notice from the chief of the division of liquor control of the state of an application for a new license as a retailer, dispenser or club within the city or for transfer of an existing license, it shall be the duty of the chief of police to make a thorough investigation concerning the character and integrity of the applicant, the conditions existing in the neighborhood where such establishment is sought, the number of existing licenses in the locality or area affected, and the effect of the granting of such license or transfer upon the public health, safety and morals. 
(Prior code § 3-7). 
5.12.030 - License-Granting or denial. 
    At the completion of such investigation, the chief of police shall forthwith recommend to the city commission that such application be granted or denied as in their discretion may be for the best interest of the city, and thereupon, the city commission shall by motion either consent to or object to the granting of such license or transfer. The city clerk shall thereupon immediately advise the chief of the division of liquor control of the action taken by the city commission. 
(Prior code § 3-8). 
5.12.040 - License-City attorney duty. 
    It shall be the duty of the city attorney to represent the city in all hearings held by the chief of the division of liquor control upon applications to which objections have been filed by the city commission. 
(Prior code § 3-9). 
5.12.050 - License tax-Imposed-Amount. 
A.  There is imposed an annual license tax upon the privilege of persons holding licenses under the laws of the state of New Mexico to operate within the city as a retailer, dispenser, canopy licensee, restaurant licensee or club licensee in the amount of two hundred fifty dollars. 
B.  The tax levied by this section shall be paid on or before July 1st of each year. 
C.  The tax shall not be prorated, but shall be paid in the full amount by all persons or entities who operate under state authority within the city at any time during the period from July 1st to June 30th. 
D.  No person or entity shall receive a city license until the tax provided for in this chapter has been paid. 
(Ord. 1440-93 § 2, 1993: Ord. 1432-93 § 3, 1993). 
5.12.070 - License tax-Daily basis for dispensers at public celebrations. 
    Any person holding a dispenser's license for the sale of alcoholic liquors within the city, and a special permit issued by the state as provided by statute, and also holding a concession from the board or other governing body in charge thereof, for the sale of alcoholic liquors at a county fair or other public celebration is required to pay a tax in the amount of ten dollars per day for each day of such county fair or other public celebration. The daily tax imposed is payable in advance. The holder of any such special permit shall be subject to all laws of the city governing the sale of alcoholic liquors. 
(Ord. 1129-79 § 8, 1979: prior code § 3-4). 
5.12.080 - License tax-Business closed for nonpayment. 
    Any police officer of the city, upon the written order of the city commission, duly entered, shall forthwith close up the place of business of any retailer, dispenser or club who has not paid the municipal license tax according to the terms of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 3-5). 
5.12.090 - License tax-No refunds-Transferability. 
A.  The revocation or suspension of any retail, dispensary club license shall not entitle the licensee to the refund of any portion of the tax imposed by this chapter which such licensee has paid. 
B.  In the event of a transfer of any license under the provisions of the laws of the state, no refund shall be made by the city to the original licensee for the unexpired portion of such license, but such assignment and transfer shall vest in the assignee and transferee the right to operate under the license tax so paid by the original licensee for the period covered by the paid license tax and to pay the balance of such license tax upon the same terms and conditions as if such assignee or transferee were the original licensee. 
(Prior code § 3-6). 
5.12.100 - Dispensers-Permitted activities. 
    Any person holding a regularly issued and current license from the state as a dispenser and who has paid the license tax imposed by this chapter shall be entitled to carry on the business of a dispenser of alcoholic liquors at the place designated in such license. Such license shall entitle the holder thereof to sell alcoholic liquors, as in Section 5.12.010, by the drink or in packages containing less than five gallons. 
(Prior code § 3-10). 
5.12.110 - Dispensers-Unlawful activities. 
    It is unlawful for any dispenser, or the servant, agent or employee of any dispenser to: 
A.  Fail to break and destroy any empty bottle which has contained alcoholic liquors upon the emptying thereof; or 
B.  Pour into any empty or partially empty bottle which contains or has contained any alcoholic liquor, liquor of a different kind, class, brand, proof or age from that represented by the label, indicia, legend or descriptive matter on such bottle; or 
C.  Have, allow, suffer or permit upon the licensed premises of such dispenser any bottle containing alcoholic liquor of a different kind, class, brand, proof or age from that represented by the label, indicia, legend or descriptive matter appearing on the containing bottle; or 
D.  Expressly or impliedly misrepresent the kind, class, brand, proof or age of any alcoholic liquor served by the drink; or 
E.  Pour into any empty or partially empty liquor bottle, liquor of the same kind, class, brand and origin as that represented by the label, indicia, legend and descriptive matter appearing on the receptacle bottle. 
(Prior code § 3-24). 
5.12.120 - Dispensers-Violations designated. 
    It is a violation of this chapter for any dispenser: 
A.  To sell, possess for the purpose of sale, or to bottle any bulk wine, for sale other than by the drink for immediate consumption on his licensed premises; 
B.  To receive, have, possess, sell, keep or allow, suffer or permit upon his licensed premises any package or container of alcoholic liquor which does not contain less than five gallons; provided, that barrels, half-barrels and quarter-barrels of beer may be sold to persons and groups for consumption at parties, outings and picnics; 
C.  Directly or indirectly, or through any subterfuge, to own, operate or control any interest in any wholesale liquor establishment, liquor manufacturing or bottling firm; provided, that his subsection shall not prevent any dispenser from owning stock in any corporation which wholesales, manufactures or bottles alcoholic liquors when he owns such stock for investment purposes only; 
D.  To sell, or possess for the purpose of sale, any alcoholic liquors at any location or place except his licensed premises or the location permitted under Section 5.12.070. 
(Prior code § 3-11). 
5.12.130 - Retailers-Permitted activities. 
    Any person holding a regularly issued and current license from the state as a retailer and who has paid the license tax imposed by this chapter is entitled to carry on the business of a retailer of alcoholic liquors at the place designated in such license. Such license entitles the holder thereof to sell alcoholic liquors for consumption off his licensed premises and in unbroken packages containing less than five gallons. 
(Prior code § 3-12). 
5.12.140 - Retailers-Violations designated. 
    It is a violation of this chapter for any retailer: 
A.  To allow or permit any alcoholic liquors to be drunk or consumed on his licensed premises; 
B.  To maintain or keep in close proximity to such licensed premises any place for the consumption of alcoholic liquors purchased from him; 
C.  To sell any alcoholic liquors at any place other than his licensed premises; 
D.  Directly or indirectly, or through any subterfuge, to own, operate or control any interest in any wholesale liquor establishment, liquor manufacturing or bottling firm; provided, that this subsection shall not prevent any retailer from owning stock in any corporation which wholesales, manufactures or bottles alcoholic liquors when he owns such stock for investment purposes only. 
(Prior code § 3-13). 
5.12.150 - Clubs-Permitted activities. 
    Any person holding a regularly issued and current license from the state as a club and who has paid the license tax imposed by this chapter is entitled to carry on the activities of a licensee club at the place designated in such license. Such license entitles the holder thereof to sell alcoholic liquors by the drink for immediate consumption on the premises of such club. 
(Prior code § 3-14). 
5.12.160 - Clubs-Violations designated. 
    It is a violation of this chapter for any club to sell any alcoholic liquor, except beer, by the can or bottle, in any manner other than by the drink for immediate consumption on the premises thereof; provided, that nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent the sale and service of wines by clubs by the bottle for immediate consumption on the premises. 
(Prior code § 3-15). 
5.12.170 - Hours of business-Generally-On election days. 
A.  The licenses of retailers of alcoholic liquors shall allow them to sell and deliver alcoholic liquors, and the licenses of dispensers of alcoholic liquors and clubs shall allow them to sell, serve, deliver and permit the consumption of alcoholic liquors on their licensed premises on Mondays from seven a.m. until midnight, on other weekdays from after midnight of the previous day until two a.m. then from seven a.m. until midnight, and on Sundays only after midnight of the previous day until two a.m. 
B.  Dispenser, retail and club licenses shall close their places of business during voting hours on the days of the biennial primary election held on the second Tuesday in May of each even-numbered year and the biennial general election held upon the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November of each even-numbered year, and on the days of any municipal election held in the city. 
(Prior code § 3-22). 
5.12.180 - Hours of business-Sundays. 
    Any holder of a dispenser's or club license, who has obtained from the state of New Mexico a permit to sale, serve or permit the consumption of alcoholic liquors by the drink on the licensed premises on Sundays shall have the right to open their licensed premises for business on Sundays from twelve noon until midnight. 
(Ord. 1129-79 § 9, 1979: prior code § 3-22.1). 
5.12.190 - Serving liquor after hours of business unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any licensed retailer of alcoholic liquors to sell or deliver alcoholic liquors, or for any licensed dispenser or club to sell, deliver, serve or permit the consumption of alcoholic liquors on their licensed premises during hours other than those prescribed. 
(Prior code § 3-23). 
5.12.200 - Manufacturing for sale without license unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person who is not the holder of a license permitting the same, issued under the provisions of the laws of the state, or whose license has been suspended or revoked, to manufacture for the purpose of sale, sell, or possess for the purpose of sale, any alcoholic liquor in the city. The keeping in excess of one gallon of alcoholic liquors, as defined by this chapter, shall be prima facie evidence of an intent to sell the same. 
(Prior code § 3-16). 
5.12.210 - Selling or giving alcoholic beverages to minors-Possession. 
A.  It is a violation of this section for a person, including a person licensed pursuant to the provisions of the Liquor Control Act, or an employee, agent or lessee of that person, if he knows or has reason to know that he is violating the provisions of this section, to: 
1.  Sell, serve or give alcoholic beverages to a minor or permit a minor to consume alcoholic beverages on the licensed premises; 
2.  Buy alcoholic beverages for or procure the sale or service of alcoholic beverages to a minor; 
3.  Deliver alcoholic beverages to a minor; or 
4.  Aid or assist a minor to buy, procure or be served with alcoholic beverages; 
B.  It is not a violation of this section, as provided in subsections A or C of this section, when a parent or legal guardian of a minor serves alcoholic beverages to that minor on real property, other than licensed premises, under the control of the parent or legal guardian. 
C.  It is a violation of this section for a minor to buy, attempt to buy, receive, possess or permit himself to be served with alcoholic beverages. 
D.  In the event a person other than a minor procures another person to sell, serve or deliver alcoholic beverages to a minor by actual or constructive misrepresentation of facts calculated to cause, or by a concealment of facts the concealment of which is calculated to cause, the person selling, serving or delivering the alcoholic beverages to the minor to believe that the minor is legally entitled to be sold, served or delivered alcoholic beverages and actually deceiving him by that misrepresentation or concealment, then that person and not the person so deceived by such misrepresentation or concealment shall have violated this section. 
E.  As used in this section, "minor" means a person under twenty-one years of age. 
F.  In addition to the penalties provided in Section 60-6C-1 NMSA 1978, a violation of the provisions of subsection A of this section shall be punished as follows: 
1.  For a first violation, the offender shall be: 
a.  Fined an amount not more than five hundred dollars; 
b.  Ordered by the municipal court to perform thirty hours of community service relating to reducing the incidence of driving while under the influence of intoxicating liquor; 
2.  For a second violation, the offender shall: 
a.  Be fined an amount not more than five hundred dollars; 
b.  Ordered by the municipal court to perform forty hours of community service relating to the incidence of driving while under the influence of intoxicating liquor; 
c.  Have his license, issued pursuant to the Alcohol Server Education Act [Chapter 60, Article 6E NMSA 1978], suspended for a period of sixty days; and 
3.  For a third or subsequent violation, the offender shall: 
a.  Be fined an amount not more than five hundred dollars; 
b.  Be ordered by the municipal court to perform sixty hours of community service related to reducing the incidence of driving while under the influence of intoxicating liquor; 
c.  Have his license, issued pursuant to the Alcohol Server Education Act [Chapter 60, Article 6E NMSA 1978], suspended for a period of one year. 
G.  A violation of the provisions of subsection C of this section is a misdemeanor and the offender shall be punished as follows: 
1.  For a first violation, the offender shall be: 
a.  Fined an amount not more than five hundred dollars; 
b.  Ordered by the municipal court to perform thirty hours of community service related to reducing the incidence of driving while under the influence of intoxicating liquor; 
2.  For a second violation, the offender shall be: 
a.  Fined an amount not more than five hundred dollars; and 
b.  Ordered by the municipal court to perform forty hours of community service related to reducing the incidence of driving while under the influence of intoxicating liquor; and 
c.  Have his driver's license suspended for a period of ninety days. If the minor is too young to possess a driver's license at the time of the violation, then ninety days shall be added to the date he would otherwise become eligible to obtain a driver's license; and 
3.  For a third or subsequent violation, the offender shall be: 
a.  Fined an amount not more than five hundred dollars; 
b.  Ordered by the municipal court to perform sixty hours of community service related to reducing the incidence of driving while under the influence of intoxicating liquor; and, 
c.  Have his driver's license suspended for a period of two years or until the offender reaches twenty-one years of age, whichever period of time is greater. 
H.  A violation of the provisions of subsection D of this section is a misdemeanor and the offender shall be punished as follows: 
1.  For a first violation, the offender shall be: 
a.  Fined an amount not more than five hundred dollars; 
b.  Ordered by the municipal court to perform thirty hours of community service related to reducing the incidence of driving while under the influence of intoxicating liquor; 
2.  For a second violation, the offender shall be: 
a.  Fined an amount not more than five hundred dollars; 
b.  Ordered by the municipal court to perform forty hours of community service related to reducing the incidence of driving while under the influence of intoxicating liquor; and; 
3.  For a third or subsequent violation, the offender shall be: 
a.  Fined an amount not more than five hundred dollars; 
b.  Ordered by the municipal court to perform sixty hours of community service related to reducing the incidence of driving while under the influence of intoxicating liquor; and, 
c.  Sentenced to a jail term of not less than two days and not more than five days. 
(Ord. 1727-2003 § 3, 2003). 
5.12.250 - Providing liquor for alcoholic or person of unsound mind unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person to sell, serve, give or deliver any alcoholic liquors to, or to procure or aid in the procuring of any alcoholic liquors for any habitual drunkard or person of unsound mind knowing that the person buying, receiving, or receiving service of such alcoholic liquors is an habitual drunkard or is of unsound mind. 
(Prior code § 3-21). 
5.12.260 - Consuming in public places-Curb service unlawful. 
A.  It is unlawful to drink or consume alcoholic liquors, or for any person who is the owner or proprietor to sell, serve, furnish or permit the drinking or consumption of alcoholic liquors in any public dancehall, poolroom, bowling alley, street, state or federal building, or in any other public place except establishments having a license to dispense alcoholic liquors. 
B.  It is also unlawful for any licensee to give any kind of curb service of alcoholic liquors except in unbroken packages, outside of the building on the premises at which licensee's business is operated, except to customers seated at tables. 
(Prior code § 3-17). 
5.12.270 - Unlawful consuming designated. 
    It is unlawful for any person to drink any alcoholic liquors in any washroom or toilet of any dispenser, or to drink or consume upon the premises of any dispenser any spirituous liquor or wine so purchased to be consumed with meals; or to drink on the premises of any dispenser any alcoholic liquors obtained elsewhere. 
(Prior code § 3-25). 
Chapter 5.16 - DANCEHALLS AND PUBLIC DANCES*[] 

Footnotes: 
--- () --- 
* For statutory provisions on the licensing and taxation of business activities, see N.M. Stat. Ann. § 3-38-1 et seq . 

5.16.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
A.  "Public dance" means any dance operated for the profit of the person conducting the dance and to which the public, generally, is invited for the purpose of dancing and for which a charge is made, directly or indirectly, by the operator of the dance for the privilege of dancing. 
B.  "Public dancehall" means any building, structure, or tent of any kind or character: 
1.  In which dancing is permitted by the person operating the dancehall; 
2.  In which dancing is permitted regularly, not less often than twice each week; and 
3.  To which the public, generally, is invited for the purpose of dancing. 
(Prior code § 7-1). 
5.16.020 - Public dancehall license-Required. 
    No person shall maintain, operate, conduct, control or manage any public dancehall in the city except upon the issuance of a license therefor as required by Section 5.16.030. 
(Prior code § 7-2). 
5.16.030 - Public dancehall license-Requirements and conditions of issuance. 
A.  Any person desiring to operate, conduct or maintain a public dancehall within the city shall first secure a license therefor from the city. 
B.  Application for the license shall be made in writing to the city clerk, and the application shall set forth the name of the applicant, the location of the dancehall, the hours of operation of the dancehall and any other information pertaining to the dancehall. The application shall be accompanied by a license fee of two hundred sixty dollars. 
C.  The application, upon receipt by the city clerk, shall be referred by the clerk to the chief of police. The chief of police shall investigate the matters set out in the application, and if in his opinion the character of the applicant, or his employees or the nature of the location of the dancehall or the hours of operation of the dancehall, or any other information contained in the application are such that the operation of such dancehall would be detrimental to the public health, safety, morals or welfare, he shall endorse the application as rejected, otherwise the application shall be endorsed as approved. The chief of police shall thereupon return the application as endorsed to the city clerk. 
D.  If, but only if, the application is endorsed approved, the clerk shall issue to the named applicant a public dancehall license. In the event any such application is denied, the license fee of two hundred sixty dollars shall be returned to the applicant. 
E.  The license shall expire upon the thirty-first of December immediately following the granting of the same. 
F.  In no event shall any such license be granted for use upon property the exterior boundaries of which are located three hundred feet or nearer to the exterior boundaries of any property which is occupied at the time of the application for the license exclusively for residential purposes. 
(Prior code § 7-3). 
5.16.040 - Public dance license required-Requirements and conditions of issuance. 
A.  Any person desiring to conduct a public dance within the city, shall first secure a license from the city. 
B.  Application for the license shall be made in writing to the city clerk at least forty-eight hours before the dance is to be held, and the application shall set forth the name of the applicant, the time and place where the dance is to be held, and any other information pertaining to the dance. The application shall be accompanied by a license fee in the amount of ten dollars. 
C.  The application, upon receipt by the city clerk, shall be referred by the clerk to the chief of police. The chief of police shall investigate the matters set out in the application, and if in his opinion the character of the applicant, or the time at which the dance is to be held, or any other information contained in the application, are such that the conducting of such dance would be detrimental to the public health, safety, morals or welfare, he shall endorse the application as rejected; otherwise the application shall be endorsed as approved. The chief of police shall thereupon return the application as endorsed to the city clerk. 
D.  If, but only if, the application is endorsed approved, the clerk shall issue to the named applicant a license to operate the dance. In the event any such application is denied, the license fee of ten dollars shall be returned to the applicant. 
E.  The license shall be valid only for the time and place issued. 
F.  All licenses issued under this section shall expire at two a.m. the day following the day of commencement of the dance. 
(Prior code § 7-5). 
5.16.050 - License fee exemptions. 
    No license fee shall be deposited with the application of: 
A.  Any person conducting any dance for charity; 
B.  Any bona fide organization formed for purpose other than profit; or 
C.  Any person having paid a license fee under the provisions of Chapter 5.12. 
(Prior code § 7-4). 
5.16.060 - Adequate policing required. 
    The city shall provide adequate policing of each dance or ball licensed by the city. 
(Prior code § 7-6). 
Chapter 5.20 - JUNK DEALERS AND SECONDHAND STORES*[] 

Footnotes: 
--- () --- 
* For statutory provisions authorizing municipalities to regulate and license secondhand stores and junk dealers, see N.M. Stat. Ann. § 3-18-24; for provisions on junk dealers, see N.M. Stat. Ann. § 57-7-1 et seq . 

5.20.010 - Records of purchases required-Contents. 
A.  All secondhand stores and junk dealers operating and doing business within the city shall keep in writing a careful record of all goods, wares and merchandise purchased or procured by them in the course of business. 
B.  The record shall show the name of the person from whom the goods, wares and merchandise were purchased or procured, a description of the goods, wares and merchandise purchased or procured and the date of purchase or procurement. Such description shall include the name of the manufacturer, any serial number or trademark names which may appear thereon, and any other marks which may be used in identifying the goods, wares or merchandise. 
(Prior code § 11-1). 
5.20.020 - Records of sales required-Contents. 
A.  All secondhand stores and junk dealers operating and doing business in the city shall keep in writing a careful record of all goods, wares and merchandise sold by them. 
B.  The record shall show the name of the person making the purchase or procurement, a description of the goods, wares or merchandise purchased or procured (such description shall include the name of the manufacturer, any serial numbers or trademark names which may appear thereon, and any other marks which may be used in identifying the goods, wares and merchandise) and the date of such purchase or procurement. 
(Prior code § 11-1). 
5.20.030 - Record maintenance and inspection. 
    The records mentioned in Sections 5.20.010 and 5.20.020 shall be kept daily and shall be subject to the inspection of the city, county and state police. 
(Prior code § 11-3). 
5.20.040 - Conditions of purchase from minors. 
    The proprietor, owner or operator of any secondhand store or junk store operating and doing business within the city shall ascertain from the prospective seller of any goods, wares or merchandise to the store his age. If the prospective seller is under the age of eighteen years then the proprietor, owner or operator shall refuse to purchase the goods, wares or merchandise until the prospective seller produces written permission from his parents or guardian to sell the goods, wares or merchandise in question; and which statement further gives the age and full description of the seller. 
(Ord. 1129-79 § 10, 1979; prior code § 11-4). 
Chapter 5.24 - RUMMAGE, GARAGE AND YARD SALES 

5.24.010 - Definition. 
    When used in the ordinance codified in this chapter the term "garage" and/or "yard sale," including sales commonly referred to as home, mobile home or patio sales, means a sale of personal property to another within a residential area of the city, conducted in such a manner as to reasonably cause the public to believe that the person conducting the sale will cease and discontinue the selling of goods at the place of sale upon the disposal of the stock of personal property on hand. 
(Ord. 1477-95 § 3(part), 1995). 
5.24.020 - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to or effect the following: 
A.  Persons acting in accordance with their powers of a court of competent jurisdiction; 
B.  Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public officials; 
C.  Duly licensed auctioneers, selling at auction. 
(Ord. 1477-95 § 3(part), 1995). 
5.24.030 - Sale requirements. 
    Any person conducting a garage or yard sale shall comply with the following: 
A.  No property purchased for the purpose of resale to the public shall be sold at a garage or yard sale. 
B.  No person may conduct more than two garage and yard sales during any one year. 
C.  No sale shall be conducted for more than five consecutive days. 
(Ord. 1477-95 § 3(part), 1995). 
5.24.040 - Enforcement and penalty. 
    It is unlawful for any person to engage in a garage or yard sale in violation of the requirements of this chapter. Any person who violates this chapter shall be subject to the penalty imposed by Section 1.24.020 of the Clovis City Code. 
(Ord. 1477-95 § 3(part), 1995). 
Chapter 5.28 - COMMON MOTOR CARRIERS*[] 

Footnotes: 
--- () --- 
* For statutory provisions on motor carrier regulation, see N.M. Stat. Ann. § 65-2-1 et seq . 

5.28.010 - Purpose and policy. 
    It is declared to be the purpose and policy of this chapter to: 
A.  Relieve the existing and all future undue burdens on the streets arising by reason of the use of the streets by motor vehicles; 
B.  Protect the safety and welfare of the traveling public in their use of the streets; 
C.  Carefully preserve, foster and regulate transportation and permit the coordination of transportation facilities. 
(Prior code § 18-1). 
5.28.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
A.  "Common motor carrier" means any person who or which undertakes to transport passengers by motor vehicle for hire on the streets of the city, except those persons excepted in this chapter. 
B.  "Motor vehicle" means any automobile, truck, trailer, semitrailer, tractor, motor bus, or any self-propelled or motor-driven vehicle whether owned, hired, leased or rented and used upon any public streets of the city for the purpose of transporting persons for hire. 
C.  "Public street" means every public street, alley, road, highway or thoroughfare of any kind used by the public. 
(Prior code § 18-2). 
5.28.030 - Certificate of public convenience and necessity required. 
    The safety and welfare of the public and the preservation and maintenance of the public streets require the regulation of common motor carriers to the extent provided in this chapter. No person shall be permitted to act as a common motor carrier within the city unless that person has a current certificate of public convenience and necessity issued by the state Corporation Commission pursuant to the provisions of Sections 64-27-1 through 64-27-81, both inclusive, New Mexico Statutes Annotated, 1953 Compilation, as now amended and as the same may be amended from time to time. 
(Prior code § 18-3). 
5.28.040 - Exempted carriers. 
    No provision of this chapter shall apply to any of the following: 
A.  Motor vehicles used exclusively to convey children to and from schools; provided, that such vehicles shall, notwithstanding the provisions of this section, be subject to all of the safety provisions of this chapter or that may be prescribed by the commission; 
B.  United States mail carriers when not engaged in other business as common carriers of passengers; 
C.  Intercity buses operating principally outside the city limits and operating under permits from the state; 
D.  Buses traveling on fixed routes and operated under special authority or franchise of the city; 
E.  Mortuary and ambulance services. 
(Prior code § 18-4). 
5.28.050 - Compliance required. 
    No common motor carrier of passengers shall operate any motor vehicle, whether owned or leased, for the transportation of persons for hire except in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 18-5). 
5.28.060 - Rates designated-Posting requirements. 
A.  Rates charged by common motor carriers shall be those rates established for each such carrier by order of the state Corporation Commission. 
B.  Each such common motor carrier shall keep a rate schedule conspicuously posted in each vehicle operated by such carrier, and shall also post a copy of its rate schedule in its principal place of business within the city. 
(Prior code § 18-7). 
5.28.070 - Compliance with traffic regulations required. 
    All common carriers operating under this chapter shall at all times comply with all the traffic regulations of the city. 
(Prior code § 18-9). 
5.28.080 - Taxi driver-Identification required in cab. 
    It is required that all drivers of taxicabs shall have their pictures and name identification clearly displayed inside the cab so that any passenger may readily see the same. 
(Prior code § 18-12). 
5.28.090 - Taxi driver-Fingerprinting required. 
    It is required that all taxi drivers be fingerprinted. 
(Prior code § 18-13). 
5.28.100 - Commission inspection powers. 
    The commission may examine and inspect or cause to be examined and inspected, at reasonable times and in a reasonable manner, under its authority, the books, records, accounts, motor vehicles and facilities of any carrier subject to this chapter; provided, that any person conducting such shall produce, when so requested, his authority from the commission to make such examination or inspection. 
(Prior code § 18-10). 
5.28.110 - Parking requirements. 
    It is unlawful for any common motor carrier operating in the city to allow motor vehicles to stand on any portion of Main Street, or on any street within one block thereof, for a longer period of time than is necessary to load and unload such motor vehicle. Any common motor carrier operating any motor vehicle in the city shall maintain parking stands for the motor vehicle off the street and on private property, and the motor vehicle shall be parked in the parking stands when not in operation. 
(Prior code § 18-15). 
5.28.120 - Misdemeanors designated. 
    Any person who damages, destroys or injures any of the equipment operated under this chapter, or who steals a ride on any motor vehicle operated under this chapter or who refuses to pay fare thereon, or who is disorderly or offensive in conduct while a passenger on such motor vehicle, or who spits on the floor of such motor vehicle, is guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Prior code § 18-14). 
5.28.130 - Penalty for violation. 
    Every carrier to which this chapter applies, and every person who violates or who procures, aids or abets in the violating of any provision of this chapter shall be punished as provided in Section 1.24.020. 
(Prior code § 18-16). 
Chapter 5.32 - TRANSIENT SOLICITORS AND VENDORS 

5.32.010 - Defined. 
    "Transient solicitor and vendor," as used in this chapter, includes any person, whether a resident of the city or not, traveling by foot, automotive vehicle, or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares, or merchandise, offering or exposing the same for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers. One who solicits orders and, as a separate transaction, makes deliveries to purchasers as a part of a scheme or design to evade the provisions of this chapter is deemed a transient solicitor and vendor subject to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 6-1). 
5.32.020 - Permit and license-Required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of transient solicitor and vendor as defined in Section 5.32.010 within the city without first obtaining a permit and license therefor. 
(Prior code § 6-2). 
5.32.030 - Permit and license-Application requirements. 
A.  Applicants for permits and licenses under this chapter must file with the city clerk a sworn application in writing, in duplicate, on a form to be furnished by the city clerk, which shall give the following information: 
1.  The name and description of the applicant; 
2.  The permanent home address and local address of the applicant; 
3.  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold; 
4.  If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship; 
5.  The length of time for which the right to do business is desired; 
6.  The place where the goods or property proposed to be sold or orders taken for the sale thereof, or manufactured or produced, where such goods or products are located at the time such application is filed, and the proposed method of delivery; 
7.  A photograph of the applicant, taken within sixty days immediately prior to the date of the filing of the application, which picture shall be two inches by two inches showing head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishable manner; 
8.  The fingerprints of the applicant and the names of at least two reliable property owners in the county, who will certify as to the applicant's good character and business respectability; 
9.  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor; 
10.  A statement by a reputable physician of the city, dated not more than ten days prior to the submission of the application, certifying the applicant to be free of contagious, infectious or communicable disease. 
B.  At the time of filing the application, a fee of five dollars shall be paid to the city clerk to cover the cost of investigation of the facts stated in the application. 
(Prior code § 6-3). 
5.32.040 - License and permit-Application investigation. 
    Upon receipt of an application, as provided in Section 5.32.030, the original shall be referred to the chief of police, who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and moral character to be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the public good. 
(Prior code § 6-4). 
5.32.050 - License and permit-Disapproval. 
    If, as a result of the investigation provided for in Section 5.32.040, the character or business responsibility of the applicant are found to be unsatisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on the application his disapproval and his reasons for the same, and return the application to the city clerk, who shall notify the applicant that his application is disapproved and that no permit and license will be issued. 
(Prior code § 6-5). 
5.32.060 - License and permit-Approval. 
    If, as a result of the investigation provided for in Section 5.32.050, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on the application his approval thereof, and return the application to the city clerk. 
(Prior code § 6-6). 
5.32.070 - License and permit-Issuance and recordkeeping. 
    Upon receipt of an application for a license and permit as required by this chapter, endorsed by the chief of police as approved, the city clerk shall execute a permit addressed to the applicant for the carrying on of the business applied for and shall deliver the permit, upon payment of the prescribed license fee and upon posting of bond required by Section 5.32.080, to the applicant. The clerk shall keep a permanent record of all licenses issued. 
(Prior code § 6-7). 
5.32.080 - Bond requirements and conditions. 
    Every applicant, not a resident of the city, or who being a resident of the city represents a firm whose principal place of business is located outside of the state, shall file with the city clerk a surety bond, running to the city an amount of one thousand dollars, with surety acceptable to and approved by the city clerk, conditioned that the applicant shall comply fully with all the provisions of the ordinances of the city and the statutes of the state regulating and concerning the business of transient vendor or solicitor and guaranteeing to any citizen of the city that all money paid as a down payment will be accounted to and applied according to the representation of the solicitor and, further, guaranteeing any citizen of the city doing business with such solicitor, that the property purchased will be delivered according to the representations of such solicitor. Action on this bond may be brought in the name of the city to the use or benefit of the aggrieved persons. 
(Prior code § 6-8). 
5.32.090 - License exhibition required upon citizen request. 
    Transient solicitors and vendors are required to exhibit their licenses required by this chapter at the request of any citizen. 
(Prior code § 6-9). 
5.32.100 - Police officer enforcement duties. 
    It shall be the duty of any police officer of the city to require any person seen engaged in the business of transient soliciting and vending, and who is not known by such officer to be duly licensed, to produce his license, and to enforce the provisions of this chapter against any person found to be violating the same. 
(Prior code § 6-10). 
5.32.110 - License or permit-Grounds for revocation. 
    Permits and licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter may be revoked by the manager of the city after notice and hearing, for any of the following causes: 
A.  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the application for license; 
B.  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement made in the course of carrying on his business of transient solicitor and vendor; 
C.  Any violation of this chapter; 
D.  Conviction of any crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; 
E.  Conducting the business of peddling in any unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety, or general welfare of the public. 
(Prior code § 6-11). 
5.32.120 - License and permit-Notice of hearing on revocation. 
    Notice of the hearing for revocation of a license issued pursuant to this chapter shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the licensee at his last known address at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. 
(Prior code § 6-12). 
5.32.l30 - License and permit-Denial or revocation appeal procedure. 
    Any person aggrieved by the action of the chief of police, the city clerk or the city manager in the denial of an application for a permit or license as provided in Section 5.32.050, or in the decision with reference to the revocation of a license as provided in Section 5.32.110, shall have the right of appeal to the city commission. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the commission, within fourteen days after notice of the action complained of has been mailed to such person's last known address, a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for the appeal. The commission shall set a time and place for a hearing on the appeal and notice of the hearing shall be given to the appellant in the same manner as provided in Section 5.32.120 for notice of hearing on revocation. The decision and order of the commission on such appeal shall be final and conclusive. 
(Prior code § 6-13). 
5.32.l40 - License expiration dates. 
    All annual licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall expire on the thirty-first day of December in the year when issued. Other than annual licenses shall expire on the date specified in the license. 
(Prior code § 6-14). 
5.32.150 - Operating outside designated hours prohibited. 
    With the sole exception of that period of time between eight-thirty a.m. and five-thirty p.m., from Mondays through Saturdays, the practice of going in and upon private premises and residences in the city by transient vendors and solicitors, not having been requested or invited to do so by the owner or occupant of such private residence, for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares and merchandise, or for the purpose of disposing or peddling of the same, is declared to be a nuisance, and punishable as such nuisance as a misdemeanor. 
(Prior code § 6-14.1). 
Chapter 5.36 - WRECKING YARDS 

5.36.010 - Machinery-Wrecking requirements. 
    All persons engaged in wrecking and dismantling worn out automobiles, cars, trucks or other worn out machinery must do all wrecking on the inside of a building. 
(Prior code § 11-5). 
5.36.020 - Machinery-Screening of parts required. 
    All parts of worn out cars, automobiles, and other machinery, not kept within buildings, must be kept from the view of passing public. 
(Prior code § 11-6). 
5.36.030 - Accumulation of machinery parts on streets prohibited. 
    All persons operating wrecking yards must not permit parts of used cars to accumulate in the streets and in the alleys adjacent to their premises. 
(Prior code § 11-7). 
Chapter 5.40 - CARNIVALS, FESTIVALS AND CIRCUSES 

5.40.010 - Definitions. 
    The following terms, when used in this chapter, shall have the following definitions: 
A.  "Carnival" means any transitory commercial entertainment, amusement or exhibition of any kind or nature which provides amusement rides, concessions, games of skill or chance, and other similar forms of amusement. 
B.  "Circus" means any area or enclosure circular or oval in shape, whether or not covered by a tent or located within a building, which is surrounded by tiers of seats and which is intended for the commercial exhibition of feats of horsemanship, acrobatic performances, clowns, trained animals and other similar forms of amusement. 
C.  "City" means the city of Clovis, New Mexico. 
D.  "Festival" means any carnival which has fifteen or fewer amusement rides, or concessions. 
(Ord. 1163-80 § 1, 1980). 
5.40.020 - Permit-Required. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to maintain or operate any carnival, festival or circus within the city without first having made application for and received a permit in compliance with the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1163-80 § 2, 1980). 
5.40.030 - Permit-Application requirements.
