    No permit for construction shall be issued to erect, improve, expand or remodel any structure, when the permit application discloses a new connection to the sewer system is involved until a sewer connection fee has been paid as required by this chapter. When new sewer connections are required for existing structures, the sewer connection fee as determined herein shall be paid before the connection is made. The sewer connection fee established is additional to other building permit related fees and assessments. 
(Ord. 1354-89 § 2(part), 1989: Ord. 1278-86 § 2, 1986: prior code § 15-3). 
13.04.040 - Sewer connection fee-Single-family residential structures. 
    The sewer connection fee for all new single family residential structures (which shall include both single family structures, and mobile homes) shall be three hundred dollars for each structure. If the permit application discloses that any single family residential structure includes more than ten plumbing or waste fixtures, an additional charge of thirty dollars per fixture will be added to the sewer connection fee. 
(Ord. 1354-89 § 2(part), 1989: Ord. 1278-86 § 3, 1986: prior code § 15-4). 
(Ord. No. 1901-2009, § 2, 1-29-09; Ord. No. 1973-2011, § 2, 9-29-11). 
13.04.045 - Sewer connection fee-Multi-family residential structures. 
    The sewer connection fee for all new multi-family residential structures shall be accessed as follows: 
A.  One to ten dwelling units-Three hundred dollars per dwelling unit; 
B.  Eleven to twenty dwelling units-Two hundred seventy dollars per dwelling unit; 
C.  Twenty-one to thirty dwelling units-Two hundred forty dollars per dwelling unit; 
D.  Thirty-one to forty dwelling units-Two hundred ten dollars per dwelling unit; 
E.  Forty-one to fifty dwelling units-One hundred eighty dollars per dwelling unit; 
F.  Over fifty dwelling units-One hundred fifty dollars per dwelling unit. 
    For purposes of this section, the term "dwelling unit" shall mean one or more rooms within a residential multi-family structure, designed for one individual or family, living within such structure independently as a single housekeeping unit. 
(Ord. No. 1973-2011, § 3, 9-29-11). 
13.04.050 - Sewer connection fee-Business, commercial or industrial structures. 
    The sewer connection fee for all new business, commercial or industrial structures shall be three hundred fifty dollars for the first three plumbing or waste fixtures and forty-five dollars for each plumbing or waste fixture within the structure in excess of three. 
(Ord. 1354-89 § 2(part), 1989: Ord. 1278-86 § 4, 1986: prior code § 15-6). 
(Ord. No. 1901-2009, § 2, 1-29-09). 
13.04.055 - Special service fee. 
    A special service fee shall be charged in addition to the connection fees set forth in Sections 13.04.040 and 13.04.050 if the city has constructed or extended at city expense up to one hundred thousand dollars an addition to an interceptor or transfer main that makes sewer service available or that increases capacity for a definable area where service has not previously been available. The special service fee shall be computed by the city utility director in each case at the time of completion of the installation for the anticipated service area benefited, and shall bear a proportionate relationship with other benefited properties to the actual cost of the improvement made at city expense. Any benefited property owner may appeal the decision of the utility director to the city commission, whose decision will be final. The special service fee shall be paid at the time provided in Section 13.04.030. 
(Ord. 1641-2000 § 2, 2000). 
13.04.060 - Sewer connection fee-Improvements, additions or remodeling. 
    The sewer connection fee for all improvements of additions to, or remodeling of existing structures, requiring the installation of new or additional plumbing or waste fixtures, shall be twenty dollars for residential property and thirty dollars for commercial property for each such plumbing or waste fixture. 
(Ord. 1354-89 § 2(part), 1989: Ord. 1278-86 § 5, 1986: prior code § 15-8). 
13.04.080 - Sewer connection fee-Disposition of proceeds. 
    The proceeds of all sewer connection fees shall be placed in a special fund, which shall be used for the purpose of defraying in whole or in part: (a) the installation of new trunk or interceptor sewer lines as part of any required physical and geographical expansion of the city's sanitary sewer system, (b) the installation of new lift stations in sewer lines, or (c) the installation of supplemental or replacement trunk or interceptor sewer lines as may be required to increase the capacity of the city's existing sanitary sewer system, and for no other purpose. 
(Ord. 1354-89 § 2(part), 1989: Ord. 1278-86 § 7, 1986: prior code § 15-7). 
13.04.090 - Use without payment of fee unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person to make, have made or use any connection to the city sewer system until the sewer connection fee has been paid as required by this chapter. Violation of this provision shall be a petty misdemeanor. 
(Ord. 1354-89 § 2(part), 1989: Ord. 1278-86 § 8, 1986: prior code § 15-2). 
13.04.100 - Service charges-Minimum amounts-Billing system. 
A.  Findings. It is necessary that adequate rates, fees and charges be established and maintained for the services rendered by the sewer system of the city, in order that the city shall at all times receive sufficient revenues to pay operating and maintenance expenses of the system, and to furnish funds for capital improvements to the system. The city commission finds that the rates established by this section are reasonable and adequate. 
B.  Rates Established. There are affixed and established for services rendered by the sewer system of the city, the following minimum charges: 
1.  Effective April 1, 2009, for each connection to a main or lateral system to which not more than five outlets are attached, a minimum monthly charge of eight dollars and twenty-five cents. Effective April 1, 2010, for each connection to a main or lateral system to which not more than five outlets are attached, a minimum monthly charge of nine dollars and twenty-five cents. 
2.  Effective April 1, 2009, for each drain or outlet to a sewer connection in excess of five, an additional charge of one dollar and sixty-five cents per month. Effective April 1, 2010, for each drain or outlet to a sewer connection in excess of five, an additional charge of one dollar and eighty-five cents per month. 
C.  Miscellaneous. The city treasurer is authorized and directed to establish a cyclical billing system, and to bill the sewer charges established by this section on a quarterly basis, in advance. All sewer charges shall be payable at the office of the city treasurer. Nothing contained in this section shall be deemed to affect in any way the payment of the sewer connection fee established by the Clovis City Code. 
(Ord. 1853-2006 § 2, 2006; Ord. 1822-2005 § 2(A), 2005: Ord. 1516-96 § 1, 1996; Ord. 1464-94 § 1, 1994; Ord. 1399-91 § 1(B), 1991; Ord. 1320-87 §§ 2-4, 1987: Ord. 1186-82 § 2, 1982: Ord. 1141-80 §§ 2, 3, 1980: prior code § 15-9). 
(Ord. No. 1901-2009, § 2, 1-29-09). 
13.04.110 - Service charges-City to pay same rates for use. 
    No free service shall be furnished by the sewer system. Any use of the sewer system or of the services rendered thereby the city or any department thereof will be paid for at the rates established and the income so derived shall be deemed to be income derived from the operation of the sewer system and used and accounted for in the same manner as any other income derived from the operation of the sewer system. 
(Prior code § 15-11). 
13.04.120 - Service changes-Disconnection for nonpayment-Reconnection charge. 
    In the event that any charge for sewer service as provided is not paid within three months after the same shall become due, the city may disconnect the service. In every case where sewer service has been disconnected for nonpayment of sewer charges, reconnection of the service shall be made only after payment of all delinquencies plus the reasonable and actual expenses incurred by the city in disconnecting and reconnecting service, but not to exceed in any event the sum of twenty-five dollars. 
(Prior code § 15-10). 
13.04.130 - Charges payable at city treasurer's office. 
    All sewer charges shall be payable at the office of the city treasurer. 
(Prior code § 15-12). 
13.04.140 - Subdivisions connection conditions. 
    The owner or developer of any subdivision within the city or requesting annexation to the city shall be entitled to connect such subdivision to the sewer system of the city upon the following conditions: 
A.  Such subdivision shall be connected to existing trunk or other sewer lines by the owner or developer at a point approved by the city commission. Prior to the commencement of installation of the subdivision connecting line, plans and specifications prepared and sealed by a professional engineer licensed by the state shall be submitted to the city commission and approved by it. The plans and specifications so submitted shall, in any event, contain a design for a sewer line sufficient as to capacity to dispose of sewage waste which may be generated by such subdivision at the time when all lots contained therein shall be improved according to the plan for such subdivision. When the installation of the subdivision connecting line has been completed, the owner or developer shall furnish to the city commission a certificate from the engineer preparing the plans and specifications therefor, and bearing the seal of the engineer, reciting that the subdivision connecting line has been completed in strict compliance with the plans and specifications. 
B.  The cost of planning and installing the subdivision connecting line shall be borne by the owner or developer, and in no event shall any reimbursement of the cost be paid from public funds of the city. 
C.  In the event the city commission shall, in the public interest and for the purpose of providing sewer service to other present or potential sewer customers, require the owner or developer to install a connecting line of a capacity greater than that required to dispose of sewer waste generated or to be generated in the future within the subdivision in question, the owner or developer shall be paid by the city for the additional costs (including the additional engineering costs, if any) required by the installation of the larger sewer lines. 
(Prior code § 15-13). 
13.04.150 - Connection requirements and charges for nonresidents. 
A.  Owners of property located outside the city limits who desire to connect to and utilize the sewer system of the city shall apply to the director of public works and must meet the following requirements: 
1.  The director of public works must determine that the sewer system and wastewater treatment facility have sufficient capacity to handle the applicants' expected requirements. 
2.  Connections outside the city limits shall be allowed only to six-inch, eight-inch or twelve-inch lines. 
3.  The director of public works shall designate when connections require the installation of a manhole. The cost of installing a required manhole will be the responsibility of the applicant. 
4.  All connections shall be made in compliance with the city construction standards. All sewer lines serving more than one unit, or having the capability of serving more than one unit shall be installed to applicable city standards (including designs by a registered engineer, manholes, grades, etc.). 
B.  Sewer connection fees and service charges for sewer service to property outside the city limits shall be two times the applicable fees set forth in Sections 13.04.030, 13.04.040, 13.04.050, 13.04.060 and 13.04.100. 
C.  All provisions of Title 13, Chapters 13.04, 13.08 and 13.12 shall apply to property located outside the city limits and serviced by the sewer system. 
(Ord. 1418-92 § 2, 1992). 
Chapter 13.08 - EXTENSION OF SEWAGE FACILITIES TO NEW SUBDIVISIONS 

13.08.010 - Findings and purpose. 
    Tracts of raw land are located in or near the corporate limits of the city which are to be developed in the future as sites for the construction of residences, or commercial buildings, or for such other uses as might be appropriate. Aside from an informal policy prohibiting the extension of sewage disposal services outside its corporate limits, the city commission has never established a policy governing the extension of municipal sewage facilities to new subdivisions. It is the purpose of this chapter to establish such a policy, for the future guidance of the city administration and the owners of property subject to development. 
(Ord. 1164-80 § 1, 1980). 
13.08.020 - Preparation of plans. 
    Whenever the city administration receives any application for approval of a new subdivision over which the city has jurisdiction, the city administration will cause plans for the extension of sewage disposal facilities to the new subdivision to be prepared. The plans may, if necessary in the opinion of the city manager, be prepared by a registered professional engineer, and shall in any event comply with all city regulations applicable to the construction of sewage disposal lines and facilities. The plans shall include an estimated cost of constructing the necessary sewage facilities and of acquiring right-of-way, if any. 
(Ord. 1164-80 § 2, 1980). 
13.08.030 - Expense of sewer line extension. 
    Upon completion of the plans and the estimate of construction costs, the city administration shall submit the same to the owner of the proposed subdivision. Upon acceptance of the construction plans by the owner and the city, the owner shall deposit with the city treasurer a sum equal to the estimated total cost of the sewer construction. Sewer construction shall then be commenced and completed, either by a licensed independent contractor or by municipal personnel, if available. The deposit by the owner shall constitute an advance in aid of construction, and shall not be refundable except as provided in this chapter. All sewage facilities constructed pursuant to this chapter shall become and remain the property of the city, and the city shall be responsible for all maintenance, upkeep, repair and replacement of such sewage facilities. 
(Ord. 1164-80 § 3, 1980). 
13.08.040 - Refund of extension costs. 
    In the event the proposed line extension crosses property not belonging to the owner of the proposed subdivision, the plans shall include a statement of the portion of the costs of extension construction which, in the opinion of the individual preparing the plans and specifications, benefits property other than that belonging to the owner of the subdivision. At such time as the intervening property is developed and requires wastewater disposal service, the city will refund to the owner of the proposed subdivision that portion of the initial cost of the sewer line extension which was determined to be a benefit to the intervening property. In no event shall any refund be made more than five years after the date of the deposit with the city treasurer of the owner's advance in aid of construction. 
(Ord. 1164-80 § 4, 1980). 
13.08.050 - Acquisition and costs of rights-of-way. 
    The owner of the proposed subdivision shall furnish the city with all necessary rights-of-way for the construction of the proposed sewer extension, whether or not such rights-of-way are located within the proposed subdivision. Any costs incurred by the owner in obtaining rights-of-way shall be included as a total cost of the development of the proposed sewer line extension. Repayment of right-of-way costs shall be made in the same fashion as repayment of the construction costs. The city will, at the request of the owner of the proposed subdivision, exercise its powers of eminent domain in the acquisition of rights-of-way. 
(Ord. 1164-80 § 5, 1980). 
13.08.060 - Individual disposal facilities when city service unavailable. 
    Whenever the city administration receives any application for approval of a new subdivision over which the city has jurisdiction, and the city manager, upon the completion of appropriate engineering studies, determines that sewage disposal service cannot be made available to that proposed subdivision by the city, the city manager shall so certify to the owner of the proposed subdivision. The owner of the proposed subdivision shall thereafter make such plans for individual sewage disposal facilities as may be required by state or federal law or regulation. 
(Ord. 1164-80 § 6, 1980). 
13.08.070 - Final approval of proposed new subdivisions. 
    The planning commission shall not give its final approval to any proposed new subdivision unless: (a) the owner of the proposed subdivision has made the deposit of the advance in aid of construction as required by Section 13.08.030, or (b) the owner of the subdivision has been furnished a certificate that no sewage disposal services can be furnished to the subdivision by the city, as required by Section 13.08.060. 
(Ord. 1164-80 § 7, 1980). 
Chapter 13.12 - INDUSTRIAL WASTE 

13.12.010 - Title. 
    This chapter shall be known as the industrial waste ordinance of Clovis, New Mexico. 
(Ord. 1424-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
13.12.020 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter the following words shall have the following meanings: 
    "BOD" (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter in a five-day period at twenty degrees centigrade expressed in milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
    "COD" (denoting chemical oxygen demand) means a measure of the oxygen-consuming capacity of organic and inorganic matter present in wastewater as milligrams per liter (mg/l). 
    "Combined sewer" means a sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. 
    "Garbage" means solid wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storing and sale of produce. 
    "Industrial liquid wastes" means all waterborne solids, liquids or gaseous wastes resulting from any industrial, manufacturing or food producing operation or process, or from the development of any natural resource, or any mixture of these with water or normal domestic wastewater. Industrial manufacturing processes include, but are not limited to: food and allied products; tobacco manufacture; textile mill products; apparel and other finished products made from fabrics and similar materials; lumber and wood products, except furniture; furniture and fixtures; printing, publishing and allied industries; chemicals and allied products; petroleum refining and related industries; rubber and miscellaneous plastics products; leather and leather products; stone, clay, glass and concrete products; primary metal industries; fabricated metal products, machinery; electrical machinery; equipment and supplies; transportation equipment; professional, scientific and controlling instruments; photographic and optical goods; watches and clocks; and miscellaneous manufacturing industries. 
    "Interference with any wastewater treatment process" means any condition or combination of conditions which cause degradation of the operational efficiency of a wastewater facility. 
    "Normal domestic wastewater" means waterborne wastes normally discharged from the sanitary conveniences of residential buildings (including apartment houses and hotels), office buildings, factories and institutions, free from stormwater and industrial wastes. Normal domestic wastewater means "normal" for Clovis, New Mexico. 
    "Person" means any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation or group. 
    "pH" means the logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration of a solution. 
    "Properly shredded garbage" means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that has been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers with no particle greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
    "Public sewer" means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties shall have equal rights, and which is controlled by public authority. 
    "Sanitary sewer" means the public sewer portion of a wastewater facility which transports wastewater and to which storm, surface and ground water are not intentionally admitted. 
    "Settleable solids" are those solids that will settle to the bottom of a cone-shaped container (called an Imhoff cone) in a sixty-minute period expressed as milliliter per liter (ml/l) of the sample. 
    "Sewer" means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
    Shall and May. "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissive. 
    "Slug" means any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than fifteen minutes more than five times the average twenty-four hour concentration or flows during normal operation. 
    "Standard methods" means the laboratory procedures set forth in the latest edition, at the time of analysis, of Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater, as prepared, approved and published jointly by the American Public health Association, American Water Works Association and the Water Environment Federation or Methods for Chemical Analysis of Water and Wastes of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. 
    "Storm sewer" means a sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage, but which excludes wastewater and industrial wastes. 
    "SS" (denoting suspended solids) means solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in waters, sewage or other liquids, and which are removable by laboratory filtering as described in the standard methods. 
    "Trap" means a device for retaining sand, silt, grit, mineral materials, petroleum solvent, grease or soil by gravity differential separation from wastewater and which is of a design and capacity approved by the city. 
    "Unpolluted process water" means any water or waste containing none of the following: free or emulsified grease or oil; acid or alkali, phenols, or other substances imparting taste and odor to receiving water; toxic substances in suspension, colloidal state, or solution; and noxious or odorous gases. 
    "Wastewater" means the used water of a community. Such used water may be a combination of the liquid and waterborne wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions. 
    "Wastewater facility" means a system of structures, equipment and processes designed to collect, transport and treat domestic and industrial wastes and dispose of the effluent from a public system. 
    "Wastewater treatment works" means an arrangement of devices and structures for treating, stabilizing or holding wastewater and sludge, and may be used synonymously with waste treatment plant or wastewater treatment plant. 
    "Watercourse" means a channel in which a flow occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
    "Stormwater" means runoff resulting from rain, snowmelt and surface runoff and drainage. 
(Ord. 1424-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
13.12.030 - Discharge of water. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, water, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated water or unpolluted process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(Ord. 1424-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
13.12.040 - Discharge of surface waters. 
    Stormwater and other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as storm sewers, or to an outlet approved by the city manager. Industrial cooling water unpolluted process waters may be discharged on approval of the city manager to a storm sewer, or natural outlet. 
(Ord. 1424-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
13.12.050 - Prohibited waste discharge. 
    No person may discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described liquids or wastes to any public sewers: 
A.  Any pollutant with a closed-cup flashpoint of less than one hundred forty degrees Fahrenheit or sixty degrees centigrade or which are injurious in any other way to the wastewater facility or to the operation of the wastewater facility. Prohibited materials include, but are not limited to, gasoline, kerosene, naphtha, benzene, toluene, xylene, ethers, alcohols, ketones, aldehydes, formaldehydes, peroxides, chlorates, perchlorates, bromates, carbides, hydrides, sulfides, any other solvent, and any other substances which the city, the New Mexico Environment Department or U.S. EPA has notified the user is a fire hazard or a hazard to the wastewater facility; 
B.  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any wastewater facility, to constitute a hazard to humans or animals, to create a public nuisance, or to create any hazard in the receiving waters of the wastewater treatment works, including but not limited to cyanides in excess of 0.2 mg/l as CN in the wastes as discharged to the public sewer; 
C.  Any herbicides or pesticides, or other toxic refractory organic chemicals; 
D.  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5, or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment and personnel of a wastewater facility; 
E.  Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of a size capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the proper operation of the wastewater facility such as, but not limited to, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, residues from refining or processing of fuel or lubricating oil, plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and flesh, entrails, and paper or plastic dishes, cups and milk containers, either whole or by garbage grinders; 
F.  Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred fifty degrees Fahrenheit (sixty-five degrees centigrade); 
G.  Any water or waste containing fats, grease, wax or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred mg/l or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between thirty-two and one hundred fifty degrees Fahrenheit (between zero and sixty-five degrees centigrade); 
H.  Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation and operation of any garbage grinder larger than those normally manufactured and sold for residential and noncommercial use will not be installed without specific review and approval by the city manager; 
I.  Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or concentrations as may exceed limits established by the city manager in compliance with applicable state and federal regulations; 
J.  Any waters or wastes having a pH in excess of 9.5; 
K.  Petroleum oil, nonbiodegradable cutting oil or products of mineral oil origin or any substance which may cause an interference or pass-through; 
L.  Any water or waste containing total residual chlorine in excess of two mg/l; 
M.  Any water or waste containing ammonia (as nitrogen) in excess of sixty-five mg/l and/or total kjeldahl nitrogen (TKN) in excess of one hundred mg/l; 
N.  Any waters or wastes containing readily reducing oxidizable substances of an organic or inorganic nature, toxic or nontoxic, which exert an immediate chlorine demand cannot be discharged into the wastewater facility if discharge of such agents will prevent the achievement of an adequate chlorine residual in the effluent of the wastewater treatment works; 
O.  Any amount of the following contaminants in excess of the scale as shown below: 
Contaminant Daily Maximum Discharge 
Concentration (mg/l) Aluminum 5.0 Arsenic 0.1 Asbestos 7.0 million fibers/liter Barium 2.0 Beryllium 0.1 Boron 0.75 Cadmium 0.01 Chromium 0.1 Cobalt 0.05 Copper 1.0 Cyanide 0.2 Fluoride 4.0 Iron 5.0 Lead 5.0 Lithium 2.5 Manganese 0.2 Mercury 0.002 Molybdenum 0.01 Nickel 0.2 Nitrate (as Nitrogen) 10.0 Phenols (total) 1.0 Selenium 0.02 Silver 0.1 Zinc 5.0  
    Dilution of any contaminant in lieu of removal is not acceptable. 
(Ord. 1424-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
13.12.060 - Discretionary waste discharge. 
    No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following described substances, materials, waters or wastes if it appears likely in the opinion of the city manager that such wastes can harm the wastewater facility, or equipment, have an adverse effect on the receiving stream, or can otherwise endanger life, limb, public property, or constitute a nuisance. In forming an opinion as to the adaptability of these waters, the city manager will give consideration to such factors as the quantities of such wastes in relation to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of construction of the sewers, nature and capacity of the wastewater facility, degree of treatability of wastes in the wastewater treatment works and other pertinent factors. The substances which must be considered include but are not limited to the following: 
A.  Any waters or wastes containing strong acid, iron pickling wastes or concentrated plating solution cannot be discharged to the wastewater facility unless completely neutralized and approved by the city manager for discharge; 
B.  Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste- or odor-producing substances, in concentrations exceeding limits established by the city manager after treatment of the composite sewage, to meet the requirements of the state, federal or other public agencies of jurisdiction for such discharge to the receiving waters; 
C.  Materials which exert or cause: 
1.  Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but not limited to, Fuller's earth, lime slurries and lime residues) or of dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium chloride and sodium sulfate), 
2.  Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solutions), 
3.  Unusual COD and BOD or chlorine requirements in such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the wastewater treatment works, 
4.  Slugs or shocks constituting an unusual volume of flow or concentration of wastes which will disturb the normal functioning of the wastewater facility; 
D.  Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the wastewater treatment works employed, or are amenable to treatment only to such degree that the effluent cannot meet the requirements of agencies having jurisdiction over discharge of wastewater. 
(Ord. 1424-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
13.12.070 - Remedies for deleterious or hazardous discharges. 
A.  If any waters or wastes are discharged, or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in Section 13.12.060, and which in the judgment of the city manager may have a deleterious effect upon the wastewater facility, or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the city manager may: 
1.  Reject the waters or wastes; 
2.  Require pretreatment of the waters or wastes to any acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers; or 
3.  Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge of the waters or wastes. 
B.  If the city manager permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the city manager and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes, ordinances and laws. 
(Ord. 1424-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
13.12.080 - Use of grease, oil and sand traps-Inspection and administrative fees. 
A.  Grease, oil and sand traps shall be provided when, in the opinion of the city manager they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients; except that such traps shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All traps shall be of a type and capacity approved by the city manager and shall be so located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. Grease and oil traps shall be installed in all new filling stations, garages, restaurants and other new facilities wherein heavy discharge of grease and oil is to be expected. 
B.  In each instance of a backup, overflow or operational defect of a grease, oil or sand trap reported to city enforcement personnel, the owner of the facility shall be assessed an inspection fee of fifty dollars for each incident or violation. 
C.  If such instance results in backup or overflow into a city main line which necessitates emergency action of any type other than normal maintenance, the owner of the facility that caused the backup or overflow shall be assessed a fee of five hundred dollars or the actual cost of such emergency maintenance, whichever is greater, for each incident or violation. 
(Ord. 1455-94 § 2, 1994: Ord. 1424-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
13.12.090 - Testing and measurement frequency and cost payment. 
    Testing of an industrial waste will be performed at least twice a year or whenever found necessary by the city manager. The person discharging the waste shall be liable for payment of all costs arising from the testing of the industrial waste. 
(Ord. 1424-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
13.12.100 - Test standards. 
    All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes shall be determined in accordance with the standard methods and shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable samples taken at the said control manhole. The control manhole shall be so located that the sampling of the industrial waste will be performed before discharge into the public sewer system. 
    Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of the constituents upon the wastewater treatment works and to determine the existence of hazards to life, limb and property. (The particular analyses involved will determine whether a twenty-four hour composite of all outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples should be taken. Normally, but not always, COD, BOD and settleable solids analyses are obtained from twenty-four hour composite of all outfalls, whereas pH's are determined from periodic grab samples.) 
(Ord. 1424-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
13.12.110 - Maintenance of preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities. 
    Where preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities are provided for any industrial liquid wastes, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his expense. 
(Ord. 1424-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
13.12.120 - Use of control manholes and right to enter premises. 
    When required by the city manager, the owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial liquid waste shall install a suitable control manhole to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. 
    Such manhole, when required, shall be accessible and safely located, constructed in such a manner as to prevent infiltration of ground and surface waters, and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the city manager. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense, and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
    The city manager or his authorized agents, bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter upon all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1424-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
13.12.130 - Rates. 
    The city commission shall take necessary steps to establish a rate schedule for sewer service that assures an equitable system of sewer user charges. The purpose hereof is that the industrial users shall pay for the costs incurred by the city in construction, operation and maintenance of that portion of the wastewater facility related to industrial wastes. 
(Ord. 1424-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
13.12.140 - Sewer user charge. 
    The sewer user charge system shall satisfy the following conditions: 
A.  The apportionment of costs must take into consideration the individual industrial user's contribution as related to the total waste load, taking into account the volume and strength of all discharges; 
B.  The costs to be considered should include, but are not limited to: 
1.  Amortization of the city's indebtedness for the cost of the treatment facilities (plant and interceptors), 
2.  Operation and maintenance of the treatment facilities, 
3.  Any additional costs which are necessary to assure adequate treatment on a continuous basis, 
4.  Recovery of a portion of the capital replacement cost of this treatment facility; 
C.  Substantial payment of a capital replacement fund shall be included in its costs from each industry that contributes in excess of the domestic waste load to be treated by the project. 
(Ord. 1424-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
13.12.150 - Industrial waste charges. 
    A charge will be assessed against persons discharging industrial liquid wastes which are of greater strength and volume than normal, untreated domestic wastewater. Normal untreated domestic wastewater is defined as having a daily flow of two hundred fifty gallons per day and a maximum yearly average BOD not in excess of two hundred twenty milligrams per liter and a maximum yearly average SS not in excess of two hundred fifty milligrams per liter. 
    The user shall furnish the city documentation of the wastewater flow (water use) for each year. The industrial charge shall be in addition to basic sewer service charges indicated in Section 13.04.100 of this code. 
    Percentage allocation of basic rate to volume, BOD, and SS is as follows: 
Volume = 57% BOD = 23% SS = 20% 100%  
    The industrial user charge shall be calculated using the following mathematical relationship: 
Ic = AV + V [B (BOD-220) 
220 + C (SS-220) ]

where, 
Ic = Industrial charge per working day 
V = Volume of wastewater in 1000 gal/day 
A = Cost of treatment per 1000 gal/day of flow = $1.12

C = Cost of treatment per 1000 gal/day of suspended solids at 220 mg/l = $0.39 
Basic rate for treatment of normal domestic wastewater = $1.64/1000 gal 
    If the measured BOD is less than two hundred twenty mg/l and/or the measured SS is less than two hundred twenty mg/l, then in the above equation, the value of BOD will be assumed two hundred twenty mg/l and/or the value of SS will be assumed two hundred twenty mg/l respectively. 
(Ord. 1822-2005 § 2(B), 2005: Ord. 1424-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
13.12.160 - Measurement of volume of flow. 
    The volume of flow used in computing the industrial waste charges shall be based upon metered water consumption as shown in the records of meter readings maintained by the water utility company. In the event that a person discharging industrial waste into the city's sewer system produces evidence to the city manager demonstrating that a substantial portion of the total amount of water used for all purposes does not reach the city's sewer system, an estimated percentage of total water consumption to be used in computing charges may be established by the city manager. 
    Any person discharging industrial waste into the sewers of the city who procures any part or all of his water supply from sources other than the water utility company, all or part of which is discharged into the city's sewer, shall install and maintain at his expense water meters of the type approved by the city manager for the purpose of determining the proper volume of flow to be used in computing the industrial waste charges. Such meters shall be read monthly and tested for accuracy when deemed necessary by the city manager. Where it can be shown to the satisfaction of the city manager that a substantial portion of the water as measured by such meters, does not enter the sewer system of the city, the city manager may require or permit the installation of additional meters at the owner's expense, in such manner as to measure the quantity of water actually entering such sewer system from the lot, parcel of land, building or premises of such owner or other person or occupant, and the quantity of water used to determine the industrial waste charges may be the quantity of water actually entering the sewer system as so determined, if the city manager so elects. If the city manager finds that it is not practicable to measure the quantity or quality of waste by such meters or monitoring devices, he shall determine the quantity or quality of the waste in any manner or method he may find practicable, in order to arrive at the percentage of water entering the sewer system of the city and the quality of the sewage to be used to determine the industrial waste charges. 
(Ord. 1424-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
13.12.170 - Measurement of BOD. 
    The BOD used in computing the industrial waste charges for a particular year and for a particular industry shall be the simple average of at least five to seven consecutive days BOD of the effluent from the industry, which is discharged into the city's sewer system. The five to seven days time period will be based on the number of working days per week for the particular industry. There shall be at least two sampling events for a particular year, each comprising of five to seven consecutive days as mentioned. The sample collected for BOD measurement shall be either a flow-weighted composite sample or a time-weighted composite sample, whichever seems feasible to the city manager during the period of such sampling event. The user (the industry) may, however, provide the city with any number of sampling and testing data of their effluent for calculating the average BOD. The user supplied data shall contain at least five consecutive working days sampling and testing shall be done in accordance with the procedures described in the standard methods. In addition, all testings shall be performed in a state certified laboratory. The user shall have to get pre-approval from the city manager regarding the sampling location and whether the sample be time-composite or flow-composite. 
(Ord. 1424-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
13.12.180 - Measurement of SS. 
    The SS used in computing the industrial waste charges for a particular year and for a particular industry shall be the simple average of at least five to seven consecutive days' SS of the effluent from that industry, which is discharged into the city's sewer system. The five to seven days time period will be based on the number of working days per week for the particular industry. There shall be at least two sampling events for a particular year, each comprising of five to seven consecutive days as mentioned. The sample collected for SS measurement shall be either a flow-weighted composite sample or a time-weighted composite sample, whichever seems feasible to the city manager during the period of such sampling event. The user (the industry) may, however, provide the city with any number of sampling and testing data of their effluent for calculating the average SS. The user-supplied data shall contain at least five consecutive working days sampling and testing results for SS. All sampling and testing shall be done in accordance with the procedures described in the standard methods. In addition, all testings shall be performed in a state certified laboratory. The user shall have to get preapproval from the city manager regarding the sampling location and whether the sample be time-composite or flow-composite. 
(Ord. 1424-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
13.12.190 - Penalty for violation. 
    Every person convicted of a violation of this chapter shall be punished, pursuant to NMSA 3-17-1C(3) to pay a fine of not more than nine hundred ninety-nine dollars or shall be imprisoned in the county jail for not more than ninety days, or shall be sentenced to both such fine and imprisonment. Each day this chapter is violated shall constitute a separate offense. The conviction and punishment of any person for a violation shall not excuse or exempt such person from the payment of any fee due or unpaid at the time of such conviction. 
    All remedies prescribed or liens created hereunder or under the provisions of the law for collection and enforcement of the fees shall be cumulative and the use of one or more remedies by the city shall not bar the use of any other remedy for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this chapter or any liens created by the law. The fees fixed by this chapter shall be a lien in favor of the city upon the personal property of the person used in connection with the sewer use which gave rise to the fee and such lien shall be imposed, collected, enforced and paid as provided by law. No property of any person shall be exempt from levy and sale of execution issued for the collection of a judgment for any fee imposed by this chapter. 
(Ord. 1424-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
13.12.200 - Review and amendment of industrial waste charges. 
    The city commission may, every two years, review those factors in the formula established by Section 13.12.150 that relate to costs and may increase or decrease such factors to reflect the changes substantiated by operational experience. 
(Ord. 1424-92 § 2(part), 1992). 
Chapter 13.14 - FATS, OILS AND GREASE 

13.14.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following definitions shall be supplemental to the definitions given in the sewer ordinance of the city. 
A.  "POTW (publicly owned treatment works)" means the city's wastewater treatment plant including any sewers that convey wastewater to the POTW, and excluding pipes, sewers, or other conveyances not connected to the POTW. POTW includes any sewers that convey wastewater to the POTW from persons outside the city who are users of the city's POTW. If the context so dictates, POTW may refer to the city. 
B.  "BOD (biochemical oxygen demand)" means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure, five days at twenty degrees centigrade expressed in terms of weight and concentration (milligrams per liter (mg/L)). 
C.  "TSS (total suspended solids)" means solids that either float on the surface of, or are in suspension in waters, sewage or other liquids, and which are removable by laboratory filtering as described in standard methods. 
D.  "FOG (fat, oil and grease)" means compounds of alcohol or glycerol with fatty acids such as, but not limited to, butter, lard, margarine, vegetable fats and oil, and other related constituents found in wastewater. 
E.  "User" means any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation or group, who contributes, or causes or allows the contribution of wastewater into the POTW. 
F.  "Base strength" means normal untreated domestic wastewater with a maximum yearly average BOD not in excess of two hundred twenty mg/L, a maximum yearly average TSS not in excess of two hundred twenty mg/L, and a maximum yearly average FOG not in excess of two hundred mg/L. 
G.  "40 CFR" means the latest edition of Title 40 of Code of Federal Regulations. 
H.  "Standard methods" means the laboratory procedures set forth in the latest edition, at the time of analysis, of Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Waste-water, as prepared, approved and published jointly by the American Public Health Association, American Water Works Association, and the Water Environment Federation of Methods for Chemical Analysis of Water and Wastes of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. 
I.  "Grab sampling" means a single sample of water collected at a particular time and place which represents the composition of the water only at that time and place. 
J.  "Composite sampling" means a collection of individual samples obtained at regular intervals, usually every one or two hours during a twenty-four-hour time span. Each individual sample is combined with the others in proportion to the rate of flow when the sample was collected. Equal volume individual samples also may be collected at intervals after a specific volume of flow passes the sampling port or after equal time intervals and still be referred to as composite sample. The resulting mixture (composite sample) forms a representative sample and is analyzed to determine the average conditions during the sampling period. 
(Ord. 1485-95 § 2(part), 1995). 
13.14.020 - Surcharge parameters. 
    The city shall develop appropriate surcharge parameters based on federal and state requirements placed on the operation, maintenance and performance of the POTW. The parameters may include but shall not be limited to the following: 
A.  Flow volume, BOD, TSS, FOG; 
B.  A base concentration or mass for each wastewater parameter will be determined by the city. The user will be surcharged for discharges in excess of the base; 
C.  The city may apply any or all of the parameters to the user as appropriate. 
(Ord. 1485-95 § 2(part), 1995). 
13.14.030 - Estimation of wastewater flows. 
A.  The city will estimate the quantity of wastewater discharged by the user. The amount of wastewater discharged shall be assumed to be ninety percent of the water consumed unless the user can provide acceptable evidence to the city showing otherwise. 
B.  The city may request the user install wastewater measuring equipment and other related items to assist with making this determination. 
C.  The user shall provide a safe, secure location meeting the city's requirements for conducting flow measurement studies within ninety days of receipt of the city's request. 
(Ord. 1485-95 § 2(part), 1995). 
13.14.040 - Wastewater sampling. 
A.  Location. The city will determine the location for all wastewater sampling. The user shall provide a safe, secure location meeting the city's requirements for the wastewater sampling within ninety days of receipt of the city's request. 
B.  Method. The method of sampling shall be determined by the city. Methods may include grab or composite sampling depending on the user's flow, access, process and other variables. The standard method will be a composite sample. 
C.  Duration. The duration and frequency of sampling shall be determined by the city. Duration and frequency may include single samples or multiple samples taken over a period of time depending on the user's flows, access, process, hours of operation and other variables. The standard duration and frequency will be five, six or seven days, twenty-four hour time weighted or flow proportional composite samples taken twice per year or as determined by the city. 
D.  Analysis. All analysis of wastewater shall be conducted by an EPA or state-approved laboratory to comply with the analysis requirements listed in 40 CFR 136 and/or the latest edition of standard methods. 
(Ord. 1485-95 § 2(part), 1995). 
13.14.050 - Wastewater resampling. 
A.  City Resample. The city may perform a resample if the results of the analysis do not appear to correspond with the user's operation or for other reasons determined by the city. Resampling shall follow the same procedure as for wastewater sampling. The city may perform periodic resampling to assure continued compliance with these rules and regulations, including inspection of grease trap pumping records. 
B.  User Resample. The user has the right to sample their own wastewater and present the data to the city for use in the surcharge program. To be valid for use in the program, the user sampling, testing and reporting shall be performed a minimum of twice per year, as scheduled with the city and must comply with the following requirements: 
1.  40 CFR 136 and/or the most current edition of standard methods; 
2.  The procedures outlined by the city. 
(Ord. 1485-95 § 2(part), 1995). 
13.14.060 - Payment of costs arising from sampling and analysis. 
    The user shall be liable for payment of all the costs arising from the sampling and analysis of the wastewater discharged from their facilities. 
(Ord. 1485-95 § 2(part), 1995). 
13.14.070 - Assessment of the surcharge. 
A.  The city will assess the surcharge on the users found to be discharging wastewater above the base strength established as average domestic strength. 
B.  Calculation of surcharge will be made in accordance with the following formula: 
SC=(A)*(1000) * (QMG). 
FOG SC = (FOG mg/L - 200 mg/L) * ($.92) * (QMG). 
TOTAL COST (SC + FOG) = ((A) * (1000) * (QMG)) + ((FOG mg/L-200 mg/L * ($.92) * (QMG)). 
QMG = Wastewater flow rate in million gallons per month. 
A = Cost of treating 1000 gallons of flow = $.423. 
B = Cost of treatment per million gallons/month of FOG at 200 mg/L = $0.92. 
(Ord. 1485-95 § 2(part), 1995). 
(Ord. No. 2090, § 2, 7-6-17). 
13.14.080 - Violations. 
    Any of the following shall be in violation of this chapter: 
A.  Disregard of notification(s) issued by the city to install proper sampling equipment, sampling port or other items requested by the city; 
B.  Upon being shown proper identification, refusing to allow city personnel on user's property for the purpose of locating a sampling port, monitoring, estimating water usage or for the developing or confirming other information necessary for the program to administer; 
C.  Removing, damaging, relocating or tampering with sampling and monitoring equipment; 
D.  Falsifying grease trap maintenance records; 
E.  Nonpayment of surcharge over thirty days past due. 
(Ord. 1485-95 § 2(part), 1995). 
13.14.090 - Grease interceptor/trap standards. 
A.  Minimum Requirements. The minimum requirements for interceptor construction, materials and other features shall be those required by the Uniform Plumbing Code (UPC), latest edition and any modifications, revisions or amendments made by the city. A minimum size of grease interceptor of one thousand gallons with at least two compartments (effective two-thirds liquid volume in the first compartment and one-third liquid volume in the second compartment) is recommended by the city. If the wastewater discharge flow rate of a business is such that a larger system is recommended based on UPC (Uniform Plumbing Code) criteria, then the larger sized system should be installed. 
B.  Special Requirements. The size and type of grease interceptor shall be subject to the approval of the city's building inspection department. The grease interceptor shall be installed in a line separate from other sanitary plumbing facilities. In general, all grease interceptors shall be designed for exterior installation, of capacity sufficient to service those grease generating fixtures connected thereto. Wastes other than those requiring separation shall not be discharged into the grease interceptor. Grease traps shall be designed, located and constructed in a manner that will permit easy access and maintained by the operator and inspected by the city. 
C.  An approved sample port shall be installed on the discharge side of all new installations. Sample ports shall be installed on existing traps and interceptors as deemed necessary for accurate sampling. 
(Ord. 1485-95 § 2(part), 1995). 
(Ord. No. 2090, § 2, 7-6-17). 
13.14.100 - Preexisting grease interceptors. 
    Any user currently operating a grease interceptor/trap, shall be exempt from these requirements, except in those cases where the city determines that the following conditions exist: 
A.  Inadequate sizing of grease interceptor/trap; 
B.  Inadequate maintenance procedures exist; 
C.  FOG concentration exceeds two hundred mg/L; 
D.  Plumbing system which separates grease interceptor facility from remainder of the sanitary system is not placed; 
E.  A sewage blockage has occurred or is occurring that, in the opinion of the city manager or his designee, may impact the public safety and welfare or the integrity of the public sanitary sewer; or 
F.  Inadequate sampling locations. 
    Should an existing grease interceptor/trap be found to meet one of the conditions above, the user operating the grease interceptor/trap shall immediately improve the conditions to comply with the requirements. 
(Ord. 1485-95 § 2(part), 1995). 
(Ord. No. 2090, § 2, 7-6-17). 
13.14.110 - Maintenance. 
    Grease interceptors/traps shall be located close to the grease-laden wastewater source and cleaned at or before the grease layer depth reaches seventy-five percent of its effective total liquid depth. The operator of a grease interceptor shall maintain a log book of all maintenance activities and evidence of grease disposal in accordance with the city regulations. Grease interceptors/traps shall be subject to unannounced inspection by the city at any time during their operation. 
(Ord. 1485-95 § 2(part), 1995). 
13.14.120 - Failing system. 
A.  Any grease generating user that is currently operating without the required grease interceptor, even though there may have been no history of blockages caused by or downstream from their location, shall be required to install a grease interceptor within a specified time period, as agreed upon between the user of the facility and the city's building inspection department. 
B.  The user shall submit plans or technical drawings to install a grease trap as stipulated in this chapter, within two months after receiving notice of noncompliance. 
C.  The user shall then have up to three additional months to install the grease interceptor, upon approval of the drawings by the city's building inspection department. 
(Ord. 1485-95 § 2(part), 1995). 
13.14.130 - Enforcement. 
    Enforcement procedures shall include: 
A.  Denial of any application for a new sewer service connection pending installation of a grease interceptor; 
B.  Any user, currently on an on-site sewer system, that is making an application to connect to the public sanitary sewer, shall install or show proof of installation of a grease interceptor, according to the above requirements, prior to the approval of the application; 
C.  Any user that is found to have grease traps which are inadequate to meet the requirements of this chapter, and is connected to the public sanitary sewer system, and/ or is in the process of changing owners, lessees or renters, shall update the system in compliance with these rules and regulations, before the new owner or operator can initiate business. 
D.  The code official shall make all the required inspections, or shall accept reports in inspection by approved agencies or individuals. All reports of such inspections shall be in writing and be certified by a responsible officer of such approved agency or by the responsible individual. The code official is authorized to engage such expert opinion as deemed necessary to report on unusual technical issues that arise, subject to the approval of the appointing authority. Section 1.04.3 (2009 International Plumbing Code) 
E.  Whenever it is necessary to make an inspection to enforce the provisions of this code, or whenever the code official has reasonable cause to believe that there exists in any building or upon any premises any conditions or violations of this code that make the building or premises unsafe, insanitary, dangerous or hazardous, the code official shall have the authority to enter the building or premises at all reasonable times to inspect or to perform the duties imposed upon the code official by this code. If such building or premises is occupied, the code official shall present credentials to the occupant and request entry. If such building or premises is unoccupied, the code official shall first make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other person having charge or control of the building or premises and request entry. If entry is refused, the code official shall have recourse to every remedy provided by law to secure entry. Section 1.04.3 (2009 International Plumbing Code) 
(Ord. 1485-95 § 2(part), 1995). 
(Ord. No. 2090, § 2, 7-6-17). 
13.14.140 - Penalties for violations. 
A.  In cases where grease interceptors are found to be inadequate due to undersizing, blockages that have occurred more than once, or the systems are not in place, or in compliance with this chapter, the city shall have the option to discontinue or revoke the business license to the responsible establishment. 
B.  Business license may be discontinued ninety days following the receipt of the notice of noncompliance, if the user has not submitted technical drawings or any other evidence that the noncompliance is being corrected. 
C.  Late fees will be charged by the city according to Chapter 3.20 for nonpayment of the surcharge over the thirty days past due. 
D.  Any user convicted of a violation of this chapter shall be punished, pursuant to NMSA 3-17-1c(3) and city code Section 1.24.030(B)(3), to pay a fine of not more than nine hundred ninety-nine dollars or shall be imprisoned in the county jail for not more than ninety days, or shall be sentenced to both such fine and imprisonment. Every day this chapter is violated shall constitute a separate offense. The conviction and punishment of any user for a violation shall not excuse or exempt such user from the payment of any fee due or unpaid at the time of such conviction. 
(Ord. 1485-95 § 2(part), 1995). 
Chapter 13.20 - LIQUID WASTE DISPOSAL RATES 

13.20.010 - Liquid waste disposal charge. 
    There is imposed a disposal charge of ninety-five dollars per thousand gallons, upon any person, firm or corporation using the wastewater treatment plant operated by the city for the disposal of liquid waste. 
(Ord. 1825-2005 § 2(part), 2005). 
Chapter 13.22 - PLAYA LAKE EXCAVATION 

13.22.010 - Authorization. 
    The director of public works is authorized to approve the excavation of soil from city-owned playa lakes, not to exceed two thousand five hundred cubic yards per excavation, in accordance with the policies and procedures set forth in this chapter. Any requests to excavate soil in excess of two thousand five hundred cubic yards, shall require the approval of the Clovis city commission. All permits and approvals pursuant to this chapter require a predetermination by the director of public works that the excavation will benefit the city of Clovis stormwater management plan by increasing the storage capacity of its playa lake(s), and will not be detrimental to the health safety or general welfare of the city or any adjoining property owner(s). 
(Ord. 1813-2005 § 2(part), 2005). 
13.22.020 - Application. 
    Each applicant requesting authority to remove and excavate soil from a city playa shall submit to the director of public works an application which shall state: 
A.  Name of applicant; 
B.  Address of applicant; 
C.  Amount of soil to be excavated and removed; 
D.  Dates for removal; 
E.  Equipment to be used; 
F.  Any other information requested by the director of public works. 
(Ord. 1813-2005 § 2(part), 2005). 
13.22.030 - Permits. 
    Upon receipt of the application and permit fee, and having made the determinations required by this chapter, the director of public works may grant a permit containing: 
A.  A designation of the playa lake from which the excavation is authorized; 
B.  The location within the playa lake where the soil is to be excavated; 
C.  Prescribed dust suppression methods to be utilized during the excavation; 
D.  Approval of equipment and excavation methods and procedures; 
E.  Designated route(s) for hauling from the excavation site; 
F.  Designated restoration work required by the applicant, which may include surface grading and seeding; 
G.  Expiration date of permit (permit shall not be issued for a period in excess of six months). 
(Ord. 1813-2005 § 2(part), 2005). 
13.22.040 - Permit fee. 
    At the time of submitting an application, the applicant shall pay a nonrefundable fee of fifty dollars. 
(Ord. 1813-2005 § 2(part), 2005). 
13.22.050 - Penalty. 
    If, at any time during the excavation authorized by the permit, the permittee fails to comply with any of the permit provisions, the director of public works may order an immediate termination of the excavation and cancellation of the permit. The permittee shall be responsible for reimbursing the city of Clovis for any costs incurred by the city arising from permittee's failure to comply with all permit requirements in a timely manner as prescribed by the director of public works. No new or additional permit shall be issued to any applicant for a permit, if that applicant has violated the terms of a previous permit or has failed to reimburse the city pursuant to this subsection. 
(Ord. 1813-2005 § 2(part), 2005). 
Chapter 13.24 - WATER MANAGEMENT ORDINANCE 

13.24.010 - Policy. 
    It is the policy of the city of Clovis to protect and conserve the consumption of water in order to insure and protect the availability of the supply of water for all residents and citizens of the city. During periods of drought, or at any time during which the supply, pumping capacity, weather conditions and weather forecasts indicate that the availability of water is threatened or comprised, the measures set forth in this chapter shall become effective and shall be implemented and enforced in the manner provided herein. 
(Ord. 1755-2003 § 2(part), 2003). 
13.24.020 - Water savings required. 
    Water conservation stages shall be determined when the possibility exists that the water utility will not be able to meet all of the water demands of its customers by a proportion of demand in relation to system capacity. Water usage restrictions shall be designated in four stages of water rationing and restriction identified in Appendix "A"*, attached and made a part of the ordinance codified in this chapter. 
A.  Stage 1 - Voluntary Water Conservation. Voluntary water conservation shall be in effect from April 1 to October 1. The procedure for Stage 1 shall be as follows: 
1.  The city manager will make public announcements in the news media that Stage 1 voluntary water conservation is in effect. 
2.  Users will be urged to conserve water in every way possible, in their homes and in their businesses. 
3.  People will be urged to avoid sprinkling their lawns and avoid watering gardens, shrubs or trees in the manner set forth in Appendix "A"*. 
B.  Stage 2 - Water Rationing. Water rationing will be in effect whenever the demand is at eighty-five percent of capacity for three consecutive days. The following requirements will be in effect: 
1.  The city manager will make public announcements through the news media concerning Stage 2 water rationing, whenever Stage 2 water rationing is in effect. The announcement will include a description of the restrictions. 
2.  All restrictions identified in Appendix "A" will become effective until Stage 2 water rationing is cancelled by the city manager. 
C.  Stage 3 - Water Rationing. Stage 3 water rationing will be in effect whenever the demand is at ninety-five percent of capacity for five consecutive days. The following requirements will be in effect: 
1.  The city manager will present to the Clovis city commission such information as is available regarding the demand deficiency and request authority from the city commission to engage Stage 3 water rationing restrictions. 
2.  The city commission shall declare Stage 3 water rationing and direct enforcement of the restrictions set forth in Appendix "A"*. 
3.  The city manager will make public announcements that Stage 3 water rationing is in effect in the news media, which restrictions shall continue in effect until the city manager determines that the demand has been reduced below ninety-five percent of capacity. 
D.  Stage 4 - Water Rationing. Stage 4 emergency water rationing shall be in effect whenever the demand is at ninety-eight percent of capacity for three consecutive days. The following requirements will be in effect: 
1.  The city manager will submit information regarding the water supply conditions and the demand deficiency percentage to the city commission, at an emergency meeting if necessary. 
2.  The city commission shall declare a Stage 4 emergency and impose Stage 4 water rationing restrictions as set forth in Appendix "A"*. 
3.  At such time as the demand is reduced below ninety-eight percent of capacity, Stage 3 restrictions shall automatically be imposed until the demand falls below ninety-five percent of capacity, at which time Stage 2 restrictions shall apply. 
4.  The city manager will make public announcements through the news media of the implementation of Stage 4 water rationing restrictions, to be followed by subsequent announcements regarding any changes in the applicable stage of water rationing restrictions. 
E.  If, based on a single event, or a combination of circumstances, at either Stage 3 or Stage 4, the city manager concludes that emergency conservation action is required to be implemented or that adjustment to the current level of conservation is necessary, the city manager is authorized to initiate procedures consistent with this section and seek ratification at the next regular, special, or emergency meeting of the city commission. 
(Ord. 1755-2003 § 2(part), 2003). 
(Ord. No. 1964-2011, § 2, 8-4-11). 
* Appendix "A" is available on file at the city clerk's office. 
13.24.030 - Adoption of use restrictions table. 
    The drought management water use restrictions table set forth in Appendix "A" is hereby adopted, and shall become enforceable pursuant to the policies and procedures set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. 1755-2003 § 2(part), 2003). 
13.24.040 - Responsibility. 
    No person shall be convicted of violating this chapter unless such person in fact, turned on water, directed the turning on of water, or kept water turned on after learning that it was turned on in violation of this chapter or failure to turn off automatic devices capable of turning on water in violation of this chapter. It will not be necessary however, to present a witness who saw the accused turning on the water, if the circumstances indicate the accused violated the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1755-2003 § 2(part), 2003). 
13.24.050 - Penalties. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be punished in accordance with the following schedule for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurred or continues: 
First violation Written warning Second violation Fine of $20.00 Third violation Fine of $50.00 Fourth violation Fine of $100.00 Fifth and subsequent violation Fine of $300.00  
(Ord. 1755-2003 § 2(part), 2003). 
13.24.060 - Recommended year-round usage restrictions. 
    It is recommended to water consumers in the city of Clovis that the following recommended practices/restrictions be followed on a voluntary basis: 
A.  Landscape watering discouraged between the hours of ten a.m. and six p.m. 
B.  Shutoff nozzles are recommended on hoses used for hand water. 
C.  Washing hard surfaces is discouraged (e.g. driveways, sidewalks, parking lots, outdoor eating areas). 
D.  Fugitive water shall not be permitted to leave the intended irrigated area. 
(Ord. 1755-2003 § 2(part), 2003). 
Title 15 - BUILDINGS AND CONSTRUCTION 
Chapter 15.04 - AVAILABILITY AND APPLICABILITY OF CODES 

15.04.010 - Findings and purpose. 
    Section 3-18-6, NMSA 1978 authorizes municipalities to prescribe certain building and construction standards within its planning and platting jurisdiction, and to issue permits pertaining to buildings. 
A.  Section 3-17-6, NMSA 1978 authorizes municipalities to adopt by ordinance the conditions, provisions, limitations and terms of any codes so long as the codes provide for minimum requirements at least equal to the state requirements on the same subject. 
B.  An ordinance adopting such code need only refer to the proper title and date of the code only, without setting forth the codes, conditions, provisions, limitations and terms and may include any exception or deletion to the code by setting forth the exception or deletion. 
C.  It is in the best interests of the public for the city to adopt uniform standards for building and construction, exercising the full authority granted by the New Mexico Constitution and the laws and statutes of the state of New Mexico. 
(Ord. 1759-2003 § 3(1), 2003). 
15.04.020 - Availability. 
    Each of the codes which have been adopted by reference in this title shall be available for inspection during normal and regular business hours at the office of the city clerk or at the office of the city building inspector. A copy of the codes adopted by reference in this title shall be available upon request and payment of a reasonable charge. 
(Ord. 1759-2003 § 3(2), 2003). 
15.04.030 - Interpretation. 
    Where conflicts occur between the technical codes, those provisions providing the greater safety to life shall govern. In other conflicts where sanitation, life safety, or fire safety are not involved, the most restrictive provisions shall govern. Where a conflict occurs between the Building Code and the Mechanical or Plumbing Codes the Building Code shall govern. The 2015 International Mechanical Code and the 2015 International Plumbing Code, both published by the International Code Council may be used as reference documents to help resolve such conflicts. 
(Ord. No. 1879-2008, § D, 3-20-08; Ord. No. 1988-2012, § 2, 10-4-12; Ord. No. 2093-2017, § 2, 8-3-17). 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1879, § B, adopted March 20, 2008, repealed the former § 15.04.030, and enacted a new § 15.04.030 as set out herein. The former § 15.04.030 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 1759-2003, 2003. 
15.04.040 - Enforcement-Procedure-Penalties. 
A.  The director of building safety, and all enforcement personnel and inspectors under his direction shall have the power and duty to enforce the provisions of the following chapters of the Clovis City Code; except that primary enforcement of the Fire Code (Chapter 15.12) shall be the responsibility of the fire chief, or his designee: 
1.  Chapter 15.08, Building Code; 
2.  Chapter 15.10, Fuel Gas Code; 
3.  Chapter 15.12, Fire Code; 
4.  Chapter 15.14, Property Maintenance Code; 
5.  Chapter 15.16, Residential Code; 
6.  Chapter 15.20, Mechanical Code; 
7.  Chapter 15.22, Existing Building Code; 
8.  Chapter 15.24, Energy Conservation Code; 
9.  Chapter 15.26, Electric Code; 
10.  Chapter 15.28, Plumbing Code. 
B.  Whenever any work is done in violation of any of the chapters referenced in the preceding subsection, or in variance with the terms of any permit issued, the inspector may order all work stopped until and unless all violations are eliminated and any work or installation made under the provisions of these regulations is corrected. Such stop order, if oral, shall be followed by a written stop order within twenty-four hours, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays or holidays. It shall be unlawful to do or perform any work in violation of such stop order, except as may be necessary to prevent injury or damage to persons or property. 
C.  A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
D.  If the condition has not been corrected within the time specified in the stop order, the city officer or inspector shall issue a citation for the infraction. Any person, firm or corporation found guilty of a violation of the terms of the chapters referenced in this section shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars nor more than three hundred dollars for the first offense. Any person, firm or corporation found guilty of a second violation occurring after the first conviction, but within one year of the first conviction shall be fined not less than two hundred dollars nor more than four hundred dollars. Any person, firm or corporation found guilty of a third violation occurring within one year after conviction of the first offense, shall be fined not less than three hundred dollars nor more than five hundred dollars for each offense. Violations after the third offense shall be treated in the manner provided for a third offense. 
(Ord. 1845-2006 § 2, 2006; Ord. 1767-2004 § 2, 2004).
