ARTICLE II - PROVISIONS OF GENERAL APPLICABILITY 

17.100.100 - Provisions of general applicability. 
    The procedures in this article shall be followed whenever such a procedure is required by Table 17.100.010. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.110 - Preapplication conference. 
A.  Purpose. The purpose of the preapplication conference is to familiarize the applicant with the goals and policies of the comprehensive plan and with the applicable provisions of this title. 
B.  Initiation. An applicant may request a date for the preapplication conference with the planning department staff. The request shall be accompanied by a description of the character, location and magnitude of the proposed development and the type of approval sought. Upon receipt of the request for a preapplication conference, the planning department staff shall schedule and hold the preapplication conference. The applicant shall be notified of the time, date and place of the preapplication conference. 
C.  No Binding Effect. The planning department staff shall review the material, make recommendations, and indicate concerns, problems, or other factors the applicant should consider in pursuing the proposal. Neither the applicant nor the city shall be bound by any statements or determinations made during the preapplication conference. Any time limits imposed by this title shall not be applicable to the preapplication conference. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.120 - Applications. 
A.  Initiation. Unless otherwise indicated in this chapter, applications shall be submitted by the owner, or any other person having a contractual interest in the land for which the use is proposed, or an authorized agent. If the owner resides out-of-state, he shall designate an individual or firm in-state for notice and service of process. 
B.  Submission of Application. An application shall be submitted to the planning department staff along with a fee established pursuant to Section 17.100.140. Applications received before two p.m. shall be dated the same working day. Applications received after two p.m. shall be dated the next working day. 
C.  Inspection and Access. Accompanying any application shall be a signed statement granting the city staff right of reasonable access to view, enter and inspect the property, uses or buildings on the site for compliance with this title. 
D.  Contents of Application. The application shall be submitted in a form established by the planning department staff and made available to the public. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.130 - Application completeness review. 
    The planning department staff shall determine, within two working days, if the application is sufficient and includes data necessary to evaluate the application. 
A.  If the planning department staff determines the application is incomplete or not sufficient, a written notice shall be mailed to the applicant specifying the application's deficiencies. No further action shall be taken on the application until the deficiencies are remedied. If the applicant fails to correct the deficiencies within twenty working days, the application shall be considered withdrawn and the application fee shall be refunded. 
B.  When the application is deemed complete, the planning department staff shall notify the applicant and begin the requisite reviews. If a public hearing is required, the date shall be set to hear the application and the applicant notified in writing. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.140 - Fees. 
    Fees shall be established and revised as needed, by resolution of the city commission, to defray costs of the application and review process. All applications shall be accompanied by the applicable fee. The fee schedule shall be available for review in the planning department. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.150 - Public hearings. 
A.  All applications requiring public hearings shall follow the provisions of this article. 
B.  Subject to subsection C below, the hearing shall be open to the public and all persons interested in the outcome of the appeal or application. All parties shall be given an opportunity to present evidence and arguments and ask questions of persons who testify. 
C.  The body conducting the public hearing may place reasonable and equitable limitations on the presentation of evidence and arguments and the cross-examination of witnesses so the matter at issue may be heard and decided without undue delay. 
D.  The body conducting the hearing may continue the hearing until a subsequent meeting and may keep the hearing open to take additional information up to the point a decision is made on the matter. No further notice of a continued hearing need be published if the date, time and place of the continuance are announced prior to the recess. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.151 - Notice of public hearings. 
    The planning department staff shall be responsible for ensuring notice in newspaper and mailed notice. The applicant shall be responsible for ensuring posted notice and shall provide the planning department staff with an affidavit and photographs evidencing compliance at least ten calendar days prior to the public hearing. 
A.  Notice in Newspaper. Applications shall be advertised in the legal notice section of a newspaper of general circulation in the city. Such notice shall appear no less than fifteen calendar days prior to the date of the public hearing and shall contain the following information: 
1.  The date, time and place of the public hearing; 
2.  A short description of the proposed action requested and the legal address and/or location of the property; 
3.  Specify how additional information can be obtained. 
B.  Mailed Notice. A mailed notice shall contain all the information required under Section 17.100.151(A). The planning department shall mail the notice to all property owners within one hundred feet of the subject property, as shown by the latest records of the county assessor, no less than ten calendar days prior to the public hearing. Similar notice shall be mailed to any interested person who has requested such notice and provided a self-addressed, stamped envelope for such purpose. 
C.  Posted Notice. The applicant shall post and maintain the notice on one or more signs, provided by the planning department staff, on the property which is the subject of the public hearing at least fifteen calendar days in advance of the public hearing. 
1.  One sign shall be posted for each two hundred feet of footage along a public or private road. 
2.  The sign(s) shall be set back no more than five feet from the street right-of-way. 
3.  All signs shall be erected in full view of the public on each street side of the land subject to the application. Where the land does not have frontage on a public street, signs shall be erected on the nearest street right-of-way with an attached notation indicating generally the direction and distance to the land subject to the application. 
4.  The applicant shall remove the sign(s) after the close of the hearing on the application. 
5.  The failure of any such posted notice to remain in place after the notice has been posted shall not be deemed a failure to comply with the standards or be grounds to challenge the validity of any decision made on the application. 
D.  Follow-Up. A separate notice stating next action(s) and with whom is not required following the public hearing or decision of a respective body in accordance with Section 17.90.310. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.152 - Public hearing procedure. 
    A public hearing held pursuant to this title shall comply with the following procedures: 
A.  Setting the Hearing. 
1.  When the planning department staff determines that an application is complete and that a public hearing is required by this title, the planning department staff shall consult with the person or board required to conduct the public hearing and shall schedule a place and time for the public hearing. 
2.  Pursuant to Section 17.100.151, the hearing shall be scheduled for the first available regularly scheduled meeting of the planning and zoning commission providing adequate time to ensure the public notice requirements can be satisfied or such time later as is mutually agreed upon between the applicant and the planning department staff. 
B.  Review and Recommendation of the Planning Department Staff. 
1.  The planning department staff shall review the application and prepare a staff report no later than five calendar days before the scheduled public hearing on the application. 
2.  The staff report shall recommend any changes in the application, as submitted, and the conditions for approval, if any, necessary to bring the application into compliance with the standards of this title. 
3.  Prior to the hearing, the planning department staff shall request appropriate city departments and other agencies to comment on the application. Comments received shall be made a part of the record of the public hearing. 
4.  The planning department staff shall provide a copy of the staff report to the applicant no later than five calendar days prior to the public hearing on the application. 
C.  Examination and Copying of Application and Other Documents. Upon reasonable request, and during normal business hours, any person may examine any application and materials concerning the application in the planning department. Copies of such materials shall be made available at cost and upon reasonable notice. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.153 - Conduct of public hearing. 
    The public hearing shall be conducted in the following manner: 
A.  Oath. Testimony and evidence shall be under oath or affirmation. 
B.  Rights of All Persons. Any person may appear at a public hearing and submit evidence. 
1.  If the person represents an organization, the chairman may request written evidence of that person's authority to speak on behalf of the organization in regard to the matter under consideration. 
2.  Each person who appears at a public hearing shall be identified, state an address, and if appearing on behalf of an organization, state the name and mailing address of the organization. 
3.  All parties shall have the right to cross-examine any persons offering testimony. 
C.  Order of Proceedings. The order of the proceedings shall be as follows: 
1.  The planning department staff shall present a written staff report which includes a narrative and/or graphic description of the application and a recommendation. 
2.  The applicant shall present any information the applicant deems appropriate. 
3.  Public testimony shall be heard. 
4.  The applicant may respond and cross-examine any person providing testimony or evidence. 
5.  The planning department staff, the city attorney, and any other city staff may respond to any statement made by the applicant or any public comment. 
D.  Testimony. The body conducting the public hearing may exclude testimony or evidence that it finds to be irrelevant, immaterial, or unduly repetitious. In the event such testimony or evidence is excluded, the person offering such testimony or evidence shall have an opportunity to make a proffer in regard to such testimony or evidence for the record. Such proffer shall be made at the public hearing. 
E.  Continuance of Public Hearing. The body conducting the public hearing may continue the public hearing to a fixed date, time and place announced prior to the recess. An applicant shall have the right to request and be granted one continuance. Any subsequent continuances requested by any party shall be granted at the discretion of the body conducting the public hearing only upon good cause shown. 
F.  Withdrawal or Modification of Application. An applicant shall have the right to withdraw or modify an application at any time prior to the action on the application by the decision-making body. Unless such modifications are so substantial or extensive that the decision-making body cannot reasonably be expected to perceive the nature and impact of the proposed changes without revised plans before it, the decision-making body may approve the application with the stipulation that the permit will not be issued until plans reflecting the agreed upon changes are submitted to the planning department. 
G.  No Ex Parte Contact. No member of the decision-making body shall inspect the site under consideration with any party or his representative. Any member who communicates outside of the public hearing with any party shall supply to the record of the hearing a copy of any documents given to the member and a written description indicating what issues about the pending action were discussed. 
H.  Record. 
1.  The body conducting the public hearing shall record the public hearing. The written or taped record of the proceedings, including testimony and statements of personal opinions, the minutes of the secretary, all applications, exhibits and papers submitted in any proceeding before the decision-making body, the staff report, and the decision of the decision-making body shall constitute the record. 
2.  All records of decision-making bodies shall be public records, open for inspection at the planning department during normal business hours upon reasonable notice. 
3.  A copy of the public hearing record may be obtained by any person upon applying to the planning department and paying the cost of duplication of the record. 
(Ord. 1524-97 § 2(part), 1997; Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.154 - Actions by decision-making bodies. 
    After the close of the public hearing, the person or board conducting the public hearing shall consider the application, the relevant support materials, the staff report and the public testimony given at the public hearing. The person or board holding the hearing shall render a decision or recommendations, as appropriate, either to approve, approve with conditions, or disapprove the application based on the standards of this title. 
A.  All decision-making bodies and persons shall act within the time limits established in this title. Action shall be taken as promptly as possible in consideration of the interests of the citizens of Clovis. 
B.  In addition to a statement of the ultimate disposition of the matter, all decisions or recommendations shall be in writing and shall include the following: 
1.  A clear statement of specific findings of fact and a statement of the basis upon which such facts were determined, with specific reference to the relevant standards set forth in this title. 
2.  A clear statement of approval, approval with conditions, or disapproval. 
3.  Any other information deemed necessary by the decision-making administrative body. 
C.  A decision made pursuant to this article is final unless an appeal is filed with the planning department staff within ten days following the date of the decision. 
D.  Notification of a decision shall be provided by the planning department staff to the applicant by certified mail, return receipt requested. A copy of the decision shall also be made available to the public at the planning department, during normal business hours, within a reasonable period of time after the decision. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.160 - General considerations in rendering decisions. 
    This title is intended to protect the interests of both present and future residents, landowners, neighbors and the general public. In rendering a decision, the decision makers shall be bound to use the standards of this title and other applicable regulations. The following rules shall govern decisions: 
A.  Except as provided in subsections B and C of this section, all decisions shall be based solely on written standards of this title, or other relevant city codes or laws. 
B.  The minimum standards of this title shall be met; however, if written findings are made regarding the unique health, safety or general welfare concerns of a particular project or a particular site, conditions may be imposed. 
C.  Where interpretation is required in rendering a decision, the legislative intent (see Section 17.110.010) shall be used to guide decisions. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.170 - Effect of approval. 
    The approval of any application shall be deemed to authorize only the particular use, plan, or other specific activity for which it is issued. Approvals shall run with the land. There are two exceptions to these rules: zoning text changes and use interpretations which are universal in application. 
A.  Time Limitations. Approvals shall expire, as indicated in Table 17.100.170, if any of the following occur: 
1.  No building permit has been issued to establish the use authorized in the approval; 
2.  Where the use does not require a building permit, the use is not established, ongoing, and in operation; 
3.  The approval is a step in a multi-stage approval process, and the next stage application has not been accepted as complete; 
4.  Any approval not listed in Table 17.100.170 shall not have a time limit. 
B.  An approval does not change with changes in ownership. 
Table 17.100.170 
Time Limits and Extensions 
Use Time Limitation (months) Extension (months) Conditional use 12* 6 Variance 12 6 Appeal 18 6 Limited use 12 6 Sign permit 6** 3 Zoning permit 12 6 Site plan 12 6  
*  Unless specified otherwise in the conditional use approval. 
** If part of a zoning permit or site plan, twelve months. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
ARTICLE III - STANDARDS FOR APPROVAL 

17.100.210 - Amendments to the text or zoning map. 
    This section provides a method for changing the boundaries of the zoning map or the text of this title. It is not intended to relieve particular hardships, or to confer special privileges or rights on any person, but only to make necessary adjustments in light of changed conditions. In determining whether to grant a requested amendment, the city shall consider the factors set forth in this section and the consistency of the proposed amendment with the intent of the comprehensive plan. 
A.  Initiation. 
1.  Amendment to Zoning Map. In addition to the landowner, an application for an amendment to the zoning map may be proposed by the city commission, planning and zoning commission or planning department staff. 
2.  Amendment to Text of Title. An application for an amendment to the text of this title may be proposed by the city commission, the planning department staff, the landowner or any citizen of the city. 
B.  General Standards. There shall be findings that amendments to the text of this title or a general amendment to the zoning map shall be consistent with the purpose and provisions of this title and the comprehensive plan. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.211 - Standards for zoning map amendment. 
    Amendments to the zoning map shall be approved only if there are findings that they meet at least one of the following standards: 
A.  Amendments that are consistent with the comprehensive plan shall be approved unless there is compelling evidence that there would be a threat to the public health, safety and welfare which is unique to the proposed amendment because the location of the property is substantially different from other areas so designated in the comprehensive plan. 
B.  Amendments that are inconsistent with the comprehensive plan shall be approved only if the applicant demonstrates that the existing zoning is inappropriate because: 
1.  An error or mistake was made when the existing zoning map pattern was created; or 
2.  The conditions of the neighborhood or community have substantially changed to justify the change. 
C.  An amendment to the zoning map shall not be approved where some of the permissive uses in the proposed district would be harmful to adjacent property, the neighborhood or community. 
D.  The cost of land or other economic considerations pertaining to the applicant shall not be the determining factor. 
E.  A zoning change request which would designate one small area different from the surrounding area, especially when only one premises is involved, is generally called a spot zone. Such a request may be approved only when: 
1.  The change will clearly facilitate implementation of the comprehensive plan; or 
2.  The area of the proposed change is different from surrounding land because it could function as a transition between adjacent districts, or because the site is not suitable for the uses allowed in any adjacent districts due to topography, traffic, or special adverse land uses nearby, or because the nature of structures already on the premises makes the site unsuitable for the uses allowed in any adjacent district. 
(Ord. 1524-97 § 2(part), 1997; Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.212 - Standards for title text amendment. 
    An amendment to the text of this title shall be approved if: 
A.  It would implement a portion of the comprehensive plan that is new; 
B.  It would implement and better achieve the goals and objectives of the comprehensive plan that have proved difficult to achieve under the existing provisions of this title; 
C.  The provisions of this title were inconsistent or unreasonable in light of standards for similar uses; 
D.  It is necessary in order to respond to state and/or federal legislation; 
E.  It provides additional flexibility in meeting the objectives of this title without lowering the general standards of this title. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.220 - Conditional uses. 
    Approval of an application for a conditional use shall be dependent upon findings that the proposed use fully complies with all the standards of this title. The application shall be filed and duly advertised and a public hearing held per the requirements of this chapter. In addition, a conditional use shall require approval of a site plan or a plat, as appropriate, which may be approved separately or concurrently. The following additional standards shall also be met: 
A.  The proposed use shall be consistent with the purposes, goals, objectives and policies of the comprehensive plan, including standards for building and structural intensities and densities, and intensities of use. 
B.  The proposed use shall be compatible with the character of the immediate vicinity of the land proposed for development. 
C.  The design of the proposed use shall minimize adverse effects, including visual impact of the proposed use on adjacent lands. 
D.  The proposed use shall minimize adverse impacts on the environment, traffic and congestion, infrastructure or governmental services. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.221 - Conditions and restrictions. 
    The decision-making body may impose reasonable restrictions and conditions on the approval of conditional use permits. All conditions and restrictions shall be put in writing and given to the developer within two days after the approval. The approval and all conditions are to be agreed to by the developer in writing within ten days. If there is no agreement, the application shall be considered denied. This may be done to accomplish any of the following: 
A.  Ensure the conditional use is developed exactly as presented in drawings, exhibits and assertions made at the hearings; 
B.  Limit uses, reduce density, increase open space, landscaped surfaces or environmental protection to insure it meets the standards by which it is approved; 
C.  Impose conditions that ensure the general purposes, goals and objectives of the comprehensive plan and this title are met; 
D.  Prevent or minimize adverse effects from the proposed use and development on other properties in the neighborhood and on the general health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.222 - Minor deviations. 
    The planning department staff may authorize minor deviations from conditional use permits that appear necessary in light of technical or engineering considerations first discovered during actual development and that are not reasonably anticipated during the initial approval process, as long as they comply with the standards of this title. Minor deviations shall not include increases in the intensity of use, the introduction of uses not previously approved, or decreases in the amount of open space or resource protection. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.223 - Amendment to a conditional use permit. 
    A conditional use permit may be amended, extended, varied or altered only pursuant to the standards and procedures for the approval of the original use set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.230 - Planned redevelopment overlay (PRO) district. 
    This section sets forth procedures and requirements for approving a planned redevelopment overlay (PRO) district. This overlay district is a planned development in which the approval is based on a preliminary site plan. The approval shall be treated as a conditional use approval subject to the requirements and standards of Sections 17.100.220-17.100.223. If public funds or eminent domain are to be used, the city shall comply with State Statute 3-60A-1 NMSA. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.231 - Eligibility. 
    The following requirements must be met to submit an application for a PRO district. 
A.  The district for redevelopment is at least fifty percent developed at the time of application; 
B.  The area shall be contiguous and have at least one-half block with frontage on three streets; 
C.  The area shall be in common ownership, or approved by owners of not less than seventy-five percent of the total area within the district; and 
D.  Upon approval of the owners of seventy-five percent of the area within the district, the city will enforce the zoning and building code ordinance in all new and existing district buildings. 
(Ord. 1718-2002 § 2(part), 2002: Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.232 - Plan requirements. 
    The plan shall meet the following standards: 
A.  The plan shall meet all requirements for a preliminary plan or plat in accordance with the subdivision regulations for the city. 
B.  A building conditions survey shall indicate all district building and property conditions. City inspectors shall have the right of access to confirm the survey data. 
C.  The preliminary plat shall indicate redevelopment areas, where buildings will be demolished and new building(s) added, and conservation areas where buildings will be rehabilitated or remain as-is, except for upgrading to comply with the city codes. 
D.  The preliminary plat shall indicate any proposed plat vacations accomplished by combining lots, streets or alleys. 
E.  The applicant shall submit a detailed description of the intended redevelopment actions and their timing and financing, including a permitted use table identifying on the plan where specific uses shall be permitted. Landscaping, sign control, street, or other public improvements shall be listed. Any proposed improvements to be performed by the city shall be identified. The proposed bonuses shall be indicated. 
F.  The applicant shall provide a specific list of any requested changes in standards from those in the underlying district, including permitted uses, lot, or other standards. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.233 - Standards. 
    The PRO district shall meet the following minimum standards: 
A.  The conditional approval requirements of Section 17.100.220; 
B.  A specific finding shall indicate the area is or has deteriorated, and that approving a PRO district will encourage reinvestment in the district and surrounding area; 
C.  The city shall determine if the applicants have the economic ability to perform the redevelopment. If multiple landowners operate separately, the city shall evaluate the applicant's ability to ensure all parties meet the desired goals and determine feasibility. Sunset and phasing conditions may be imposed to ensure the proposed action occurs within the proposed time frame. 
D.  As conditions warrant, the city shall take all vacation and funding actions essential to implementing the redevelopment plan. Failing to approve these conditions shall render the approval void. If a decision for approval must await a new budget cycle, the city shall have the right to hold the final approval until such a determination can be made. 
E.  All density bonus calculations shall be based on the original area of the PRO district, not including any land gained by vacations to be made by the city. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.234 - Approvals. 
    Approval is a two-step process. Each step must go through the hearing process. A preliminary approval is based on a preliminary plan. Final approval requires submitting and approval of a final plat. Final plat approval shall be granted if the plat: 
A.  Generally conforms to the preliminary plat; 
B.  All engineering is acceptable to the city; 
C.  All required financing or other surety required for public or community improvements are acceptable to the city; 
D.  The approval is limited to the specific plan. Should that plan not be built, the controlling standards remain that of the underlying zoning district. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.235 - Mapping. 
    Upon receiving preliminary approval, the zoning map shall be amended to indicate the boundary of the PRO district. The letters PRO, the word "pending," and the date of approval shall be placed on the zoning map. The underlying districts letters shall also appear within the boundary. Upon receiving final approval, the word "pending" shall be removed and the district given a file number for future reference. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.240 - Variances. 
    This section sets forth the procedures and conditions for a variance from the standards of this title which permit, under limited circumstances, a building or structure to be built that does not comply with all standards in this title. A variance may be appropriate when strict enforcement would represent a unique, undue and unnecessary hardship. Under no conditions shall a variance allow a use that is not otherwise permitted in the district. The applicant shall be instructed to submit a zone change request, which is the only way such a change of use may occur. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.241 - Standards for variances. 
    To approve a variance, the decision-making body shall find that all of the following standards without exception are met based on the evidence presented by staff reports and testimony: 
A.  There are special circumstances or conditions which are peculiar to the land or building for which the variance is sought that do not apply generally to lots, land or buildings in the neighborhood. 
B.  The special circumstances and conditions have not resulted from any act of the applicant subsequent to the adoption of this title. 
C.  The special circumstances and conditions are such that the strict application of the provisions of this title would deprive the applicant of the reasonable use of the land or building. 
D.  The granting of the variance is necessary to provide the applicant a reasonable use of the land or building. 
E.  The variance granted is the minimum necessary to make possible the reasonable use of the land or building. 
F.  The granting of the variance will not be injurious to the neighborhood surrounding the land where the variance is proposed and is otherwise not detrimental to the public welfare. 
G.  The granting of the variance is in harmony with the purposes and intent of this title. 
H.  The granting of the variance is consistent with the comprehensive plan. 
I.  Financial hardship to the applicant shall not be the sole basis for the decision. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.242 - Conditions and restrictions on variances. 
    In approving the application for any variance, the decision-making body may impose additional restrictions and conditions on such approval, including limits on the use of the property, the standards for locating the use, standards for mitigating the impact on adjoining property owners who would lose protection as a result of permitting the variance, or standards to protect the general health, safety and welfare. All conditions imposed upon any variance shall be expressly set forth in writing with the granting of such variance. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.243 - Subsequent development approvals. 
    Development approved by the variance shall not be carried out until the applicant has secured all other development approvals required by this title. The approval of a variance shall apply only to that section of the regulations for which it is approved, and does not ensure that the development shall receive subsequent approval unless the relevant and applicable portions of this title or other ordinances are met. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.244 - Amendment to a variance. 
    A variance may be amended, extended, varied or altered only pursuant to the standards and procedures for the original approval of a variance. An application for the same variance on the same site may not be considered within twelve months of the date of final action on the prior application. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
ARTICLE IV - APPEALS AND INTERPRETATIONS 

17.100.300 - Appeals and interpretations. 
    This article contains rules and standards for appealing the decisions made pursuant to this title. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.310 - Appeals. 
    There are two types of appeals, administrative appeals and judicial relief. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.311 - Administrative appeals. 
    Administrative appeals shall be heard based solely on the materials (plans, documents, reports, studies, drawings and testimony) available to the official or body rendering the decision. Appeals shall not consider new or altered plans. However, information submitted, but not discussed or considered in rendering a decision shall be considered part of the original evidence. New evidence shall not be permitted. If the body rendering a decision on the appeal believes that there is insufficient evidence to render a decision, it shall remand the matter back to the person or body that made the original decision, stating specific reasons for remanding the matter and the purpose for conducting the public hearing to obtain additional evidence. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.312 - Persons may appeal. 
    Any party can appeal. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.313 - Requirements for application. 
    Applications for an appeal shall clearly articulate the reasons for the appeal, specifically citing and explaining one or more alleged errors: 
A.  In applying adopted city plans, policies and ordinances in arriving at the decision; 
B.  In the appealed action or decision, including its stated facts; 
C.  In acting arbitrarily or capriciously or being manifestly abusive of discretion. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.314 - Procedures for appeals. 
    In addition to the procedures established in Sections 17.100.152 and 17.100.153, the following additional procedures shall be applicable to public hearings for appeals: 
A.  An untimely appeal shall not be considered, pursuant to Section 17.100.154(C) of this title. 
B.  The planning department staff shall provide written notice of the date, time and place of the public hearing to the applicant, a representative of the opponents, if any are known, and the appellant at least ten working days prior to the hearing. A similar notice shall be mailed to any interested persons who have provided stamped, self-addressed envelopes for such purpose. 
C.  The body hearing the appeal shall hold a hearing on the entire record sent to it and shall not consider new evidence or testimony. The decision on the appeal may be to reverse, affirm or modify the original decision. 
D.  If it appears that some additional evidence is necessary for the proper disposition of the matter, the body hearing the appeal shall remand the matter back to the person or body from which the original decision came with the specific reasons for the remand. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.315 - Administrative appeal standards. 
    The purpose of the appeal is to determine if the original decision met the requirements of this title. The body hearing the appeal is limited to the following determinations: 
A.  The decision maker made an error in reviewing whether a standard was met. The record must indicate that there was an error in judgment, or misreading of facts, plans or regulations in determining whether this standard was met. 
B.  Where conflicting evidence exists, the appeal is limited to determining what evidence or testimony bears the greatest credibility. 
C.  The decision maker made the decision on standards not contained in this or other city ordinances, regulations or state law; or a standard was applied more strictly or broadly than is appropriate to implement the comprehensive plan and this title. This title does not permit administrative decision makers to consider or create standards that are not officially adopted. 
D.  The decision maker made an error in applying a standard or measuring a standard. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.316 - Judicial relief. 
    The final decision on any application may be appealed to the district court, pursuant to Section 3-21-9 NMSA 1978, provided all administrative remedies have been exhausted. Specifically, denials that could be approved via a variance or a beneficial use appeal shall be submitted to the courts only upon the completion of the procedures specified in this title. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.320 - Beneficial use determination. 
A.  The purpose and intent of this title is that every landowner in Clovis should enjoy a beneficial use of their property. A beneficial use determination is a process by which the city evaluates the allegation that there is no beneficial use, and can provide relief from the regulations by granting additional development potential to provide a beneficial use of the property. It is also the intent of this section that such relief not increase the potential for damaging the health, safety or welfare of future users of the property or neighbors that might reasonably be anticipated if the landowner were permitted to build. 
B.  In the event that a landowner in Clovis is of the opinion that all beneficial use of that landowner's property has been denied, or taken by the application of this title, then the procedures of Sections 17.100.320-17.100.323 shall be used prior to seeking relief from the courts in order that any denial of beneficial use of property may be remedied through a nonjudicial forum. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.321 - Special application data. 
    The nature of this appeal requires detailed financial information on the property that is not required or desired in normal applications. The following data shall accompany all applications for a beneficial use appeal: 
A.  Documentation of the date of purchase and the purchase price of the property; 
B.  A description of the physical features present on the property, the property's total acreage, and the present use of the property, and the use of the property at the time of the adoption of this title; 
C.  A description of the specific portions of the regulations which are alleged to result in an elimination of all beneficial use of the property together with all appraisals, studies, any other supporting evidence, and any actions taken by the city related to the property; 
D.  A description of the use which the landowner believes represents the minimum beneficial use of the property and all documentation, studies, and other evidence supporting that position; 
E.  Documentation that the property has been listed for sale for at least six months after the adoption of this title, and originals or copies of all bids, offers-to-purchase, and other correspondence regarding the sale of such property. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.322 - Deprivation standards. 
    In determining if a landowner has been deprived of beneficial use of property, the hearing officer and the city commission shall take into account the following factors: 
A.  Diminution in Value. The value of the property prior to adoption of this title which caused the landowner to apply for relief shall be compared to the value of the property with the regulations as applied. A mere diminution in value does not deprive the landowner of a beneficial use; the diminution must be so drastic that it effectively deprives the landowner of any significant use or enjoyment of the property. 
B.  Common Land Uses. A use common to the city and/or the area of the subject site, although it may not involve further development of the land, is considered a beneficial use. Attention shall also be given to land uses that are considered to be the lowest intensity in the city or adjoining areas but which uses still provide for occupation and living by the landowner. These land uses shall be considered beneficial uses. 
C.  Unique Treatment. Whether or not the property is being singled out for different treatment than similarly situated properties under this title. 
D.  Subsidy. A minimum beneficial use of the land should be one that does not have any governmental subsidy attached to the use or long-term safe occupation of the property. If such a subsidy exists, then it should be reflected in considering minimum beneficial use on a valuation basis. The public costs of a subsidy should be considered as a payment to the landowner for the restriction on the property if there is an annual subsidy that enhances the economic return of the existing use to the landowner. To reflect the degree to which a subsidy enhances the property value, the value of a proposed use shall be adjusted by determining value of the use without the subsidy. 
E.  Adverse Impacts. The extent to which the regulations protect users or neighbors from threats to health or safety shall be fully accounted for. A use that seriously threatens the health of future residents or neighbors is not a beneficial use. 
F.  Expectations. Expectations shall, in general, not be considered. Expectations shall only be considered if they are backed by investments, made prior to the adoption of the restrictions in question, that are substantially above the cost of the land and normal planning investments, shall they be considered. 
G.  Nuisances. In no case shall a use that is a nuisance per se, or a use that in that particular location constitutes a nuisance, be granted as relief. Such uses are not legal uses of the land and thus no taking of beneficial use of the land can occur. The hearing officer shall recommend denial if the proposed use or current use to be discontinued is a nuisance. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.323 - Granting of relief. 
    If the hearing officer finds a landowner has been denied all beneficial use of his property, then he shall recommend that relief be granted. 
A.  Minimum Increase. In granting relief, the landowner shall be given the minimum increase in use intensity or other possible concessions from this title to permit a beneficial use of the land. The highest use, or even an average reasonable expectation, is not required or intended as the appropriate remedy. The following guidelines shall be used for determining the minimum beneficial use of property and, therefore, the amount of relief to be granted a landowner to reach that minimum. 
1.  The standards of Section 17.100.322 shall be used to indicate the need for additional density or uses. 
2.  The limited development potential, given the natural condition of the property, shall not be attributed to the regulations applied to the property. If the property is such that it cannot safely accommodate development with normal grading and clearing practices, this fact shall be taken into account in identifying the best site for development that minimizes costs of development. Any savings to the developer in land modification shall be considered in determining the beneficial use. 
3.  The potential for damages to either residents or property shall be assessed in determining a beneficial use. Conditions shall be placed on sites where damage from building on hazardous conditions is likely. The conditions may include location restrictions, size limitations, construction practices, and shall require a building to be built so it will not be damaged. 
B.  Granting of Relief. The decision of the hearing officer shall be ratified by the city commission at its next regularly scheduled meeting. The ratification shall be by resolution. If the city commission does not ratify a grant of relief recommended by the hearing officer, it shall conduct a public hearing to amend this title in accordance with the standards of Section 17.100.212. Under no conditions shall relief be granted unless there is a finding of no beneficial use. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.330 - Interpretations. 
    An interpretation is required when this title's provisions are not clear or when a use is proposed that is not listed in Tables 17.30.110 and 17.30.111. Sections 17.100.331-17.100.335 shall guide the planning department staff in rendering an official interpretation. Any person may seek an interpretation, provided it is associated with a proposed use of land. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.331 - Unlisted uses. 
    Uses not listed in Chapters 17.30 and 17.150 shall be placed into the most similar category. For nonresidential use, the SIC code shall be the first guide. Where an SIC code is found in several categories, the interpretation shall seek similar characteristics, including the intensity of the use and its likely impacts. Where a choice remains after reviewing impacts, the use should be classified with the similar use with the most impacts. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.332 - Meaning or application. 
    When evaluating a provision of this title as to its meaning or application, the provisions of Section 17.110.010 on legislative intent shall be applied. Interpretations shall not lessen protection, but may provide greater flexibility in meeting this title's objectives. Determining the public health, safety and welfare purposes of the provision shall guide the decision. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.333 - Procedure. 
    The planning department shall evaluate the request in light of the comprehensive plan, this title, and/or the zoning map, whichever is appropriate; may consult with the city attorney; and then shall render a written interpretation. The interpretation shall be mailed to the applicant within twenty days of receipt of a complete application. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.334 - Official record. 
    The planning department staff shall maintain a record of all interpretations rendered. This record shall be available for public inspection in the planning department, upon reasonable request, during normal business hours. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.335 - Annual review. 
    By January 25th of each year, the planning department staff shall report to the planning and zoning commission and the city commission of interpretations made. The agencies and planning department staff shall report to the city commission as to whether they agree or disagree with the interpretations. Should the city commission disagree with the interpretation(s), they shall direct the planning department staff not to follow said interpretations in subsequent applications. Further, they shall instruct the planning department staff to prepare amendments to this title to clarify their intent. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
ARTICLE V - ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEDURES 

17.100.400 - Administrative procedures. 
    Specific administrative procedures may require standards in addition to those stated in Article 2 of this chapter and are given in this article. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.410 - Limited use review. 
    The planning department staff shall make limited use reviews. Such reviews shall be limited solely to determining whether the conditions in Sections 17.50.200-17.50.226 for limited uses have been met. If they have, then that criteria for approval shall be deemed met and a report noting same attached to the file. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.100.420 - Zoning permit. 
    A zoning permit shall be required prior to the receipt of a building permit for all uses permitted by right, in accordance with the provisions of this article to ensure proposed development complies with this title's standards and has any required permits for access, water, sewer, etc. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
Chapter 17.110 - ADOPTION AND PURPOSES 

17.110.000 - Purpose. 
    This title implements the city comprehensive plan and promotes the health, safety and general welfare of Clovis's present and future inhabitants and businesses by: 
A.  Land Use Patterns and Community Character. 
1.  Establishing rational land use and growth patterns and encouraging the most appropriate use of individual pieces of land in accordance with the comprehensive plan; 
2.  Dividing the city into districts of distinct community character according to the use of land and buildings, the intensity of such use (including bulk and height), and the surrounding open space to promote health and safety; 
3.  Providing suitable transitions between areas of different community character to minimize the amount of incompatible land use and adverse impacts on property value; 
4.  Regulating and restricting the location and use of buildings, structures and land for trade, industry, residences, and other uses; 
5.  Providing protection from noise, glare, odor or vibration through buffers and other regulations; 
6.  Securing adequate natural light, clean air, privacy, convenient and safe access to property, and a safe environment; 
7.  Limiting the bulk, scale and density of new and existing structures to preserve the desired character of Clovis and its various neighborhoods for residents and to promote and encourage the community's growth and economic health; 
8.  Encouraging high quality, attractive and marketable development for the resident and future population and businesses; 
9.  Providing standards limiting the location and spacing of uses considered to present problems for the city in terms of increased incidents of crime or other social problems. 
B.  Natural and Cultural Resources. 
1.  Protecting ground and surface water resources for safe and secure drinking water upon which the city's population depend; 
2.  Controlling the density, open space, land use and vegetative cover so as to prevent ground and surface water contamination; 
3.  Protecting life and property by avoiding or lessening the hazards of flooding, stormwater accumulation, runoff or destabilization and movement of soils by district or performance standards. 
C.  Public Infrastructure. 
1.  Creating an environment that is safe from fire, flood and other dangers; 
2.  Protecting residents by facilitating development patterns that are cost effective to provide with public services; 
3.  Encouraging the most efficient use of existing and planned public facilities and utilities; 
4.  Ensuring adequate and safe roads and facilities by limiting land use intensity to the capacity of the roads or facilities and controlling access; 
5.  Protecting and enhancing a pattern of streets and arterial streets and highways that produces a unified, safe and efficient system for movement; 
6.  Reducing the danger and congestion of traffic on roads and highways by both limiting the number of friction points, such as intersections and driveways, and minimizing other hazards; 
7.  Protecting residential streets from degradation by nonresidential traffic; 
8.  Establishing and regulating setback lines along streets and highways, property lines and drainage facilities to ensure adequate and safe facilities; 
9.  Promoting economy in governmental expenditures; 
10.  Promoting and encouraging basic public services which meet the needs of the people of Clovis and provide for public safety and services that ensure the health of residents and businesses. 
D.  Justifiable Expectations. 
1.  Protecting and enhancing the values of land and buildings; 
2.  Seeking to balance the impact of regulations by permitting clustering and a greater variety of uses to offset restrictions; 
3.  Protecting landowners from adverse impacts of adjoining developments; 
4.  Protecting and respecting the justifiable reliance of existing residents and businesses on the continuation of existing, established and planned land use patterns; 
5.  Maintaining a desirable lifestyle for residents; 
6.  Protect residents' welfare and morals by regulating adult uses that have created problems in the city, other cities in New Mexico, and around the nation. 
E.  Administration. 
1.  Defining the powers and duties of administrative officers and bodies necessary to administer this title; 
2.  Prescribing penalties for the violation of the provisions of this title. 
    Each purpose listed above serves to balance the interests of the general public of Clovis and those of individual property owners. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.110.010 - Legislative intent. 
    This title is intended to protect the interests of both present and future residents and the general public from adverse impacts of land uses. Each standard is developed as a regulatory response to an identifiable negative impact or potential. At the same time, this title is intended to respect the right of landowners to a beneficial use of their property. These regulations were designed to provide greater flexibility and more development options to protect public rights and to minimize impact on property owners to the greatest extent consistent with good planning principles. A sound interpretation of any standard cannot be ensured without a careful analysis of the end to which the regulation is directed. Administrators and other persons shall interpret this title based on an understanding of the purposes intended. The intent of the standards and supporting definitions is to protect both individual property owners and the general public from adverse impacts which might otherwise be the result of a proposed land use. To this end, those called upon to interpret this title shall proceed as follows: 
A.  Public Purpose. Before any decision is made, there must be an explicit identification of the purposes for which the regulation or standard was initially imposed by the legislative body. This shall include the purposes stated in this title and its relevant chapter(s), article(s) or section(s), and an examination of the comprehensive plan. 
B.  Impact. Two questions must be asked to determine the actual impact of various proposed interpretations: 
1.  Does the interpretation reduce protection to the public or occupants of the site? 
2.  Does the interpretation provide greater freedom to the landowner to use the property? 
C.  Decision Criteria. The decision should permit flexibility in design provided that it shall not lower the protection afforded to the public. An interpretation which permits increased design freedom is to be encouraged. An interpretation which permits any of the following is prohibited: 
1.  A use prohibited in the district or a use similar to a prohibited use; 
2.  An intensity increase in the use beyond the degree specified in this title; 
3.  A decrease in a standard that reduces the protection afforded neighbors, the environment or the general public; 
4.  A decrease in a standard that would endanger users of a property or others. 
D.  Balancing Rights. This title has been carefully designed to avoid regulations that either sacrifice legitimate public goals, including the protection of adjoining property owners, or require undue limitations on the ability of property owners to use their land in manners consistent with the goals of the city comprehensive plan. Great care has been taken to both balance the rights of competing groups and achieve maximum protection with flexibility and a range of use options. Persons interpreting this title shall not substitute their judgments for the legislative intent of the city commission. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.110.100 - Severability. 
    If any article, section, paragraph, clause, provision or portion of this title is adjudged unconstitutional or invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of this title shall not be affected. If any application of this title to a particular structure, land or water is adjudged unconstitutional or invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such judgment shall not be applicable to any other structure, land or water not specifically included in said judgment. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
Chapter 17.150 - DEFINITIONS 

17.150.000 - Purpose. 
    This chapter defines words, terms and phrases found in this title. 
(Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996). 
17.150.100 - Word usage. 
    The provisions and rules of this chapter shall be observed and applied when interpreting this title, except when the context clearly requires otherwise: 
A.  Words used or defined in one tense or form shall include other tenses or forms. 
B.  Words in the singular number shall include the plural number. Words in the plural number shall include the singular number. 
C.  The masculine gender shall include the feminine. The feminine gender shall include the masculine. 
D.  The word "shall" is mandatory. 
E.  The word "may" is permissive. 
F.  The word "person" includes individuals, firms, corporations, associations, trusts, and any other similar entities. 
G.  The word "attorney" means the Clovis city attorney. 
H.  The words "building code" mean the current Curry County building code. 
I.  The word "city" means the city of Clovis, New Mexico. 
J.  The words "comprehensive plan" mean the comprehensive plan of the city of Clovis. It includes all maps, charts and explanatory materials adopted in April 1992 and subsequent amendments. 
K.  The word "commission" means the Clovis city commission. 
L.  The words "planning and zoning commission" mean the Clovis planning and zoning commission. 
M.  The words "planning department" mean the staff of the Clovis planning department. 
N.  The words "recorder of deeds" mean the Curry County clerk's office. 
O.  The words "registered engineer" mean an engineer registered in the state of New Mexico. 
P.  The word "state" means the state of New Mexico. 
Q.  The letters "SIC" mean the Standard Industrial Classification (as listed in the 1987 manual printed by the Executive Office of the President, Office of Management and Budget). 
R.  The phrase "zoning board" means the Clovis planning and zoning commission. 
S.  The words "zoning map" refer to the official zoning map of the city of Clovis, New Mexico. 
(Ord. 1524-97 § 2(part), 1997; Ord. 1495-96 § 3(part), 1996).

    The following abbreviations are used in this title:
